But she admits the turmoil that kept the exclusive liberal arts college in the news much of last year gave her parents second thoughts about her choice of schools. Two campus firebombings, the slaying of a student activist, rising racial tensions and publicity about drug use gave parents plenty to think about. ``I wasn't really disturbed by it, but there was a point where my father said, `Maybe you shouldn't go there,''' Donofrio, 18, of Southport. She spoke last week as she waited in line to register for classes, which begin Wednesday. School officials acknowledge that events of the past year contributed to a decline in enrollment. Thirty-six percent of those accepted by the school have enrolled, down from 38 percent last year, or 663 freshmen, down from 684. Among Connecticut residents, who were closer to the publicity, enrollment in this year's freshman class is down from 71 to 47. ``We took a hit, but I think it's momentary,'' said Wesleyan President William M. Chace. ``I'm just not of the belief that we're some deeply wounded, crippled institution that is worse off than other universities.'' Wesleyan, where annual costs for each of the 2,700 students will top $20,000 this year, has a reputation for academic excellence pursued in a less formal, more pastoral setting than its neighbor to the south, Yale University. But school last year began inauspiciously with news stories about an unofficial annual rite of passage at Wesleyan, a marijuana-smoking bash. Some students asserted that the administration looked the other way when it came to drug use, something school officials vehemently denied. The campus was outwardly quiet until April, when the firebombing of Chace's office fomented simmering racial tension. A second firebombing, at the Wesleyan boathouse, followed a few weeks later. Several students, including Nicholas B. Haddad, a 21-year-old sophomore from Lebanon, charged that the administration and local police unfairly singled out black students in their investigation of the firebombings. Tensions increased when racial slurs were found spray painted in the basement of the Malcolm X House, a residence housing 26 black students. Some students staged demonstrations, including a nine-day hunger strike, to protest the university's minority policies. Just when the summer break promised a respite, Haddad was found shot to death in a Hartford park, a cache of weapons in his car. Police concluded he was slain by two men with whom he was setting up a drug distribution ring. Among those charged in Haddad's death was Kumar Viswanathan, the 21-year-old son of Tanjore Viswanathan, an adjunct professor at Wesleyan and a prominent musicians. Then Viswanathan's cousin, Sudhama Ranganathan, 18, was charged in the firebombing of Chace's office. His late father also was a faculty member at Wesleyan. Chace said last week that the school is addressing student concerns over minority issues. It has hired boosted minority hiring and received a $100,000 Ford Foundation grant to develop new courses in multiculturalism. Freshmen attended discussions on race relations during orientation week. But some students say the school may have a hard time returning to its former calm. ``I thought when we returned in the fall, things would have mellowed out, but with the murder of Nick Haddad, there will still be some tension here,'' said Christina Daly, a sophomore from Middletown, N.Y. Other students said they are optimistic that last year's turmoil won't spill over into the new school year. ``Last year a lot of consciousness was raised and people are talking more than they used to,'' said Liz Martin, a senior from Barre, Vt. Donofrio's mother, Margaret, said she and her husband no longer have reservations about their daughter's attending Wesleyan. ``I'm really not worried because most of the things that happened seemed limited to a few people,'' she said. ``The students seem to be able to roll with it and handle it.''

DOC.HEAD: Burial in Chile's Capital For Allende, 17 Years After His Death
LaserPhoto SCL1
DOC.TEXT: The remains of former Marxist President Salvador Allende are to be unearthed Tuesday from his modest tomb in a resort city for re-burial in Santiago, 17 years after his death in a bloody military coup. The government of President Patricio Aylwin, a political foe of Allende, has supported the plan to move Allende's remains to the capital. But right-wing politicians are bitterly criticizing it, reviving the controversy over Allende's three-year government. Tuesday, the day of the burial and ceremony, marks the 20th anniversary of the day Allende became the first Marxist freely elected president in a Western country. Three years later, Allende was toppled by Gen. Augusto Pinochet, whom he had named army commander. Allende died during in an attack on his presidential palace on Sept. 11, 1973, during the coup led by Pinochet. Allende, who according the military committed suicide rather than surrender, was buried the day after the coup in a modest family tomb in Vina del Mar, 75 miles northwest of Santiago. Hundreds of people visited the tomb Saturday and Sunday, placing a thick carpet of red carnations on it as police with automatic weapons stood guard. During Pinochet's 16{-year rule, the tomb remained unmarked. When supporters of the former president placed a plaque indicating he was buried there, it was quickly removed by authorities. After the Santiago ceremonies, Allende's remains will be buried at a mausoleum in the capital's main cemetery, where other former presidents and Chilean dignitaries are buried.

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: New Kids on the Block member Donnie Wahlberg got into a scuffle with a fellow passenger over an airline seat during a weekend flight from Salt Lake City to Atlanta, authorities said Monday. A police report said Wahlberg, 20, fought with the man in the coach section of Delta Air Lines Flight 1140 after it left Salt Lake City on Sunday. Wahlberg, who had been sitting in the first-class section of the plane, went to visit with members of his entourage sitting in the coach section. He departed briefly, then returned to resume his conversation and found the seat he had used was taken by the passenger, the police report said. The two began fighting. The report alleged Wahlberg poked the passenger in the eye and passenger allegedly responded by kicking Wahlberg in the stomach. The passenger was treated for minor injuries at South Fulton Medical Center and released. He declined to file charges against Wahlberg, the police report said. There was no comment Monday from Wahlberg; calls to his agent were not answered. It was the second Atlanta incident involving the rock group in less than a month. On Aug. 9, Steven Chandler of Boston, a bodyguard for New Kids singer Jordan Knight, was arrested on two counts of battery after an altercation at an nightclub.

For ABC Sports announcer Al Michaels, the arrival of Brent Musburger from CBS this spring was nothing to worry about, although there was speculation that Musberger might unseat Michaels as ABC's top announcer. ``Hey, that was the last thing I had to worry about, really,'' Michaels said in this week's TV Guide. ``My contract specifies what events I do. It's locked in. ``Brent is a great addition for ABC, and there's lots for him to do _ college football, spring football, golf, bowling, a lot of stuff.'' Michaels is perhaps best known as host of ``Monday Night Football'' and for his announcing during the 1980 Olympics when the U.S. hockey team upset the Soviet Union and during the earthquake that interrupted the 1989 World Series. ``It's such an irony that a guy who so loves baseball is best known for a hockey game and an earthquake,'' he said.

Robert Wagner and Stefanie Powers, stars of the 1979-84 TV series ``Hart To Hart,'' make their London stage debuts next month in an American play, ``Love Letters.'' A. R. Gurney's play, which was seen on Broadway last season, opens Oct. 1 at Wyndham's Theater for a four-week run. Wagner and Powers play lifelong friends whose relationship over the years is traced through readings of their letters to one another. The New York production employed different pairs of stars every week, from Jason Robards and Colleen Dewhurst to Timothy Hutton and Elizabeth McGovern. Wagner and Powers will appear throughout the London run.

Mikhail Gorbachev has been a lead player on the stage of history for years, so maybe it's appropriate that that he will soon be portrayed on a real stage. ``Moscow Gold,'' opening in London later this month, will bring to theater audiences an array of communist giants, from Lenin to the present-day Soviet president, to be played by David Calder. The play was written by London playwrights Howard Brenton and Tariq Ali, who were responsible for last year's ``Iranian Nights,'' about the plight of author Salman Rushdie under Moslem death threat. Calder says the play treats Gorbachev as someone on whom ``the fickle finger of historical fate suddenly lands, rather than a man of ambition desperate to get into the old Lenin seat.'' ``Moscow Gold'' opens Sept. 26 at the Royal Shakespeare Company's Barbican Theater. It runs through Nov. 3.

Country music singer Tammy Wynette just happened to spend the night in a motel where police had a standoff with an armed man who barricaded himself in his room for more than five hours. Customers in rooms near the man were evacuated and there were no injuries, Police Chief James Bozicevich said. The man, who was alone in the room, surrendered after authorities broke a window early Monday and tossed in two tear gas canisters, Bozicevich said. Neither Miss Wynette nor any member of her crew was associated with the man or incident, Bozicevich said. The chief said Miss Wynette was staying in a part of the hotel which was not evacuated. She was in the Iron Range area of northern Minnesota to perform at Ironworld USA in nearby Chisholm. The chief said someone reported late Sunday that the man, a customer at the motel, had pointed a gun at someone. No shots were fired, the chief said. The man, from Mayfield, Ky., had more than one gun in his possession when he surrendered, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Japan, Soviets to Set Aside Border Dispute for Better Ties
DOC.TEXT: Japan and the Soviet Union hold top-level talks this week amid growing willingness on both sides to improve relations even if a stubborn 45-year-old land dispute remains unresolved. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze arrives Tuesday for talks with his Japanese counterpart and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu. Moscow's ties with Japan have not kept pace with its improving relations with Western countries. This is because of continuing bitterness over a group of small islands off northern Japan seized by Soviet troops in the final days of World War II. For years, Japan has demanded that the islands be returned. The two countries never formally signed a treaty ending World War II hostilities as a result of the dispute. But both sides now say they are willing to discuss a broad range of cooperation while continuing their negotiations on the territorial question. ``There's definitely been a shift,'' said George Komarovsky, counselor at the Soviet Embassy in Tokyo. ``We have begun to find a common language,'' he said. ``In the recent past when the two sides met, they talked only about the territorial problem and there was only confrontation. Now there is a very constructive dialogue on international relations, and on many issues our positions are identical.'' That view was echoed by a Japanese Foreign Ministry official, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``We consider (a solution of the border issue) as being the most important goal, but at the same time we have made it clear that we are not saying that Japan-Soviet relations consist only of this single issue,'' the official said. ``We are prepared to find other common areas where we can make progress.'' In another sign of change, Kaifu directed Japan's Defense Agency to delete references to a ``Soviet threat'' in its annual policy paper due out this month, Kyodo News Service reported Monday. Shevardnadze's talks with Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama and Kaifu are expected to focus on preparations for a visit by Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev next year, the first by a Soviet leader. Japan has proposed 10 areas in which agreements could be reached during the visit, including economic, technical and cultural cooperation and assistance to victims of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant accident, the Foreign Ministry official said. Japan has indicated its willingness to provide technical support for Gorbachev's reforms in areas such as management training, said the official, who briefed reporters on condition of anonymity. Shevardnadze is expected to ask that Soviet banks be allowed to open branches in Japan and to seek Japanese joint ventures in the Soviet Union. He also is likely to ask for Japanese participation in a new collective Asian security organization. Details are expected to be outlined in a speech the Soviet official is to give in the eastern Soviet port city of Vladivostok before his arrival, ministry officials said. Some analysts predict the Soviet Union will urge Japan to join the security arrangement in exchange for a withdrawal of Soviet troops from the contested islands. The two sides also are likely to discuss the Middle East crisis, Cambodia and tensions on the Korean peninsula, Japanese and Soviet officials said. In meetings in China last week, Shevardnadze and Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen urged that force be avoided in the gulf. Shevardnadze is likely to make the same point with Japanese officials.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets: Summit to Be Long on Business, Short on `Theatrics'
DOC.TEXT: Presidents George Bush and Mikhail S. Gorbachev plan an informal meeting in Helsinki focusing on the Persian Gulf and other issues without the ``theatrics'' of previous summits, a Soviet spokesman said Monday. The summit, proposed by Bush, will build on the personal rapport the presidents established at previous meetings, Foreign Ministry spokesman Gennady Gerasimov told a news briefing ``Such personal meetings, both presidents believe, offer a unique possibility to compare notes on the fast-changing situation, grasp each other's reasoning better, and consequently, help enhance constructive trends and neutralize negative developments in the world today,'' Gerasimov said. ``The first summits _ they were to establish personal relations and to discuss things in general terms. But now they have concrete business, what to do in the Persian Gulf, what to do with our arms talks in Vienna and Geneva, what to do with Germany.'' Gorbachev and Bush will meet in the Finnish capital for one day with only their foreign ministers and chiefs of staff, Gerasimov said. He said the presidents discussed the possibility of holding such meetings on short notice with no formal agenda during their talks at Camp David in June. ``The concept of promptly arranged, trustful contacts at summit level fits in perfectly with the new fiber of Soviet-American dialogue, based on the renunciation of Cold War stereotypes,'' he said. The Soviet spokesman said relations between Moscow and Washington are moving away from ``theatrics ... to really a working level when the leaders meet not to exchange compliments, not to organize a mutual admiration society ... but to talk business, and now they have business, a lot of business.'' Gerasimov said he doubted Gorbachev would try to contact Iraqi President Saddam Hussein before the summit. He said Moscow has not been asked to play a mediating role in the crisis that began with Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The last of the 941 Soviet women and children stranded in Iraq returned to Moscow on Monday, but Gerasimov said he did not know when about 7,000 Soviet men remaining in Iraq could be evacuated. He acknowledged the continued presence of 193 Soviet military advisers in Iraq was embarrassing but said removing them was ``a very delicate situation for us.'' The military experts have been training Iraqi soldiers how to use Soviet-built weapons, and repairing and maintaining those weapons. Soviet officials insist they were not advising Baghdad about the invasion of Kuwait. ``It's an unhappy situation that we have so many Soviet experts there, but we started this in 1972 when we signed a treaty of friendship and cooperation with Iraq, and they asked us to send advisers to many places,'' Gerasimov said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush's Pass-The-Plate Strategy Questioned
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is dispatching two high-level missions this week on a global search for billions of dollars to support the economic and military campaign against Saddam Hussein _ a strategy some say is unbecoming of a superpower. One delegation, led by Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, leaves Tuesday for stops in Paris, London, Seoul, South Korea and Tokyo, passing the plate in search of as much as $25 billion to help defray the expense of the American troop deployment and to aid nations suffering hardships from the economic embargo against Iraq. Secretary of State James A. Baker III leaves later in the week on a similar whirlwind trip looking for assistance in the capitals of oil-rich Persian Gulf countries. Bush announced the burden sharing effort just last Thursday and on Monday officials were still scrambling to put together itineraries for the hastily scheduled trips. The fact that Bush was sending two of his closest Cabinet advisers served to emphasize the importance the president was attaching to the task of getting other countries to share the burden. However, administration officials conceded that the sales job was not going to be easy. Bush's effort has also raised questions about the propriety of issuing a global call for donations to support the U.S. military. Critics charged that it left the appearance that America's soldiers are up for hire as mercenaries. ``I don't want to leave any impression in the world that we pay for our soldiers and our sailors if we send them into another part of the world only through another country's money,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt. ``This is not a rent military. It's not a mercenary force.'' Leahy said a better approach to take would be to boost taxes if necessary to pay for the Persian Gulf buildup. Bush has vigously rejected suggestions that putting pressure on the allies for money to support the U.S. military was improper and he has received support for this position from other members of Congress. ``The Japanese have a hell of a stake in this and they ought to pay a hell of a share,'' said Sen. Frank Lautenberg, D-N.J. Many congressmen noted that Japan and many countries in Europe are more dependent on the flow of oil from the Persian Gulf than the United States is. Still, many private analysts saw the pledge-seeking missions as stark examples of where America's global fortunes now stand. As the world's largest debtor nation, burdened by huge trade and budget deficits, the United States no longer has the economic muscle to go it alone. ``We are no longer the economic super power we used to be,'' said Lawrence Chimerine of the Economic Strategy Institute, a Washington research organization. ``Our changing role in the world economy is clearly in evidence here.'' In launching the burden sharing initiative last week, Bush maintained that the ``shape of the post-Cold War world'' was at stake in the Persian Gulf crisis. C. Fred Bergsten, a former Treasury Department official in the Carter administration, said that Bush's hasty effort could well serve as a prototype for future global cooperation in which the U.S. military would stand ready to preserve peace with financial backing from other countires. Bergsten said that a more formal agreement, perhaps under the auspices of the United Nations, may evolve from the current conflict with the expected contribution from each country spelled out more clearly in advance of any conflict. That would relieve one of the problems in the current crisis in which many U.S. allies have been slow to make economic commitments. While it is recognized that Germany is facing huge costs in the reunification effort in its country, critics contend that the $1 billion pledged so far by Japan stops far short of what that country should be doing. However, a more formal arrangement that committed the United States to putting U.S. soliders in harm's way to police the world's hot spots would raise political opposition, Bergsten concedes. ``Some Americans are not going to like that because it sounds like we are mercenaries,'' Bergsten said. ``But the fact is that the world is an insecure place and we have the military capability to make a difference.''

DOC.HEAD: University's Bugfest Offers `The Fly', Petting Zoo
LaserPhoto DC1
DOC.TEXT: With corn borers in the corn bread and crickets in the chocolate, there must be fly in the ointment at Iowa State University. But not so, say the entomologists. Their Insect Horror Film Festival at the Ames campus this week is designed to give bugs a better name, not to mention a better flavor. Not only can you see how bugs are portrayed in bad movies, but there will be ``treats'' for those with enough intestinal fortitude to try chocolate covered grasshoppers or roasted larvae. Those who prefer their bugs on the hoof will delight in a petting zoo featuring cockroaches, drone bees, tarantulas, giant walking sticks, water beetles and dragonfly nymphs. For some 300 guests, there will be praying mantises to take home. ``When we think of bugs, we tend to dwell on those insects that we don't like or make us uncomfortable,'' said John Obrycki, an entomology professor. ``Insects get a lot of negative press.'' That's especially true in Iowa, where farmers are on a mission to stamp out bugs. ``Yes, there are pests,'' said Obrycki. ``But when you go out and try to kill all the bugs in a field, you'll kill far more good ones than bad.'' But that wisdom hasn't sunk in for adults, he said. Hence, the horror show, which runs Thursday through Saturday. ``In kids' films, bugs are mostly friendly, Jiminy Cricket type stuff and `Honey, I Shrunk the Kids,' '' he said. ``I've taken 2-inch-long cockroaches into first grades and the kids love it. They all want to hold it. ``But you take the same insect into the undergraduate class I teach here, most people would just as soon not handle it,'' he said. ``I don't know where the dividing point is, but somewhere along the line we learn not to like insects.'' Especially not for meals. But there's nothing harmful about corn borers, roasted and ground up as a flour substitute, he said. ``And we'll have garlic fried larvae that you find on clover leaves,'' said entomology undergraduate student Cynthia Lidtke. What kind? ``Large green and yellow ones,'' she said. ``I gave some to my daughter and she thought they were good.'' The festival kicks off Thursday with ``An Itch in Time,'' a cartoon featuring a singing flea. Two bug cartoons will be shown before each feature _ things like ``The Fly,'' ``Bug'' and ``Them.''

DOC.HEAD: Former President Reagan Likens Saddam Hussein to Hitler
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 2nd graf to CORRECT Nixon to Reagan.
DOC.TEXT: Former President Ronald Reagan has joined President Bush and others in likening Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to Nazi leader Adolf Hitler. Reagan barely mentioned the Middle East crisis in a weekend speech, but did say Arab nations' banding together against Saddam Hussein is ``reason for very great optimism.'' He called the Iraqi leader the ``reincarnation of Hitler.'' President Bush ``is doing very well in what is needed,'' he said in a speech at a copy service company's convention. Despite the Mideast crisis, Reagan, 79, said he is ``more optimistic than I've ever been'' about the prospect for freedom and peace in the world. Reagan spoke Sunday to more than 2,000 people at the Kwik-Kopy International Conference. He also talked about the importance of the free flow of information in a free society, even though he had requested that the press in general be prohibited from attending his speech, said Jan Norris, a spokesman for Kwik-Kopy. Reagan, whose speaking fee was not disclosed, said Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev understands that his government ``must allow the flow of information'' to prosper.

DOC.HEAD: Albanians Stage General Strike to Protest Serbian Rule
DOC.TEXT: Ethnic Albanians staged a general strike Monday to protest Serbian rule in Kosovo province in defiance of warnings that they would face suspension or lose their jobs. ``We are striking to show how we feel about the bad situation in Kosovo for Albanians,'' said Salem Lepaja, a university lecturer. The strike was called by independent trade unions set up recently by Kosovo's 1.9 million ethnic Albanians, who make up 90 percent of its population. Serbia's Communist government took administrative control of Kosovo last spring, saying it had to abolish the province's autonomy to protect the Serb minority from alleged harassment by the majority ethnic Albanians. In July, the Kosovo parliament proclaimed the province's independence from Serbia, which reacted by dismissing the lawmakers. Streets in this provincial capital were virtually deserted Monday. Almost all shops were closed. Pristina's usually lively bazaar was deserted, with empty stalls, the previous day's trash strewn about and a big metal gate chained shut. There were no reports of violence. Last week, Serbian authorities said 21 police and scores of demonstrators were injured in clashes with thousands of ethnic Albanians waiting for a U.S. Congressional delegation investigating charges of human rights abuses. The delegation, headed by Sen. Robert Dole, a Kansas Republican, criticized what it called ``a systematic pattern of violating the rights of Albanians.'' ``Trade union leaders asked us not to go out to avoid conflicts with the police,'' Lepaja told journalists in his home near the center of the city. ``We all expect we could lose our jobs,'' he said, adding that his wife, who works for a state firm, had already emptied her desk ``because she is convinced she will be fired tomorrow.'' ``But Albanians are ready for sacrifices _ the community has never been so united before,'' Lepaja declared. Officials of Serbia's provisional government in Kosovo said any ethnic Albanians absent from work in state companies on Monday faced dismissal. They threatened to replace them with workers brought in from Serbia. ``Ethnic Albanian managers and experts responsible for vital services will be replaced and suspended'' for taking part in the walkout, the Tanjug news agency quoted Momcilo Trajkovic, Serbia's vice premier in charge of the economy, as saying. Disciplinary and other ``legal measures'' will be taken against all strikers, and ``energetic actions'' will be implemented against the owners of private shops and groceries that fail to open, Trajkovic said. Kosovo was the core of Serbia's medieval kingdom and has strong sentimental value for most Serbs. Serbian leaders contend that if it were given sovereignty, it would secede and merge with neighboring Albania. More than 60 ethnic Albanians have died in the province in the past 18 months during protests against Serbian dominance. The bloody riots, a wave of arrests of ethnic Albanians and other Serbian policies have drawn strong protests from international human rights monitoring groups.

DOC.HEAD: Former KGB General Elected to Soviet Parliament
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Stands for AM-KGB General on news advisory.
DOC.TEXT: An ex-KGB general who alleged the secret police agency continues to spy on Soviet citizens scored a decisive victory in a runoff election for a seat in the Soviet parliament, officials said Monday. Oleg Kalugin won 57.9 percent of the vote in Sunday's voting for the seat in the southern Russian province of Krasnodar, about 750 miles south of Moscow, said Vladislav Busheyev, chairman of the regional Election Commission. Kalugin defeated Nikolai Gorovoi, an agricultural official who won 39.2 percent of the vote, Busheyev said in a telephone interview. ``My election victory is a manifestation that the revolutionary process is shifting from the center to the provinces,'' Kalugin told the independent Interfax news agency. The win ensures that Kalugin will have broad immunity to continue criticizing his former employers without fear of prosecution. Kalugin's campaign focused on his allegations that the KGB continues to tap telephones, infiltrate trade unions and the Russian Orthodox Church and play dirty tricks abroad, despite a campaign to shed its image as an instrument of purges and repression. Kalugin, 55, was dismissed and stripped of his rank after going public with his accusations in June. The Soviet prosecutor has been investigating him since July 17 under a law against divulging state secrets, but no formal charges have been filed. As an elected lawmaker, Kalugin cannot be prosecuted on criminal charges without the agreement of the Soviet legislature. The former major general was a KGB agent in the United States from 1958 to 1970, first under the cover of being a Radio Moscow correspondent and later as a first secretary in the Soviet Embassy in Washington. The KGB and its supporters tried to discredit Kalugin before an initial vote was held last month in Krasnodar, an agricultural region along the Black Sea. Kalugin outpolled 20 other candidates but did not win the required majority. Kalugin told the independent news agency Interfax on Monday that KGB agents were ``very active'' in Krasnodar and followed his campaign workers. On Saturday, the KGB accused him of slander for saying that two people who had once worked as assistants to KGB Chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov and his deputy chairman, Viktor Grushko, later defected. Kalugin made the allegations Friday night on the popular television program Vzglyad, or Viewpoint. The KGB called it ``another slanderous allegation by Oleg Kalugin.'' In a statement released by Tass, the KGB also said ``it is impossible to bypass the fact that many statements by Kalugin betray striking affinity to numerous statements'' by one of the defectors. The KGB said neither Kryuchkov nor Grushko ever had assistants who betrayed their country. Krasnodar's seat in the national Congress of People's Deputies, which meets twice a year, was vacated by Ivan Polozkov, who left to become the Communist Party chief of the Russian republic.

DOC.HEAD: Bread In Short Supply in Moscow for First Time Since Khrushchev
DOC.TEXT: Soviet citizens are used to waiting in line for bananas, paying under the table for meat and using ration coupons for sugar. But bread, that staple of the Russian diet, was always fresh and plentiful. Now that has changed. On Monday, Soviets lined up for bread at stores across Moscow for the first time in years. Many were grumbling, blaming President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms for shortages of a growing list of products that includes tobacco, paper, cheese and gasoline. Russian bread, which is chewy but wholesome and cheap because of government subsidies, had been one of the few products Soviet consumers could count on. The last time people remember long bread lines was under Premier Nikita Khrushchev, who was ousted from power in 1964. ``That's perestroika _ we're not moving forward, we're going backward,'' said Viktor Lyubeznov, a 52-year-old electrician who went to four Moscow bread stores before finding a loaf. ``Now we think freely, we speak freely, but the economic situation is more severe than ever,'' said Irina Samoruppa, 65. The shortage could undermine support for the political and economic reforms _ known as perestroika _ initiated by Gorbachev. Inside Moscow's Bread Store No. 150 on Monday, tempers flared as customers accused saleswomen of saving the last few loaves of white bread for themselves. ``Look, comrades, they have more left back there, they just won't sell it,'' one woman cried. ``You don't know what you're talking about, so just be quiet,'' answered a husky saleswoman in a white apron. Outside, people stood in clusters, commiserating and arguing. ``Never in my life have I ever had to search for bread before,'' said Anatoly Znamensky, a 66-year-old retired taxi driver. ``Vegetables, fruit, cheese, butter, meat _ they appear and disappear. But with bread there was never a problem, until now.'' ``Everything will be fine,'' said Mrs. Samoruppa. ``It isn't possible for this to continue very long.'' ``Anything's possible. You can't rule anything out anymore,'' said Valery Myutek. The bread shortage, which began late last week and worsened over the weekend, appeared to be limited primarily to Moscow, although bread rationing has been introduced in Tarusa, a small city to the south. The newspapers Moskovskaya Pravda and Izvestia said the capital's bakeries were unable to keep up with the sudden rise in demand when residents returned from their traditional August vacations. The problem is not a lack of grain. A record harvest is expected this year. Izvestia said the bottleneck is Moscow's central bread bakeries, which have undergone little expansion or modernization since the 1950s, when the population was about half the current 8.8 million. The shortage could be especially hard on the city's retirees. Some receive pensions of only $48 to $96 a month and survive largely on bread, which costs just 11 to 18 cents a pound, depending on the variety. The lack of bread comes on the heels of a summer-long shortage of tobacco, which led to street demonstrations in Moscow, strikes in other Russian cities and a riot in Siberia. In addition, gasoline has become hard to find. Hard cheese has virtually disappeared from stores in Moscow in recent weeks. As school reopened, shelves were bare of the notebooks children are required to use in class. Of all the shortages, however, bread is potentially the most politically troubling, if only because of its historical symbolism. When Lenin returned from exile to lead the revolution in 1917, his slogan promised Communism would bring ``Peace, Land and Bread.''

DOC.HEAD: Summit by Five Arab League Foreign Ministers Ends
DOC.TEXT: Foreign ministers from five Arab League nations ended a two-day summit on Monday by adopting a working document aimed at ending the crisis in the Persian Gulf. The document, whose contents were kept secret, was to be relayed to the leaders of Algeria, Libya, Mauritania, Morocco and Tunisia for further consideration. The ministers' closed-door discussions were not made public, but were believed to have included seeking an ``Arab solution'' to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and Libya's longstanding border dispute with Chad. A source close to the discussions said Monday there was a ``broad convergence of views'' on the implications of Iraq's invasion, as well as on measures to solve the situation. The five North African countries took opposing sides at the Arab League vote last month in Cairo on whether to support sending troops to the Gulf region as part of a multinational peacekeeping force. Morocco voted in favor of sending troops, Libya against and Algeria and Mauritania abstained. Tunisia boycotted the meeting. Morocco has committed about 1,200 troops to the peacekeeping operation.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Uganda Soldier Detained Without Trial 4 Years Freed by President
DOC.TEXT: President Yoweri Museveni freed a former army major who was held for four years but was never tried, officials said Monday. Fred K. Mpiso, described by human rights groups as a prisoner of conscience, was released Saturday by presidential pardon, officials said. Mpiso, 31, was arrested in May 1986 and charged with being drunk and neglecting his duties. He challenged the charge and was freed but was rearrested on a charge of treason in December. High Court Judge James H. Ntabgoba ordered Mpiso's release a month ago after the military failed to present the prisoner in court as demanded by his wife. The army, however, ignored Ntabgoba's order.

DOC.HEAD: For Those Without Insurance, Tornado Aftermath Particularly Hard
DOC.TEXT: A rusty toaster, a child's plastic sand bucket and some soggy clothes were just about all that an angry twister left behind when it came to call on Carol Levenston and her 4-year-old son. While hundreds of other Illinois tornado victims last week stood in line to see their insurance agents, Levenston, whose second child is due any day, pecked through the pile of rubble she once called home. ``We had just really got started here,'' said Levenston, 30. ``We thought about (insurance) but we just never expected this to come about.'' The tornadoes killed 27 people and demolished more than 270 homes and 14 apartment buildings last Tuesday in the small towns of Plainfield and Crest Hill, some 30 miles southwest of Chicago. An additional 639 dwellings were damaged. By week's end, many residents were meeting with insurance agents, calling building contractors and beginning to look to the future. ``We're totally covered,'' said Scott Ellerbrock of Plainfield. Ellerbrock joked he is ``31 years old going on 80,'' after the storm left only two walls of his house intact. He said his insurance agent had already issued him a check and that, for his family, the worst was over. ``Take your best shot _ I can take it,'' the Dow Chemical Co. worker said. ``I've been through hell and I made it.'' Ellerbrock plans to rebuild on the same site _ this time a larger house for his wife and two young children. Throughout the area, insurance agents scurried to meet demand left in the wake of the twisters.Many residents praised the quick response of their agents. ``They came out Wednesday morning _ figured it was a total loss for me,'' said Richard Vogen as he carried a few chairs from his three-bedroom home. Vogen said his agents issued him a check on the spot. Two disaster relief centers were set up by the state and federal governments to assist some victims with loans and outright grants. The newly appointed director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency, Wallace Stickney, toured the disaster area Monday and visited the two centers. Stickney, who also flew over the devastation in a helicopter, praised the quick response of federal and state emergency workers. ``We may be able to beat the response by a couple of hours next time, but I think we've set a record here that's going to be hard to match in the future,'' Stickney said. It is Stickney's first major disaster since taking over FEMA two weeks ago. Ron Buddecke, a regional FEMA official, said Friday that the agency antifipates serving a lot of people with insufficent insurance or no insurance. Many residents of the modest Crestlakes Apartment complex in Crest Hill, where at least nine of the fatalities occurred, said their losses had not been covered. Paul Hendrix, 30, pulled ``a pillowcase full'' of clothes from his apartment Friday. Hendrix said his losses were compounded by looting on Wednesday and Thursday while he was working at an auto dealership. ``I couldn't even afford to take off,'' said Hendrix. Even for the insured, the road was not easy. In Plainfield, an unidentified man wept as he pleaded over the phone with his insurance company. ``You can't call me,'' the man said. ``I have no phone. My home has been destroyed. I'm sorry. I'm upset.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Federal Rule Over Kashmir
DOC.TEXT: Parliament on Monday extended federal rule over Kashmir, and the government said it will investigate allegations that security forces battling Moslem secessionists have raped and molested women. The Rajya Sabha, or upper house of Parliament, endorsed direct federal rule over the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir, replacing an administrative ordinance issued July 18. The lower house had approved the move last week. The local elected government was first suspended in January and replaced by a federally appointed governor in a crackdown on the separatists. Subodh Kant, the junior minister for interior affairs, said three security personnel faced unspecified punishment for ``excesses on women.'' He also said the authorities will investigate more that 30 other cases of alleged rape or molestation. The Indian police, army and paramilitary forces have been accused of human rights violations and indiscriminate killing while hunting Moslem militants. Kant said most of the allegations of atrocities by government forces were fabricated by the militants. On Sunday, two air force technicians were abducted and killed in Srinigar, the state capital. The government clamped a curfew on the city and authorized its forces to shoot curew violaters on sight. Press Trust of India reported three more people died in the state Sunday night and Monday, including a militant commander and a security man who died of injuries in an earlier clash. The body of an unidentified woman also was recovered from a river, PTI said. At least 1,089 people have been killed since January. The latest round of secessionist violence flared on Jan. 20 following a government crackdown on escalating protests, bombings and attacks on state officials. The secessionist campaign has been alternately simmering and flaring for more than 40 years. The militants had earlier campaigned for union with Pakistan, which claims Kashmir because of its predominant Moslem population, but now demand independence and the status of a neutral country.

DOC.HEAD: Army Vehicle Carrying Missiles Explodes in Saudi Desert
DOC.TEXT: An Army vehicle carrying Tow anti-tank missiles and other weapons exploded Monday in eastern Saudi Arabia, the Army said. No injuries were reported. The fire that caused the explosion is under investigation, the Army said in a statement. The vehicle _ a high mobility multipurpose wheeled vehicle _ is the modern version of the Army jeep. It was in a motor pool at an 82nd Airborne Division camp when it caught fire, the statement said. No other details were immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Holiday Dampened In South, Upper Midwest, Southwest
DOC.TEXT: Wet weather dampened Labor Day activities Monday across parts of the South and the upper Midwest, and the desert Southwest was threatened with heavy rain. Afternoon showers and thunderstorms extended over central and southern Florida, southern Louisiana, northwestern Mississippi, northeastern North Carolina, western Tennessee, and northeastern Arkansas. Showers and thunderstorms also spread across parts of western Wisconsin, central Minnesota, southeastern North Dakota, and eastern South Dakota. In the desert Southwest, showers and thunderstorms were scattered from the deserts of southern California into eastern Nevada and Arizona, with a threat of locally heavy rain. Rain also fell across northeastern Idaho. Rainfall amounts during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT were less than one inch. Rain was light but welcome at Kodiak, Alaska. Only 0.01 of an inch of rain had fallen at Kodiak from Aug. 17 until Monday morning, when 0.09 of an inch of rain fell. Cape Hatteras, N.C., warmed to a record-tying 90 degrees. Monday's low for the Lower 48 states was 29 at Truckee, Calif. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 61 at Everett, Wash., to 103 at Needles, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Somalia President Replaces 6-Month-old Government
DOC.TEXT: President Mohamed Siad Barre, whose country is convulsed by rebellions and banditry, on Monday sacked the 6-month-old government of Prime Minister Mohamed Ali Samantar. The president, in power since a 1969 coup, gave no reason for the move in the state radio announcement. He asked Mohamed Hawadle Madar, a former Cabinet minister, to form a new government in this East African nation and said Samantar will stay on as a caretaker until then. Madar, a former vice president of the national assembly, is a member of the northern Isaak clan that makes up the main element of support for the rebel Somali National Movement (SNM). The sacking comes amidst continued fighting against the SNM in the north and intensified battles against the rebel United Somali Congress in central Somalia. The country also is suffering from hyperinflation, which threatens to overcome the economy, widespread banditry and interclan fighting in the interior. Heightening tension in the capital, Mogadishu, has included at least a half-dozen unexplained bomb blasts at foreign missions the last two months. A Western diplomat, asked about the dissolution of the government, said the public was dissatisfied with the performance of the old government _ ``politically, economically and socially.''

DOC.HEAD: Former CIA Agent Tried For Not Reporting Contra Arms Profits
DOC.TEXT: A former CIA agent embroiled in the Iran-Contra affair goes on trial Tuesday in a case expected to shed light on who made how much in the secret arms supply network to Iran and the Contra rebels in Nicaragua. Thomas G. Clines, who retired from the CIA in 1978 after a 29-year career, is accused of under-reporting his earnings from arms sales on his 1985 and 1986 tax returns. He also is charged with failing to tell the Internal Revenue Service about overseas bank accounts. Clines, of Middleburg, Va., pleaded innocent March 9 to all four counts. If convicted of all charges, Clines could be fined up to $1 million and sentenced to 16 years in prison. ``As I've said in open court, we thought the case should never have been brought,'' said Clines' attorney, Paula M. Junghans. ``He intends to defend it vigorously.'' She declined to comment further. Prosecutors contend Clines reaped about $882,000 in commissions for helping buy and sell arms to Iran and the Contra rebels fighting the Marxist Sandinista government in Nicaragua. Some of the money was kept in a foreign account code-named ``C.Tea,'' according to the congressional Iran-Contra report issued in November 1987. Clines was in the arms business with Richard V. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, and Albert Hakim, an Iranian-born businessman, the indictment said. The business allegedly operated in 1985 and 1986. It was directed by former National Security Adviser John M. Poindexter and retired Marine Lt. Col. Oliver L. North, a former National Security Council aide, court papers said. ``North and Poindexter played critical roles in providing the funds that Clines, Hakim and Secord used to pay for the weapons the Contras eventually received,'' according to court documents. ``Those funds also provided the source of the profits that Clines and his partners kept, which are at the heart of this case.'' Prosecutors claim evidence will show that Clines received about $423,000 in 1985 and $459,000 in 1986. Clines reported gross receipts of $265,000 for the tax year 1985 and $402,513 for 1986, the indictment said. Hakim, who managed bank accounts in the Iran-contra affair, is a key witness in the case against Clines. Hakim pleaded guilty Nov. 21, 1989, to a misdemeanor of supplementing North's salary. He was sentenced in February to two years of supervised probation and was fined $5,000. Hakim was a principal shareholder of Lake Resources Inc., a company that pleaded guilty to stealing government property. That was done by diverting the proceeds from arms sales to Iran to the Contras. The government also is expected to put Secord on the stand. Secord pleaded guilty Nov. 8, 1989 to one felony count of making false statements to the Iran-Contra congressional committees. He was sentenced in January to two years of probation. Clines worked for the CIA as an agent in Southeast Asia and was involved in the Bay of Pigs invasion in Cuba. He became director of training in the directorate of operations, also known as the clandestine services. In 1984, Clines pleaded guilty on behalf of a company he owned to overcharging the Defense Department for shipping military equipment to Egypt. He was fined $10,000. In a plea agreement in Richmond, Va., Clines also agreed to pay $100,000 in exchange for assurances that he wouldn't be sued for up to $8 million his company allegedly overcharged the government.

DOC.HEAD: One Escapee Caught, Second Fugitive and Guard Missing
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `About 15 law...', to RESTORE first reference to Simpson.
DOC.TEXT: Stands for AM-Escape-Abduction on AM-News Advisory.

The capture of a jail escapee has provided leads in the search for a second escapee and the woman guard who investigators believe is romantically linked to him, authorities said Monday. James V. Barnes, 35, of Romney, was captured Sunday night in a vacant vacation home, said West Virginia State Police Cpl. E.E. Bolyard. He escaped early Wednesday from a jail in Cumberland, Md., 30 miles to the north. About 15 law enforcement officers surrounded the house and a police dog and its handler who entered through a window found Barnes hiding behind a door, said Maj. Gary Simpson of the Allegany County Sheriff's Department in Maryland. Barnes was treated for a bite from the police dog. Barnes waived his right to fight extradition and was being held in the Hampshire County Jail until he could be taken back to Maryland. Barnes and Edgar Eugene Kerns Jr., 30, escaped from their maximum-security cells at the Allegany County Detention Center in Cumberland. Another prison guard watched them take guard Sandra Kay Beeman with them, grabbing her neck in a choke hold. At first authorities regarded Beeman as a hostage although they wondered how the men, armed just with hard objects in white socks, were able to force Beeman to open two sets of locked doors. Then, on Saturday, the 46-year-old guard telephoned her daughter in Frostburg, Md., to tell her: ``I'm fine. I'm with him.'' A warrant charging Beeman with aiding in the escape, a felony that carries a maximum sentence of 10 years, was issued later that day. The capture of Barnes clears up who Beeman is with, Simpson said. Barnes told authorities Kerns and Beeman were together when the trio separated earlier in the week. Statements by Barnes confirmed police beliefs that Kerns and Beeman are romantically linked, Simpson said. Barnes also provided new leads about where the pair may have headed, Simpson said. Barnes had been sentenced to 50 years in prison in Virginia for rape, kidnapping and robbery. He entered the Cumberland jail Feb. 14 to await trial for rape, kidnapping and assault with a deadly weapon a knife. Kerns, of Martinsburg, W.Va., had been in the Cumberland jail since Jan. 13. He was awaiting sentencing on charges of grand larceny and writing bad checks. He had been charged with assault for allegedly beating his wife, but that case wasn't prosecuted because she declined to testify, authorities said. On the night of the escape, co-workers said, Beeman asked an officer to pick up dinner from a nearby carryout restaurant, leaving Beeman and another guard on duty. Beeman then went upstairs for a routine round, carrying keys to all the cells, a breach of policy. The two men, who had been in maximum security cells, and Beeman walked downstairs and through a series of doors, including one that was supposed to be locked at all times. The men threatened the other officer, who locked herself in a bathroom, co-workers said. The three then left in Beeman's car. ``I've known Kay,'' said Allegany Deputy Craig Allen Robertson, the detective in charge of the case. ``She was a friend of mine. But now she's crossed a border. ... It makes it very hard.''

DOC.HEAD: Mongolian Legislature Convenes, Elects President
DOC.TEXT: Mongolia's first popularly elected legislature met in its initial session Monday and re-elected Punsalmaagiin Ochirbat as president of the Central Asian nation, a source in Ulan Bator said. The session lasted about 10 hours, said the source, who spoke in a telephone interview from the Mongolian capital on condition of anonymity. ``Everyone really felt free to get up and speak their piece, and did so,'' he said. The source said the leader of the communist party, formally called the Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, nominated Ochirbat and the opposition Social Democratic Party seconded the nomination. He said Ochirbat will be sworn in Tuesday. His information was based on radio reports shortly after Monday's session ended. Ochirbat, a former mining engineer, was trade minister when first named president last March during a leadership shuffle forced by months of pro-democracy protests. Jambyn Batmonh, who was president and communist party chief, resigned both posts. Ochirbat initiated a policy in recent years of seeking ties with countries outside the Soviet bloc, to which Mongolia has belonged since a 1921 communist revolution. He came to China in May to normalize relations after many years of coolness caused by the Chinese-Soviet split. The Mongolian Democratic Party initiated Mongolia's pro-democracy movement and was the first opposition party when it was founded this year. It did not support Ochirbat's nomination, but did not nominate its own candidate, the source said. The vote count was not immediately available. Opposition parties hold only 10 percent of the 430 seats in the legislature, called the Great People's Hural, following Mongolia's first multiparty elections on July 29. A communist victory was guaranteed in the elections because the five new opposition parties lacked time to put up candidates for each seat. The source said that despite their small numbers, the presence of the opposition party members changed the atmosphere of the entire legislature. ``It clearly was a departure from previous hurals _ everybody feeling free to speak,'' he said. Mongolia has 2 million residents.

DOC.HEAD: Parades, Raft Race, Bridge Walk Mark Labor Day
LaserPhoto XDV1
DOC.TEXT: Americans marked the last blast of the summer with Labor Day picnics, parades and a river raft race in Oklahoma. A Chicago neighborhood sent red, white and blue messages to U.S. soldiers in the Persian Gulf. Michigan Gov. James Blanchard joined 65,000 people early Monday for the 5-mile walk across Mackinac Bridge, which links the state's two peninsulas. Blanchard made the trek in one hour and 10 minutes, then flew to Detroit for more walking in the Labor Day parade and the Polish Day parade in Hamtramck. A morning parade in Oklahoma City sponsored by the Central Oklahoma Labor Council drew plenty of spectators but only nine floats. The parade's brevity didn't seem to disappoint the children, who gleefully scooped up candy thrown from the floats and cars. A holiday perennial, the Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon, turned 25 this year, shifting from Las Vegas to a revolving Hollywood stage. Lewis kicked off the 21{-hour fund-raiser Sunday night for the Muscular Dystrophy Association with a dedication to the late Sammy Davis Jr. The weekend in Virginia Beach, Va., ended as peacefully as it began, without the looting and rioting that marred last year's gathering of college students. City officials blocked off a section of the oceanfront to traffic and restricted visitors' movements. ``I think I'll be in the Bahamas next year,'' said Tracy Jordan, 21, of New York City. ``It's just too much trouble to get down here and then they kept us from going anywhere.'' In Tulsa, Okla., about 180 rafts _ some nothing more than two tire inner tubes strapped together _ were registered for the 18th raft race. At the boom of a cannon, the crafts left their moorings at Sand Springs on the Arkansas River for the 8.3-mile trek to Tulsa's River West Festival Park. About 1,000 people marched in the 27th annual Wellington-Oakdale Old Glory Marching Society on Chicago's north side. After the four-block parade, about 150 marchers turned in tiny American flags on which they had penned messages for troops in the Persian Gulf. ``Hurry home,'' said one. ``We're thinking of you'' and ``God bless you,'' said others. Someone wrote the current standings of all four baseball divisions on the back of one of the 4-by-6-inch flags. Galesburg, Ill., extended a tradition with its 98th Annual Galesburg Labor Day parade, one of the oldest in the nation. In New York City, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo exhorted labor leaders Monday to go on the offensive against higher Social Security taxes. Leading that kind of a fight would restore the prestige and influence of the labor movement, the governor said at a pre-parade Labor Day breakfast hosted by the New York City Central Labor Council.

DOC.HEAD: Shiite Leader Rules Out Early Release of American Hostages
DOC.TEXT:
An influential Shiite Moslem leader on Monday ruled out any quick release of the six American hostages in Lebanon, but indicated seven Europeans could soon be freed. ``If there is going to be a hostage release, it will be Europeans, not Americans,'' Hussein Musawi said in Baalbek, a town in eastern Lebanon. ``The United States has spearheaded the West's occupation of Saudi Arabia after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and that eliminated the chance of releasing American hostages in Lebanon this year,'' Musawi told reporters. Musawi heads a pro-Syrian wing of Hezbollah, or Party of God, the reputed umbrella for extremist Shiite Moslem factions in Lebanon. He is said to be the mentor of pro-Iranian Shiite factions believed to hold the hostages. There are four Britons, two West Germans and an Italian in addition to the six Americans held in Lebanon. He was commenting on reports published in Beirut newspapers quoting unidentified Lebanese sources close to Iran as saying all 13 Western hostages, including the Americans, would be freed by the end of the year. These reports quoted the sources as saying ``backstage negotiations and preparations are under way to free Anglican Church envoy Terry Waite soon. ``Barring unforeseen hitches, Waite will be the next hostage to be freed. Otherwise it will be John McCarthy.'' Waite, 51, was kidnapped on Jan. 20, 1987, after leaving a West Beirut hotel for a rendezvous with representatives of Islamic Jihad, a group that claims to be holding American hostages Terry Anderson and Thomas Sutherland. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, is the longest-held Western hostage in Lebanon. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Sutherland was dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut when he was abducted June 9, 1985. No group has claimed to be holding Waite and none of the freed hostages this year has mentioned seeing him in captivity. McCarthy, 33, a British reporter for the London-based Worldwide Television News, was kidnapped April 17, 1986, as he drove to Beirut airport to catch a flight to London. No group has claimed to be holding him either. But several Lebanese Shiite leaders recently asserted that Waite was alive and well, which suggests he is being held separately from the other hostages. Five Western hostages have been released the past four months. The first two were Americans Robert Polhill and Frank Reed, freed 10 days apart in April.
Swiss orthopedic specialists of the International Committee of the Red Cross, Emanuel Christen and Elio Erriquez, were released respectively last month after 10 months in captivity.
The latest freed was Irish teacher Brian Keenan, who was released on Aug. 24. Keenan said upon his release that he had seen Anderson and McCarthy in captivity and that both were well.

DOC.HEAD: Virginia Beach's Holiday Weekend Ends Without Repeat of Violence
DOC.TEXT: Young people left the sand and surf at the end of the Labor Day weekend with city officials and merchants pleased there wasn't a repeat of last year's violence. Some of the young visitors complained much of the fun also was missing. ``I think I'll be in the Bahamas next year,'' said Tracy Jordan, 21, of New York City. ``It's just too much trouble to get down here and then they kept us from going anywhere.'' Last year, the informal end-of-summer party that draws thousands of students, many from predominantly black East Coast colleges, was marred by violent confrontations between police and young people. More than 100 stores along the main beachfront avenue were looted. Hundreds were arrested, and damage was estimated at more than $1.4 million. This year, facing accusations that the city didn't want black visitors, officials took an active role in planning the weekend. Turnout was low _ down from an estimated 100,000 last year to about 28,000 this year. The city closed a 200-block section of the oceanfront to traffic. Visitors with hotel reservations could drive in, but others had to walk or take buses. ``I think the restrictions have significantly helped in the planning of the event,'' said City Manager Aubrey V. Watts. But many of the young visitors complained. ``We couldn't go nowhere,'' said 28-year-old Elaine Alexis of New York City. ``Can't have any fun here. They're just too strict.'' Jack Gravely, president of the Virginia chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People,, said the civil rights group supported the city's control of access to the beachfront, but was uncomfortable with the high profile of police. ``It seemed as if the city had a South African frame of mind. It's sending an ominous message that anytime you have a large number of blacks gathering, you are under a state of siege,'' he said. Hundreds of extra officers were on duty when the weekend started. But after peaceful nights Friday and Saturday, state police scaled back operations. The violence last year prompted a call for an economic boycott of this year's party by some blacks, and businesses along the resort strip reported lower than normal sales on what is generally the busiest weekend of the summer. But for the most part, merchants were content. ``My business was off, but I'm happy with what we got. I'm glad this is over and everybody had a good time,'' said Herman Davison at the Showboat Bar.

DOC.HEAD: British Women, Children to be Bused from Kuwait to Baghdad
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 500 British women and children are expected to travel in a bus convoy from Kuwait to Baghdad on Tuesday, the Foreign Office said. Once in the Iraqi capital, they hope to continue overland to neighboring Jordan or to fly to Amman en route home. A Foreign Office spokesman said the estimated 500 people will be housed in hotels after the half-day journey to Baghdad while their exit visas were arranged. ``We are willing to take any route which we can use to get our citizens out. Any option is as easy or as difficult as the Iraqis choose to make it,'' the spokesman said. The British Broadcasting Service was to transmit instructions by radio to those wishing to join the convoy to be at the Sultan Center car park in Salmiyah before dawn Tuesday, carrying one suitcase per person plus hand luggage. ``They should be prepared for a long journey and take water and food accordingly,'' the planned broadcast said. The Foreign Office said it knew of 25 British citizens with exit visas in Baghdad. It said it was also considering chartering Iraqi planes to evacuate Britons from Baghdad. ``We're not talking about a ransom here to get people out. We're talking about paying a commercial fare,'' the spokesman said. The government estimates 2,500 Britons are still in Kuwait and about 500 in Iraq. An Iraqi Airways jet that landed in Paris, London and Washington on Sunday carried 199 Britons, mostly people detained in Kuwait. The Boeing 747 returned to London on Monday to pick up about 105 Iraqis in Britain. Britain also said it has protested to Iraq over the detention of seven British men who were held with three Americans while seeking exit visas for their wives. The Foreign Office said the 10 men, all employees of the Bechtel Corp., were thought to have been taken to ``civilian installations'' around Baghdad after being picked up Saturday. The Washington Post reported from Baghdad that the Americans were lured from haven at the U.S. Embassy when Iraqi immigration authorities asked them to report in connection with their wives' exit visas. The Foreign Office spokesman, briefing reporters on condition of anonymity, said he did not know whether the Britons had been in the British Embassy, their homes or hotels. ``We have protested to the Iraqi authorities both in London and Baghdad about this,'' said the spokesman. The Foreign Office earlier said it was checking reports that Iraq has banned all foreign flights intending to pick up Western women and children. A British airline, Virgin Atlantic, said it had been refused permission to land in Baghdad. A French aircraft was also denied permission. Virgin Atlantic said it would fly a jumbo jet with blankets, food and medicine to Amman on Tuesday, and fly out about 150 Britons, Europeans and Americans who have fled Iraq. It said the remaining seats would go to Egyptian refugees, with the plane stopping first in Cairo. The passengers would be carried free of charge, it said. Virgin Atlantic said it was acting on an appeal by King Hussein of Jordan to its chairman, Richard Branson, for help in coping with the tens of thousands of refugees who have poured into Jordan from Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Three Troopers Hurt, 25 Arrested at Pigeon Shoot
LaserPhoto HX1
DOC.TEXT: Three state troopers were injured and 25 people were arrested during an annual live pigeon shoot Monday after protesters rushed onto a field and tried to free the caged birds. Several fistfights broke out, a skunk was thrown at demonstrators and one protester kicked out the windshield of a car before state police stopped the protest at the 57th Fred Coleman Memorial Shoot in Hegins. Participants pay to shoot birds released from cages, and the proceeds are used to maintain a park in this small east-central Pennsylvania town. Fourteen people with fake blood dripping from their mouths ran onto the field at different times to free the animals. Spectators chanted ``shoot'' as state police tried to handcuff the demonstrators. ``It was just getting out of control,'' said state police spokesman Tom Lyon. He said 40 officers were assigned to the park and a state police helicopter was called in as an ``extra show of force.'' The 14 people who rushed the field were charged with criminal trespass. An additional 11 demonstrators were charged with disorderly conduct. The officers received only minor injuries. About 150 people from Pennsylvania, California, Maryland, Kansas, Illinois, New Jersey, West Virginia, Virginia, Texas and Florida picketed the Labor Day event, billed as the largest live pigeon shoot in the world. Competitors using shotguns stood about 20 yards from the birds, which were released one a time from metal cages. After a group of birds was shot, a group of ``trapper boys'' ran onto the field to retrieve them. The children would wring the birds' necks or pull their heads off if they were fluttering on the ground wounded. Dead birds were put in a barrel to be used in fertilizer, shooters said. An estimated 4,800 birds were killed Monday, organizers said. Tammy Cox, a mother with three children, said she is sick of the yearly display by protesters and told them to ``take care of their own back yards.'' ``Our churches are packed on Sundays,'' said Anne Coleman. ``We have more churches than barrooms. So we're doing something right. Good people come out of this area. We even had a Miss Pennsylvania a few years ago.'' Jack Keating, a 30-year shooter, said the protesters don't realize the event is just ``shooting rats with wings.'' Tim Leese, 12, sported a T-shirt that read, ``Save a Pigeon. Kill a Protester.'' ``They're retarded,'' the seventh grader said. ``They should protest something else. It's not too cruel because the pigeons carry diseases.'' Signs read, ``Small Men, Big Guns,'' ``Stop the Slaughter,'' and ``Killing for Fun is Sick.'' ``It's deplorable that these men get their kicks out of this,'' said Paula Murphy, an elementary school teacher from Ashland.

DOC.HEAD: Third Countdown for Columbia Proceeding Smoothly
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to move up references to grounded shuttle fleet; ADD information about Magellan and Hubble. Pick up 8th graf pvs, `We've had...' ^By MARCIA DUNN
DOC.TEXT: NASA's third countdown for the space shuttle Columbia and its astronomy mission proceeded uninterrupted Monday as the space agency aimed for a Thursday liftoff. ``We want the shuttle Columbia and the science payload to be right when we launch,'' said Vance Brand, commander of the seven-man crew. ``We are enthusiastic about the mission and ready to fly it.'' The latest countdown began early Monday and liftoff is scheduled for 1:20 a.m. EDT Thursday. If the Columbia takes off, it will be the first shuttle launched since hydrogen fuel leaks grounded NASA's three-shuttle fleet in the spring. Columbia originally was scheduled to lift off with the $150 million Astro observatory in March 1986. However, the January 1986 explosion of the Challenger, which killed all seven crew members, postponed all shuttle missions. Columbia's launch was eventually rescheduled for May 30 of this year, but hydrogen fuel leaks halted the countdown. A month later, the Atlantis shuttle also was found to have hydrogen leaks, prompting the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to ground the whole fleet. Atlantis' classified Pentagon mission, originally scheduled for July, is now set for November. Last week, communications problems with Astro's X-ray telescope halted Columbia's second countdown. The launch had been scheduled for Saturday. Four astronomers on board will take turns operating Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes round the clock. But the X-ray telescope has to be managed by computer commands sent from Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Md. The communication problem was corrected over the weekend when workers replaced an electronic component in the 1,500-pound X-ray telescope, anchored along with the ultraviolet telescopes in Columbia's cargo bay. A minor software problem was fixed Sunday. The Columbia would be the first shuttle launched since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. The stretch between missions is the longest since flights resumed in 1988 following the Challenger disaster. A beleaguered NASA has spent the summer also contending with Hubble's defective mirror and communications problems with the Venus-orbiting Magellan spacecraft. At NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory in California, engineers hoped computer commands radioed this week and next would restore the Magellan spacecraft to normal operation. They have not determined why the Magellan suffered two long communications blackouts, but hoped its $744 million mission to map Venus with radar would begin this month. ``We've had some trouble, but responding to trouble, fixing problems, is our strong suit,'' said Columbia test director Mike Leinbach. ``We've been disappointed several times, of course, but Thursday morning we hope that's all behind us.'' ``I'm ready to get this one off the ground'' and move on to Discovery's planned flight in October with the Ulysses spacecraft, Leinbach said. Ulysses is to study the sun. Columbia's nine- to 10-day mission will be one of the longest since the first shuttle flight in 1981. It also will be the first shuttle mission in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. Astro will examine some of the hottest objects in the universe, including a supernova and Comet Levy, which is making its first recorded pass through the solar system. The observatory will remain in the cargo bay and be returned to Earth for possible use on a future mission.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Logging Demonstrators March to Lumber Mill in Last Summer Action
DOC.TEXT: About 600 anti-logging demonstrators marched peacefully Monday to a lumber mill here for the last planned protest of Redwood Summer. The ``Redwoodstock'' marchers were met by 100 counter-demonstrators. Authorities said there were no arrests and no violence as the environmentalists made their way to the Pacific Lumber Co. mill in this town on California's northern coast. The march came on the third day of the last summer action planned by environmentalists who oppose clear-cutting and logging of old growth timber. Logging companies had urged their employees and others who back timber interests to ignore the protest. Humboldt County sheriff's officials said 700 to 800 Redwood Summer participants gathered peacefully over Labor Day weekend. The main campsite for the protesters was on the banks of the Eel River near Fortuna. About 100 law enforcement officers were on hand over the weekend, said sheriff's spokeswoman Leona Mendenhall. Humboldt County tried to block the march by refusing to approve a permit. A federal judge in San Francisco ruled last week that such a prohibition violated the marchers' freedom of speech. The judge allowed the march to go on.

DOC.HEAD: Socialists Reportedly Willing to Accept Minority in New Cabinet
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Socialists are offering to take a minority share of seats in a new Cabinet to induce the opposition into joining a coalition government, an opposition leader said Monday. Petar Dertliev, chairman of the opposition Bulgarian Social Democratic Party, said after meeting with Premier Andrei Lukanov on Monday that the Socialists were willing to accept only 40-45 percent of the positions in a new Cabinet. Dertliev also said Lukanov, a leading Socialist, had offered to freeze his membership in the Socialist Party. ``The meeting created an atmosphere of dialogue between the government and the opposition, and it gave certain guarantees for the civil peace,'' Dertliev said. The Socialists are the renamed Communist Party, now dominated by the reformers who ousted hard-line leader Todor Zhivkov in November. The sole exception to the trend away from Communism in Eastern Europe, they won multiparty elections in June. But the Socialists have seen their popularity plummet since then because of Bulgaria's worsening economy. Many key food and consumer items are rationed, and Bulgaria has placed a moratorium on paying its $10.3 billion foreign debt. The Socialists' newspaper Duma said Sunday that the country is threatened with famine. President Zhelyu Zhelev, a prominent opposition figure, last week asked Lukanov to form a new government. The Socialists want to draw opposition figures into the government because they say comprehensive economic reforms cannot be made without broader public support than they alone can muster, and that no Western aid will be forthcoming if the Socialists govern alone. The opposition has refused to enter a coalition government if it has a minority in parliament. Zhelev last week said ``an outright coalition is out of the question.'' Dertliev on Monday termed the idea ``destructive'' for the Socialists' opponents. But Dertliev said the Agrarian Party, one of the largest opposition parties, was ready to accept the Socialists' invitation to enter a coalition. There was no confirmation from the Agrarian Party. An opposition spokesman also told reporters that Parliament had gone into closed session Friday to discuss a claim of responsibility for a fire that gutted the Socialist Party headquarters on Aug. 26. Michail Nedelchev, a spokesman for the Union of Democratic Forces, a coalition of opposition political parties, told reporters the claim was made by an anonymous caller to Vice President Atanas Semerdzhiev on behalf of a group calling itself the Bulgarian Secret Central Revolutionary Committee. No information about the Committee was available, and its claim to have set the fire could not be verified. The party headquarters in downtown Sofia was torched during an anti-Communist demonstration on Aug. 26. The protesters were demanding the removal of the red star _ the symbol of Communist, one-party rule _ atop the building.

DOC.HEAD: Thai Conservation Fighter Commits Suicide, Official Says
DOC.TEXT: Sueb Nakasathien, known as one of Thailand's most dedicated wildlife conservationists, shot himself to death in a vast wilderness area he fought to protect, an official said Monday. He was 41. Gov. Uthai Manthavorn of Uthai Thani province said the death was believed a suicide. He said it was certain Sueb killed himself with a pistol at his quarters in Huay Khakaeng Wildlife Reserve. The body was found Saturday. The governor said he learned from Sueb's subordinates that Sueb had set very high standards and was probably disillusioned by lack of results. Sueb spent years at Huay Khakaeng and adjacent Thung Yai sanctuary, which contain one of the last great forests of mainland Southeast Asia and an abundance of animal life. He assailed a plan to build a major dam in the area and tried to ward off other attempts at encroachment by loggers and poachers which adversely affected Thailand's wildlife parks and reserves. The plan was shelved in 1988. Funeral arrangements were uncertain.

DOC.HEAD: Pakistani Court Overturns Nepotism Charge against Bhutto Minister
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday overturned charges of nepotism and abuse of power against Ehsanul Haq Piracha, who was deputy finance minister under ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan removed Ms. Bhutto on Aug. 6 on charges of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. Weeks earlier, the Lahore High Court accused Piracha of nepotism when he granted a relative permission to start a stock exchange at Islamabad. The case was a civil matter aimed at stopping establishment of the stock exchange. No criminal charges were filed. But the charge was widely used by opposition politicians to attack Ms Bhutto's government. That and other allegations prompted Ishaq Khan to dismiss her 20-month administration. The nation's highest court disputed the Lahore finding, saying, ``Relationship with a director or promotor or a sponsor of a publically owned company or a trade organization does not disqualify an administrative decision-maker.'' The ruling will make only a minor dent in corruption charges leveled against Ms. Bhutto, her former Cabinet and members of her Pakistan People's Party.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Youth Sentenced for Stoning Arab Cars
DOC.TEXT: A district court sentenced a 16-year-old Jewish youth to 10 months in prison Monday for stoning cars belonging to Palestinians from the occupied territories, the national news agency Itim said. The youth, whose name was not given, also drew a one-year suspended sentence, Itim said. It did not say if the youth caused any damage or injuries. The stonings two weeks ago followed anti-Arab rioting after two Jewish teen-agers were slain in Arab east Jerusalem, believed killed by Palestinians. Stonings and firebomb attacks have characterized the 33-month-old Palestinian revolt against Israeli rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

DOC.HEAD: Lady Home, Wife of Former Prime Minister, Dies at 80
DOC.TEXT: Lady Home, wife of ex-prime minister Lord Home, died Monday after a stroke, her son said. She was 80. Lady Home died in Law Hospital, Carluke, a southern Scottish town near the family's shooting estate at Castlemains, in Larnarkshire, said her son, David Douglas-Home. He said his mother was taken ill at home while his father was out walking on the estate. She was taken to the hospital in a coma from which she never recovered. Lady Home, the former Elizabeth Alington, was the daughter of the Very Rev. Cecil Alington, who was headmaster of Eton when Alec Douglas-Home _ then Lord Dunglass _ attended the prestigious boys' boarding school during World War I. She married Home, seven years her senior, in 1936 after they had met again as adults when she visited Scotland. They had one son and three daughters. Home, the 14th Earl of Home and scion of an ancient Scottish aristocratic family, renounced his titles in 1963 to become prime minister.
