He served in that post until 1964, and then was opposition leader until 1965. Home was later knighted and was given a life title, Lord Home of the Hirsel, in 1974. The Hirsel, in Berwickshire, near the Scottish-English border, is another huge estate owned by the family. Lady Home often traveled with her husband through his long political career as a top leader of the Conservative Party. But she once described how his career often kept them apart, even when together. ``Actually we did find ourselves sitting next to each other at the Guildhall (the Lord Mayor of London's official residence), but I couldn't think of anything to say to him,'' Lady Home said. ``After all you cannot ask him about the children in the middle of an official function.''

DOC.HEAD: Former Army Chief of Staff Moshe Levy Seriously Injured
DOC.TEXT: Former Israeli Army Chief of Staff, Lt. Gen. Moshe Levy, was seriously injured and partly paralyzed Monday in an accident at his home, hospital officials said. Israel radio said Levy slipped and fell on his back at his home on the communal settlement of Beit Alfa in northern Israel. He suffered an injury to his spine and could not move some of his limbs, the radio said. Levy was admitted to the neurosurgery wing of the Tel Hashomer Hospital near Tel Aviv. ``He is not in danger of dying, but he is suffering from some paralysis,'' said Head Nurse Hanna Hava. She would not disclose further details about his condition. She said doctors had not yet decided if Levy needed surgery and that there was a chance his paralysis was temporary. Levy, 54, retired from the army in February 1987 after serving for four years as chief of staff. He assumed command in 1983 during Israel's invasion of Lebanon and was instrumental in withdrawing the bulk of the Israeli troops from that country in 1985.

DOC.HEAD: King Hussein says Jordan Hardest Hit by Persian Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordan's King Hussein told President Francois Mitterrand on Monday that Jordan is suffering the most in the Persian Gulf crisis, sources close to their talks said. Mitterrand pledged emergency aid of $770,000 to Jordan to help ease the crush of refugees from neighboring Iraq. Hussein's trip on the crisis has already taken him to nine countries. He dined in Paris on Monday with U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. No details of those talks were available, but the U.N. chief was believed to have briefed Hussein on his two days of fruitless talks with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz. Perez de Cuellar arrived Sunday in Paris, saying he was ``deeply disappointed'' he failed to budge Iraq on withdrawing its soldiers from Kuwait, which it invaded Aug. 2. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said Monday that France would support tightening the U.N.-imposed economic embargo of Iraq to include cutting off Iraq's land and air links. If the embargo proves ineffective, France's position ``would be to extend it,'' he said on the TV interview show ``L'Heure de Verite.'' Dumas expressed hope that at the U.S.-Soviet summit next Sunday in Helsinki ``the Americans and Soviets agree on a solution that can be a solution of peace . . . or a solution of greatest firmness, that is, reinforcing the embargo, . . . (and) eventually forcible action.'' Dumas said a joint French-U.S. command will be set up in Bahrain, just off Saudi Arabia, to coordinate movements of U.S. and French fleets. Hussein told Mitterrand he was ``deeply preoccupied that Jordan is the country suffering the most from the situation,'' sources said, speaking on condition of anonymity. More than 250,000 refugees have poured across Jordan's border with Iraq since Iraq's invasion. Jordan's resources are severely strained trying to provide shelter and food for them. The aid promised by Mitterrand is in addition to about $4 million granted to Jordan by the European Community. Hussein, a long-time friend and strong ally of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, has been criticized for his reluctance to join international sanctions on Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Jumbo Jet Leaves London Carrying 195 Iraqis
DOC.TEXT: An Iraqi Airways jumbo jet bearing a group of Iraqis who were stranded in Britain by the Persian Gulf crisis took off from London's Heathrow airport Monday night bound for Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. A senior official with the airline, speaking on condition of not being further identified, said the plane left with 195 passengers. The jet arrived from Washington after carrying Westerners from Baghdad to the United States, Britain and France over the weekend. They were among thousands of Westerners detained by Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and imposition of U.N. sanctions on the government of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. Many Iraqis were left in Britain without transportation home. ``This is a very terrible situation and we hope it can be settled peacefully,'' said Ahmed Ali, an Iraqi flying out with his wife and four children. ``We do not want war but I must say I support Saddam Hussein. He is only doing what he believes is correct for his Arab brothers. However, I do believe it is wrong to use women and children to prevent an attack against Iraq. But this proves he thinks the Americans and British will attack our country.'' An Iraqi who refused to give his name said he was returning to get his family and leave Iraq. ``President Saddam is crazy,'' he said. ``He wants war to prove he is the leader of all the Arabs. But he is wrong. He will die if there is war _ and so will my country. There is no future in Iraq.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Suspends Repaying Foreign Debt
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq on Monday suspended repayment of its foreign debt in response to the United Nations trade embargo, the official Iraqi News Agency reported. Iraq's outstanding debt has been estimated at $30 billion to $35 billion, most of it owed to the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union, West Germany and Japan for purchases of weapons, technology and food. In another development, Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz urged countries that have large number of expatriates in Iraq to ``take urgent measures'' to send them food supplies, according to INA, monitored in Cyprus. ``Suffering as it is from the effects of the international siege, Iraq will not be responsible for their suffering resulting from the shortages in food supplies,'' Aziz was quoted as telling Cornelio Sommaruga, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, on Monday. INA quoted Mohammed Mahdi Saleh, the acting minister of commerce and finance, as saying the debt suspension would have extremely adverse effects on countries and companies ``incapable of withstanding the current situation.'' He was referring to the economic difficulties faced by poorer countries who count on trade with Iraq for generating critical foreign exchange. Some countries, like Sri Lanka and Jordan, have asked the United Nations to clarify what items are covered by the embargo. Jordan relies heavily on income from Iraqi shipments through the port of Aqaba. It has asked for international financial help to make up for the loss caused by the embargo. Saleh was quoted as saying, ``Compensation is not going to be a solution for the economic crisis because it is temporary, limited and ineffectual for dealing with the losses suffered by these countries . . . dragged into the aggressive schemes of the U.S. administration.'' The U.N. Security Council imposed the trade embargo Aug. 6 to force Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to withdraw from Kuwait, which he invaded Aug. 2 and subsequently annexed. INA said Iraq had paid $5.5 billion on its debt in the first half of this year. Saleh, a U.S.-educated economist, said the impact of the crisis on the world economy was indicated by U.S. moves to obtain help in paying for its Persian Gulf deployment. President Bush last Thursday appealed to prosperous countries in Western Europe and Asia to subsidize the cost of U.N. economic sanctions enforced by a great fleet of warships in the gulf region. In his comments to the Red Cross, Aziz said he hoped the organization would assist the countries involved in taking needed measures to supply foreign nationals in Iraq with food, INA said. Iraq has said previously that should food shortages occur because of the U.N. sanctions, foreign hostages would suffer the same as the Iraqi population. The invasion of Kuwait caught about 3 million foreigners in Iraq and Kuwait, including about 3,000 Americans and 18,000 other Westerners.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Fighter Jet Crashes In Saudi Arabia
DOC.TEXT: An Air Force F-16 fighter crashed in southern Saudi Arabia on Monday, but the pilot, who was alone aboard the aircraft, bailed out safely, a Pentagon official said. The crash happened around 7:51 a.m. EDT during a ``routine training mission,'' said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The plane was assigned to the 363rd Tactical Fighter Wing at Shaw Air Force Base in South Carolina and was deployed as part of Operation Desert Shield. The pilot, who was not identified, was taken to a local hospital and later released, the official said. No cause of the accident was given, and a military investigation was to be conducted, the official said.

DOC.HEAD: New Zealand Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Moore, Palmer quotes, background on economic problems, minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Geoffrey Palmer resigned Tuesday as opinion polls indicated his ruling Labour Party would be routed in next month's national elections. External Relations and Trade Minister Mike Moore, who Palmer defeated in a party vote when former Premier David Lange resigned 13 months ago, was named to succeed Palmer in the Oct. 27 balloting. The opposition National Party is leading by a large margin over the Labour Party in the latest polls. Moore, 41, who in recent months had repeatedly denied he would seek to unseat Palmer, had been ranked third in power behind Palmer and Deputy Prime Minister Helen Clark. Moore told a news conference that New Zealanders wanted a ``new direction'' and that his bid for the leadership ``in no way is a reflection on Mr. Palmer's service to New Zealand.'' New Zealand, with 3.5 million residents, has been hit in recent months by a weakness in its general economy and a rise in unemployment. Palmer, 48, had denied he would step down as recently as Monday. New Zealand Press Association quoted sources as saying he had enough support to stay in office but decided to quit because the internal power struggle would have devastated the party. Palmer told a news conference he ``may well have had the numbers to remain, but I took the view that to have a leadership contest on a vote would be destructive, it would be divisive, that it was not in the best interests of the collective.'' Palmer said, ``I've done the best that I can do and I certainly hope that we will improve our fortunes (for victory) in the next eight weeks.'' Palmer appears ready to leave politics altogether. He said he would not seek re-election to Parliament, although he agreed to stay on as environment minister, a non-Cabinet position, through the election. Labour parliamentarians, who met briefly Tuesday, were to meet again Thursday. The move comes as Labour members have voiced concern they could not hold onto power with Palmer as leader. Some have run campaign ads without the Labour logo. A Radio New Zealand poll in late July showed the conservative Nationals leading by a 46 percent to 21 percent margin over Labour. Polls also have shown Moore to be leading all candidates for prime minister. Moore was the clear choice too in a survey of business chief executives. Some political commentators say Labour may even be hard pressed to hold onto 20 seats in the 97-seat Parliament, a result that could oust several Cabinet ministers, including Ms. Clark. Labour holds 56 seats, the Nationals 40 and the breakaway left-wing New Labour Party one. The 5-month-old Green Party has been running third in opinion polls. However, a large section of voters remain undecided, including many traditional Labour supporters. Opinion polls in some electorates have put the undecided vote at 38-47 percent. Labour took power in 1984, ousting the Nationals. It won re-election in 1987 despite losing some support because of its deregulation policies. Palmer defeated Moore for the prime minister's job at a government caucus after Lange resigned in August 1989 due to health reasons. Both Palmer and Moore represent districts in Christchurch, the largest city on New Zealand's South Island. Palmer is a former attorney who taught law at the University of Iowa and University of Virginia. Moore became the youngest person ever elected to Parliament when he won his first seat in 1972 at age 23. He was ousted in 1975 in Labour's landslide loss, but returned three years later.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister, 90 North Koreans Cross Armed Southern Border
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with border crossing, quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: North Korean Prime Minister Yon Hyong Muk and 90 of his countrymen crossed the heavily armed Korean border into South Korea on Tuesday for a historic visit aimed at easing four decades of hostilities. Yon and the six official North Korean delegates to the premiers' talks were welcomed by their South Korean counterparts at the truce village of Panmunjom inside the Demilitarized Zone separating the rival Koreas. ``A Korean proverb says a thousand miles start with a first step,'' said South Korean Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul, who was among those to greet the visitors. The North Koreans were given bouquets of flowers, a traditional Korean gift of friendship, and tea, before being escorted to South Korean-made sedans for a 35-mile trip south to Seoul. A military helicopter hovered overhead as the motorcade of 12 cars and three buses prepared to move south toward Seoul. The group is the first to cross the border since 1985 and only the third delegation to travel to the South since the end of World War II in 1945. South Korean Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon was to meet the North Koreans at a luxury hotel near Olympic Park, official headquarters for the talks. The premiers' meeting is seen as a new phase in capitalist South Korea's efforts to coax the totalitarian Communist North out from four decades of isolation and begin a thaw in their Cold War. South Korean officials say the meeting will be the first in which both sides recognize the legitimacy of each other's governments. North Korea has steadfastly refused to recognize the Seoul government since the Koreas established separate capitals in 1948. During the visit, the North Korean prime minister is expected to make a courtesy call of South Korean President Roh Tae-woo, possibly delivering a letter from North Korean leader Kim Il Sung. If all goes well, a second round of talks is to be held Oct. 16-19 in North Korea's capital of Pyongyang. ``The Korean peninsula still remains in the grip of the Cold War era that has placed South and North Korea in a state of mutual distrust and confrontation,'' said Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul, spokesman for the South Korean delegation. ``This continued national tragedy should not be permitted to go on endlessly,'' he said. ``Every effort must be made to establish regular dialogue between the two sides.'' The Korean peninsula was divided at the end of World War II into the Communist North and capitalist South. The two sides fought the 1950-53 Korean War but a peace treaty was never signed. The border between the Koreas remains the most heavily fortified permanent demarcation in the world, with more than 1.5 million armed men on either side behind bunkers and barbed wire. There is no travel, mail or other communication between civilians of the two sides. Stock prices in Seoul jumped Monday by four percent in anticipation of the visit. Businessmen believe the visit could lay the groundwork to joint ventures combining the North's resources and cheap labor with South Korean capital and technology. Formal talks were scheduled Wednesday and Thursday and the delegation is to return north on Friday. The schedule also includes informal talks and sightseeing, lavish dinners, a stage show and a trip to the National Museum, which houses relics of shared Korean history.

DOC.HEAD: Jerry Lewis Raises Money for MDA
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 8-11, `While donors...' with 6 grafs to UPDATE with details of protest; ADDS byline. Pick up final graf pvs, `This year's...
DOC.TEXT: A tearful Jerry Lewis remembered the late Sammy Davis Jr. Monday during Lewis' 25th telethon to raise money to fight muscular dystrophy. The event raised a record $44,172,186 in pledged donations, organizers said. Weeping, the comedian narrated a tribute to Davis, who appeared at the Muscular Dystrophy Association telethon for 13 years, including last year while suffering from the cancer that killed him. On Sunday, Lewis dedicated the telethon to his friend. ``There is only one reason why he isn't here with us this year, and that is the only thing that could have kept him away,'' Lewis said Monday. ``When you knew him, you knew that God made something special.'' The Labor Day telethon changed settings this year, moving to Hollywood after 17 years in Las Vegas. Producers said they wanted to cut costs and update the telethon's image. The Las Vegas shows raised millions in pledges, with last year's tally a record $42.2 million to fight 40 neuromuscular diseases that kill and cripple thousands of people annually, most of them young people. In 17 years in Las Vegas, Lewis has raised more than half a billion dollars. While donors phoned in pledges to the studio on Sunset Boulevard, about 40 protesters marched outside, demanding more accountability for the money. ``We want them to open up and really show us what they have achieved,'' said Sue Marston, secretary of a group called the Alliance for Research Accountability. ``Every year they say they have a new break,'' she said. ``They always say the cure is right around the corner. They always say they're breathtakingly close.'' Gary Cifra, president of the activist group said, ``There's no treatment and there's no cure. Something's wrong.'' Telephone calls made about 30 minutes after the telethon was over to the Los Angeles and New York offices of the Muscular Dystrophy Association Inc. were unanswered. Calls made backstage to seek comment about the protesters' complaints also were unanswered. John Neunzer, 25, sat in a wheelchair with a sign saying: ``Once Jerry's kid, now a forgotten adult.'' He said he was a poster child for the 1975 Labor Day telethon. This year's syndicated telethon, broadcast from the Star Search Theater, where Ed McMahon presents his glitzy talent show, was seen on 200 stations nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Gang's Shooting Spree Kills One, Injures Others
DOC.TEXT: Gang members thwarted in an attempt to attack rivals rampaged through the city, killing one person and wounding up to nine others, police said Monday. The victims apparently were chosen at random during a four-hour spree of shootings and robberies Sunday night throughout this central California city of 350,000 people, said Sgt. Mike Guthrie. ``There doesn't seem to be any identifiable pattern,'' Guthrie said. ``I think it was more driving until they saw an opportunity and taking it.'' Police arrested four boys, ages 14, 15, 16 and 17, and confiscated five guns early Monday. All of those arrested are from Fresno, Guthrie said. Each was charged with one count of murder, six counts of attempted murder and seven counts of armed robbery. Their names were withheld because of their ages. One suspect remained at large and additional charges were pending against the four held, police said. Besides the three shotguns, one rifle and a handgun, police seized crack cocaine from one of the youths, Guthrie said. The rampage began after uniformed officers patrolled a drug-infested west Fresno neighborhood called ``the U,'' said Guthrie. Five gang members intended to shoot rivals, but left the area because of the police, Guthrie said. After the fatal shooting downtown, one juvenile left the group, Guthrie said. The other four robbed and shot people along an eight-mile stretch north to near Fresno State University, then headed back downtown, he said. ``This entire scenario was an afterthought,'' Guthrie said. The shooting spree was ``unprecedented in our city,'' he said. ``I can recall nothing of this magnitude ... There very easily could have been half a dozen or more murder victims.'' Police blamed the juveniles for the killing of a 47-year-old man and shootings that left six other men wounded. Two remained hospitalized Monday in serious condition, said Sgt. Dwight Williamson. The others weren't seriously wounded, he said. The victims' names were withheld released. Three other people were injured in shootings Sunday night and investigators were trying to determine whether the same youths were to blame.

DOC.HEAD: Returning Students Warned that Killer Still At Large
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 8th graf pvs, `Edward Lewis...,' to UPDATE with comments from suspect's attorney, police saying he isn't prime suspect; INSERTS 1 graf after 15th graf pvs, `Police guarded...,' to ADD that killer left non-written `messages' at crime scenes. Pick up 14th graf pvs, `The bodies...
DOC.TEXT: Campus life was returning to normal Monday for many college students frightened by a string of mutilation murders, but police warned that the killer could still be on the loose. Students returning to the University of Florida for the second week of classes said they were less worried than they were last week by the deaths of five students who were found slain in their apartments. ``All you can do is be very careful. I'm usually in my room before dark,'' said Ava, a sophomore from Fort Lauderdale who refused to give her last name. ``Everyone I know is calming down,'' said Aaron Sotala, 20, a sophomore from Copper Harbor, Mich. ``It has been almost week, but there is still tension on the campus.'' Police said they have eight suspects, but warned residents against dropping their guard. ``Students should know that the killer has not been apprehended _ the killer is not in custody _ and assume that person or persons is still in the area,'' Lt. Sadie Darnell, a police spokeswoman, said Monday. Police said an emotionally troubled University of Florida freshman, in custody in Brevard County for allegedly assaulting his grandmother, remained a suspect. Edward Lewis Humphrey was held on $1 million bond. Public Defender J.R. Russo said he would seek a hearing Tuesday to request reduced the bond. ``Are we just holding a citizen just because he fits a certain mental pychological profile or do they have specific evidence which justifies a million dollar bond?'' Russo said Monday. Lt. Spencer Mann, an Alachua County Sheriff's Office spokesman, said: ``There is a presumption that Humphrey is simply `the' suspect in this case. He is one of a possible number of suspects. It is premature to say he is the prime suspect in the case.'' The Gainesville Sun reported Monday that Humphrey's psychiatric records were subpoenaed by the task force investigating the killings. Prosecutors and Humphrey's public defender said they likely would seek a psychological evaluation of Humphrey this week. Humphrey's psychiatrist, Phillip K. Springer, said he opposed being legally compelled to turn over the records and didn't believe Humphrey's mental condition should be a basis for suspicion in the murders. Humphrey has been treated with lithium, a mood-stabilizing drug. Brevard Circuit Judge John Antoon signed an order Sunday allowing investigators to take Humphrey's footprints to compare with those found at one of the crime scenes. Police guarded his apartment over the holiday weekend while other officers continued searching a creek behind the apartment complex. Police have said the killer or killers spent a lot of time at the crime scenes, leaving deliberate clues and relishing the confrontation with police. Police have refused to characterize the messages other than to say they were not in the form of notes or other writings. The bodies of University of Florida freshmen Sonja Larson, 18, and Christina Powell, 17, were found Aug. 26. The body of Sante Fe Community College student Christa Hoyt, 18, was found the next day, while the bodies of Tracey Paules, 23, and Manuel Taboada, 23, were found Aug. 28. Miss Paules went to the University of Florida, while Taboada was a student at Santa Fe. All five died of multiple stab wounds. The bodies of the first three victims were mutilated, police said. Humphrey lived briefly this summer at an apartment complex where Taboada and Miss Paules were killed and at Tolbert Hall, a coed dormitory where Miss Powell lived during summer school.

DOC.HEAD: Historian Marcus Cunliffe Dies
DOC.TEXT: Marcus Falkner Cunliffe, a historian and commentator on American life, died after an extended illness. He was 68. He died Sunday at George Washington University Hospital, a hospital statement said. He may have been best known for his 1958 biography of America's founding father, ``George Washington: Man and Monument.'' Cunliffe also authored or edited more than 15 books on American history and literature. For the last decade he was a professor at George Washington University. Cunliffe, a native of Great Britain, received his master's degree from the University of Manchester and his bachelor's from Oxford University. During a 40-year career in education, he was a visiting professor at Harvard University, Mount Holyoke College, Gettysburg College, Washington State University, University of Michigan and the City University of New York. He is survived by his wife Phyllis Palmer, son Jason, two daughters Shay and Antonia, and four grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Asks `Urgent' Food for Hostages, Suspends Debt Repayment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Iraqis leave London for Baghdad, Bush returns, Saudi promise on oil, Iraqi bid foiled to shed Kuwait at conference. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos DHA1,2,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Baghdad balked on Monday at allowing more airlifts of hostages, told nations with citizens trapped in Iraq to urgently send them food, and suspended payment of its foreign debt in response to the U.N. trade embargo. Western governments expressed fear that Saddam Hussein's government did not intend to fulfill its promise to free remaining women and children held captive since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Diplomatic efforts to resolve the crisis also seemed mired. U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar met Monday with Jordan's King Hussein in Paris after returning empty-handed from talks with Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz. President Bush returned to Washington from his vacation home in Maine to prepare for his Sunday summit in Helsinki, Finland, with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They will discuss, among other things, the gulf crisis. Foreign ministers of the European Community nations planned to meet in Rome before the summit. Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman Giovanni Castellaneta told reporters Monday the 12-member EC would consider Bush's request for financial support for the U.S.-led deployment of forces to the gulf region. Iraq was having its own money troubles. The official Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Cyprus, reported Iraq had suspended repaying a foreign debt estimated at $30 billion to $35 billion. Most of it is owed to the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union, West Germany and Japan for purchases of weapons, technology and food. The U.N. Security Council imposed a trade embargo on Aug. 6 to force Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait. INA also quoted Aziz as telling Cornelio Sommaruga, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, on Monday that ``suffering as it is from the effects of the international siege, Iraq will not be responsible for . . . (foreigners') suffering resulting from the shortages in food supplies.'' Aziz urged countries with large number of expatriates caught in Iraq to ``take urgent measures'' to send them food supplies, according to the agency. About 3,000 Americans were among 21,000 Western hostages believed in Iraq and Iraqi-occupied Kuwait. Saddam says hostages were being used as human shields to protect Iraqi targets. An Iraqi Airways jumbo jet carrying some Iraqis stranded in Britain by the crisis left London late Monday for Baghdad, the Iraqi capital. An airline official said 195 passengers were aboard. Secretary of State James A. Baker III is expected Friday in Saudi Arabia for talks with Kuwaiti government-in-exile officials, which likely will center on the cost to America of the military operation. King Fahd promised a U.S. congressional group Sunday that Saudi Arabia will do its utmost to help the world avert any oil crisis due to the confrontation, according to statements distributed Monday by the official Saudi Press Agency. Fahd expressed hope other oil-producing states will do the same. Saudi Arabia is the world's largest oil exporter. A perceived threat to the kingdom following Kuwait's takeover helped spur U.S military moves. Including Kuwait, Iraq now holds 20 percent of the world's oil reserves. The U.N. embargo on Iraq and Kuwait led to a world shortfall of 4 million barrels of oil a day. Diplomats at 30 embassies in Kuwait continued to defy Iraqi orders to close their doors and get out. One reason they stood fast was that leaving could be seen as implying recognition of Iraq's annexation of Kuwait. The 10-day-old standoff was taking its toll. East Germany says Iraqi authorities grabbed its envoy and took him to Baghdad when he ventured out of his embassy. Troops ring the missions and power, water and telephone service are cut off. The envoys and citizens under their protection were running out of food and water in 120-degree temperatures. The punishing Mideast climate also increased the misery of thousands of refugees, mostly Arabs and Asians, who flooded into Jordan. At Shaalan, 24 miles east of the Jordanian border post at Ruweishid, a slum city of desperate Asian refugees has sprung up. Jordanian authorities will not process their entry until the refugees' governments guarantee rapid repatriation. ``It's like a piece of sandpaper from horizon to horizon, with scorpions and snakes,'' said Jim Nuttal, coordinator for Save the Children who has been working with the refugees. ``They desperately need tents, transportation, food, water and medical care.'' During the weekend, hundreds of foreigners made their way out aboard three separate flights from Baghdad. Britain and France had sought permission to send in planes to pick up more Westerners, but they said on Monday the airlifts were apparently on hold. In London, the Foreign Office said about 500 British women and children on Tuesday will travel in a bus convoy from Kuwait to Baghdad. They hope to continue overland to Jordan or fly to Amman, bound for home. Saddam promised last week that all foreign women and children captives could leave, but Saturday's flights were the only large-scale departures. The French Foreign Ministry indicated Monday that Iraq set unacceptable conditions for landing rights for a French plane to repatriate 200 women and children. Britain's Virgin Airways said it received permission to fly into Baghdad, but permission was revoked in a telex on Sunday. Calls went out Monday to keep up the pressure on Baghdad by strictly enforcing the U.N. economic sanctions. British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd was in Yemen, considered somewhat of a weak link in the enforcement chain. ``If we can make sanctions fully effective ... the chances of a peaceful solution are good, are reasonable,'' he said. Japan's Kyodo News Service said Iraq was asking Tokyo to bend the sanctions _ in exchange for freeing Japanese hostages. The report quoted Iraq's cultural and information minister, Latif Nasif, as saying Iraq would release Japanese if Japan resumed buying Iraqi oil and allowed Iraq to buy food and medicine. Jesse Jackson, who escorted 47 freed American hostages out of Iraq on Sunday, cautioned Monday against relying solely on military pressure to deal with Iraq. ``Just as our generals are in Saudi Arabia with a military presence, our politicians should be as evident in seeking diplomatic solutions,'' the civil rights leader said in an interview on NBC-TV's ``Today'' show. In other developments: _An Army vehicle carrying Tow anti-tank missiles and other weapons exploded Monday in eastern Saudi Arabia, the Army said. No injuries were reported. A U.S.-led multinational force is in Saudi Arabia to discourage any move by Iraq to seize more territory. _The Labor Day holiday in the United States and the unsuccessful U.N.-Aziz talks kept trading light Monday. Stock prices fell sharply on thin trading in Tokyo and London prices rose slightly. _The Turkish government said Monday it will seek power to send troops abroad and permit foreign troops to be stationed in Turkey. _Iraq failed in a bid to unseat Kuwait's delegation at a 140-nation conference in Geneva reviewing an international treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons, diplomats said Monday. Iraq said Kuwait had ceased to exist and had no right to representation.

DOC.HEAD: Rival Christian Forces Skirmish in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces battled with machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades for two hours before dawn Monday, police said. Warring Shiite Moslem factions meanwhile pledged to observe a cease-fire brokered by Syria and Iran to halt an inconclusive power struggle. Police said troops loyal to rebel Gen. Michel Aoun clashed with Lebanese Forces militiamen led by rival Christian leader Samir Geagea in east Beirut and the adjoining 310-square-mile Christian enclave. They said no casualties resulted. Aoun and Geagea have waged an inconclusive battle for control of the Christian enclave since Jan. 30. Military sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said over the weekend that Syrian troops and Lebanese soldiers loyal to President Elias Hrawi were being deployed around the gateways into the Christian enclave. They said the buildup indicates an attack may be imminent to drive Aoun from the presidential palace in Baabda, five miles east of the capital. On Monday, Aoun warned opposing troops in a radio address they would pay a heavy price if they attacked. Military sources in predominantly Moslem west Beirut, where Hrawi's government is based, said about 6,000 Lebanese troops and 20,000 Syrians, backed by 300 tanks, have been positioned around the main approaches to Metn province, where Aoun has been holding out with 19,000 troops. The buildup followed a summit in Damascus Wednesday between Hrawi and Syrian President Hafez Assad, who pledged to help Lebanon's government extend its authority over the whole of Lebanon. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi, who was elected Nov. 24 to implement an Arab League-brokered plan to end Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war. Aoun wants a guarantee for withdrawal of 40,000 Syrian troops deployed in Lebanon under a 1976 Arab league peacekeeping mandate. The peace plan gives the Moslems, who make up 55 percent of Lebanon's 4 million people, an equal share of power with the traditionally dominant Christians. Hrawi has fired Aoun as interim prime minister and army commander, but the general refuses to step down. The cease-fire between rival Shiite forces was called at 8 p.m. Sunday after meetings between representatives of the Iranian-backed fundamentalist Hezbollah and the more secular, pro-Syrian Amal militia. three years. The two factions have been fighting for dominance among the 1.2 million Shiites who make up Lebanon's largest single sect.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Injures Five in Manila
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Monday at a suburban shopping center, wounding five people, police said. It was the 18th bombing attack in the capital since Aug. 13. No immediate claim of responsibility was made in the bombing. The government has blamed the bombings on military rebels seeking to oust President Corazon Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Chedli Klibi Resigns as Secretary-General of Arab League
DOC.TEXT: Arab League Secretary-General Chedli Klibi resigned Monday, apparently in anticipation of next week's relocation of the League's headquarters to Cairo, officials said. Klibi, 66, a Tunisian, has been the Arab League's secretary general since 1979, when the organization's headquarters were moved from Cairo to Tunis. He was reappointed to a five-year term in March 1989. The decision to move the headquarters back to the Egyptian capital has provoked protests from Iraq. Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz criticized the move because of what he called Egypt's ``partial attitude'' against Iraq. Klibi apparently did not want to take responsibility for divisions within the League concerning the location of its headquarters, observers said. The Arab League Secretariat is expected to release a communique explaining Klibi's resignation, Arab League officials said. A meeting of Arab League ministers has been called for Sept. 10 in Cairo, where the transfer of the League's headquarters back to Cairo will be officially announced.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Strike Hits Shortage-Plagued Industrial City
DOC.TEXT: The city of Chelyabinsk, which was wracked by shortages of food, tobacco and alcohol suffered more woes Monday when bus drivers went on strike, the Tass news agency reported. The drivers, whose demands include higher wages, longer vacations, retirement at age 55 and better housing, agreed to return to work later in the day, Tass said. It did not elaborate on their demands. The buses in the southern Ural Mountains city of about 1 million people are old, with no spare parts, and the regional transit authority loses about $35 million a year, the official news agency said. On Aug. 22-24, disturbances broke out in Chelyabinsk, about 900 miles east of Moscow, following a protest by hundreds of demonstrators demanding better supplies of food and consumer goods, according to Soviet media. The Worker's Tribune newspaper reported Sunday that 64 people were injured, including 11 policemen, and five people were arrested. The protests began when a supermarket refused to sell alcohol to shoppers waiting in line and expanded to include food and tobacco. Cigarettes have been in short supply all summer.

DOC.HEAD: Two Nevada Candidates Injured on Eve of Primary
DOC.TEXT: A light plane crash Monday seriously injured two candidates in Nevada's primary election, authorities said. One person was killed in the election-eve accident. The injured included Sue Wagner, a candidate for lieutenant governor, and Bob Seale, who is running for state treasurer. Seale, a licensed pilot, was flying the plane, said Churchill County Sheriff Bill Lawry. The Republicans were among five people aboard a twin-engine Cessna 411 that crashed shortly after takeoff from the Fallon, Nev., municipal airport, about 60 miles east of Reno, the sheriff said. The plane was carrying the candidates to Carson City from Fallon, where they attended a Labor Day parade. It appeared the plane's right engine lost power and the pilot was trying to make it back to the airport when the crash occurred shortly after 12:30 p.m. in a grassy area about a mile from the airport. The plane was badly damaged and witnesses said one of its wings was sheared off. Officials who spoke on condition of anonymity said Seale's wife, Judy, was killed in the crash. Lawry confirmed one death, but withheld the victim's name pending notification of family members. Two other passengers, Stephanie Tyler, a campaign aide to Mrs. Wagner, and Brian Krolicki, Seale's campaign manager, suffered less severe injuries and were taken to a Fallon hospital, the sheriff said. Mrs. Wagner and Seale were taken to Washoe Medical Center in Reno. A hospital spokeswoman said the two were listed in serious condition but the exact nature of their injuries wasn't immediately known. Mrs. Wagner, 50, is a longtime state senator, and Seale, 48, is a certified public accountant. Both are on Tuesday's primary election ballot. Mrs. Wagner's late husband, Peter B. Wagner, was killed in a 1980 plane crash in northern California. Lawry said Krolicki managed to walk out about two miles to a nearby ranch house to notify authorities of the crash about 1:15 p.m.

DOC.HEAD: Longtime CBS Radio Newscaster Paul Lockwood Dies
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT that he collapsed Aug. 23 sted Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: Newscaster Paul Lockwood, who spent 15 years on the CBS radio network, has died at the age of 51. Witnesses said Lockwood, who had worked for the past year as news director at WBAZ-FM at Southold on Long Island, collapsed Aug. 23 after getting out of his car to do a remote broadcast from the Polishtown Fair in Riverhead on Aug 23. He never regained consciousness and died Saturday at Central Suffolk Hospital. He had a history of heart disease. Highlights in his career included coverage of Ronald Reagan on the campaign trail and of Hurricane Alicia, which hit Texas in 1983. Lockwood broke into the New York City broadcast market in 1964 on the former WPIX-FM, followed by jobs at WNEW-AM, WHN and WINS. Lockwood is survived by his mother, his wife, a daughter and two grandchildren. Services were set for Wednesday in Rockville Centre.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Some Snapple Bottles Contain Glass, Oily Residue
DOC.TEXT: Bits of glass and an oily substance were found in bottles of Snapple orange-flavored ice tea sold in a convenience store here, police said Monday. A woman purchased two tainted bottles Sunday at a Quik Chek, and several bottles in the same lot were found to be contaminated, police said. Telephone calls Monday night to Snapple's headquarters in Ridgewood, N.Y., went unanswered. Police advised consumers to check Snapple drinks from lot number CT5042221N2. The matter was referred to the Parsippany health department. City officials could not be reached for comment Monday. A clerk at the Quik Chek referred all questions to the manager, who was not at the store.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Block Traffic to Gambling Town
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 2 and 7 to CORRECT number of arrests to 23 sted 25.
DOC.TEXT: Protesters demanding more parks blocked traffic into this gambling center, delaying thousands of Labor Day travelers on the casinos' busiest day of the year. Police arrested 23 black activists out of the approximately 250 who demonstrated on behalf of what they called ``the forgotten youth of Atlantic City.'' Leaders of the group said they would extend their protests through the week and disrupt the Miss America Pageant, which has its finals televised live Saturday night. They called for more recreational sites and an end to alleged police brutality. Negotiations broke off last week between the group and Mayor Jim Whelan, a former teacher who says he wants to work with them but refuses to be pressured by demonstrations. Police on motorcycles, in cars and a helicopter watched as the demonstrators marched through the slums that abut the glittering Boardwalk strip of casinos and hotels, Shortly before 1 p.m., the marchers blocked traffic coming into town on the Atlantic City Expressway, forcing officers to temporarily divert traffic to side streets. Eight of the marchers, including the Rev. Al Sharpton, who has been active in black community protests in New York and elsewhere, sat down. Twenty-three people, including Sharpton, were arrested, said mayoral aide Lou Tuscano. Most of the arrests were for being disorderly; one was for aggraved assault for throwing things at officers. Sharpton and local group organizer Steve Young also were charged with incitement to riot for allegedly telling others to cross police barricades.

DOC.HEAD: Army Halts Advance on Last Mohawk Stronghold
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with 30 women, children in detox center, Mohawks seeking protection from police, block New York-Canada bridge, police enter building on reserve, death reported, minor editing. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MTL2
DOC.TEXT: Army commanders on Monday ordered troops to halt their advance on the last stronghold occupied by armed Mohawks as they tried to persuade the Indians to surrender. Earlier Monday, a shot was fired as soldiers moved through a wooded area toward the Mohawk positions. Both Mohawk and army representatives denied shooting. The incident took place as a nearly 2-month-old standoff wore on, with troops surrounding about two dozen members of the militant Mohawk Warrior's Society and 30 women and children holed up in a drug and alcohol detoxification center on Indian land in the Kahnesatake settlement. Mohawk warriors with rifles and automatic weapons manned foxholes around the center, which was encircled by a tight cordon of troops, armored vehicles and barbed wire. Lt. Gen. Kent Foster, commander for the Montreal region, told a news conference Monday, ``The army's next move is to stay in place and keep the perimeter closed (around the detoxification center). There will be no more military movement. We will stay here until this is over.'' Foster said the army has a phone line open to the Mohawks in the detoxification center. He said the commander on the scene, Brig. Gen. Armand Roy, was negotiating with Terry Doxtater, a chief of the Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy, in an effort to persuade the Indians to lay down their arms. Doxtater described the situation as ``desperate.'' ``The people of the Pines (the Kahnesatake Mohawks) are not going to lay down their arms if the Canadian army moves in. This is a decision made by the men and the women,'' he said. ``The army has created an environment which they hope will trigger the all-out bloody assault they seek.'' Another Iroquois Confederacy chief, Bob Antone, said the negotiations centered on creation of a native peacekeeping force to replace the Quebec provincial police in Kahnesatake. The Indians have said they will not give up their weapons without some guarantees of protection from police reprisals. They fear the Quebec police might seek revenge for the death of a policeman in a July 11 clash that triggered the Oka standoff. On Sunday, about 350 soldiers demolished the last barricades blocking access to the Kahnesatake settlement and seized control of most of it. The Mohawk militants were confined to a small wooded area about the size of a football field around the detoxification center. The Indians had erected the barricades at Kahnesatake and another Mohawk community, Kahnawake, in a dispute over plans by Oka town officials to expand a golf course onto what they claim is tribal land. The barriers had blocked traffic on an Oka highway and, about 20 miles to the east, on the Mercier Bridge over the St. Lawrence River connecting Montreal with its southern suburbs. In northern New York, Mohawks set up a roadblock Monday afternoon on the international bridge between Canada and the United States near Hogansburg. The Mohawks set up the roadblock on the Canadian side of the bridge, but were persuaded to move by Canadian police after about an hour, according to State Police in Massena, N.Y. Traffic was impeded on the New York side, but was moving again by 1 p.m. At the Mercier Bridge near the Kahnawake Mohawk reserve south of Montreal, Indian women and children staged a peaceful demonstration to support the Oka natives. The army asked Quebec Transport Department employees working to reopen the bridge to withdraw and moved three armored personnel carriers onto the structure. Later, Quebec provincial police entered the Longhouse, a site of traditional Mohawk government on the Kahnawake reserve. Army troops helped cordon off the building, but did not enter, said an army spokesman, Maj. Jean-Paul Macdonald. Mohawk leaders said several Indians were hit by rifle butts and injured in scuffles with police who entered the Longhouse to interrogate the 75 people inside, most of them women and children. Police and army officials denied the allegations. Meanwhile, Mohawks charged that a rock-throwing incident last week contributed to the death of 65-year-old Mohawk Joe Armstrong. Armstrong was in a convoy of Mohawks fleeing the Kahnawake reserve who were pelted by stones thrown by angry local residents. Armstrong died of a heart attack in a hospital early Sunday. Armstrong was not struck but was ``scared to death'', said Kahnawake band counselor Hazel Lazare. He was, however, already a ``very sick man'' when his family decided to take him off the reserve, she added. The army moved into the Kahnesatake Mohawk settlement on Saturday afternoon after factional fighting broke out between moderate and militant Mohawks. The dispute over the golf course expansion was solved when the federal government purchased the land and said it would give it to the Indians. But the Mohawks seized the situation to publicize a much wider range of grievances, including demands for sovereignty.

DOC.HEAD: Gunman Opens Fire Outside Nightclub, 9 Wounded
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with details; CORRECTS spelling of lounge name from Speakeasy to Speak Easy; CLARIFIES victims were inside club. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A gunman opened fire outside a popular nightclub early Sunday and wounded nine people inside, police said. The nine victims, one of whom received a gunshot wound to the face, were in stable condition at Park Place and St. Mary hospitals, said Port Arthur Police Sgt. K.J. Landry. The shooting occurred shortly after 1:00 a.m. outside the Speak Easy Lounge in downtown Port Arthur, said patrolman Paul Arvizo. The gunman, who remained at large Sunday night, possibly used an assault rifle to spray the club, police said. Police believe four or five of the victims were shot and the others were hit by bullet fragments or broken glass, Landry said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: ``Roseanne'' actor John Goodman and his wife, Annabeth, are parents of a girl. Molly Evangeline Goodman was born Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center, Goodman's spokesman, Paul Rosenfield, said Sunday. She weighed 8 pounds, 11 ounces. The parents and the baby have left the hospital and are doing fine, he said. The Goodmans _ he is 37, she is 22 _ were married Oct. 27. Besides his role as husband Dan on the hit ABC series, moviegoers this summer saw him in the role of a fearless exterminator in ``Arachnophobia.''

Prince Charles, recovering from bone surgery, got a get-well card from a sly 9-year-old and a visit from Princess Diana. The heir to the British throne had a second operation on Saturday to mend his right arm, which was broken in a polo match two months ago. Princess Diana visited on Sunday and thanked another patient at the hospital, 9-year-old Penny Hutchins, who slipped past security guards and pushed a get-well card under the prince's door. Penny, who is being treated for a skin ailment, and other young patients drew a teddy bear with an arm in a sling on the card, which read, ``Get well soon, your Highness.'' Doctors at Queen's Medical Center in Nottingham said the surgery was a success and that the 41-year-old prince was in excellent condition. He had a sore hip after surgeons removed bone slivers for transplant into his arm during the three-hour operation. A six-inch titanium plate also was screwed into the damaged bone. The fracture did not heal after the first operation on June 28, the day he fell off his horse.

Greta Garbo may have been reserved around adults but she loved babies and spent hours cooing to each new addition to her family, says her grandniece Gray Horan. ``My mother said she came to visit all of us at the hospital when we were born,'' Horan wrote in an essay about her famous great-aunt in Sunday's New York Times Magazine. ``My son was not even a week old when she arranged to come out to see him.'' Horan, the executrix and sole beneficiary of Garbo's estate, said Garbo saw herself in the little boy and would hold him for hours. ``I brought him to visit her one afternoon, and she said, `Someday, you must tell him I gave him an entire bottle,' '' Horan wrote.

Miss America 1990 Debbye Turner sent American troops in Saudi Arabia words of cheer as the 50 women in this year's pageant gathered for a fund-raiser. ``Hang in there and stand proud and stand tall,'' Miss Turner said Sunday on a radio show called ``Hangin' with Hollywood'' to be broadcast today on Armed Forces Radio. ``The entire country is praying for them. ... I know it's hot,'' she said. The women who want to be Miss America 1991 were the guests of honor Sunday at a $150-a-plate dinner for the Betty Bacharach Rehabilitation Hospital in Atlantic City.

DOC.HEAD: Movie About Cabbie and Jewish Musician Looks at Soviet Life
DOC.TEXT: Pavel Lungin's movie ``Taxi Blues'' examines Soviet life at a time when, in the opinion of many citizens, it couldn't be worse. Into a daily mixture of ethnic unrest, shortages and a rising crime, the Soviet director has dropped the story of the love-hate relationship between a coarse Russian taxi driver and a drunken Jewish jazz saxophonist. The two-hour commentary on the tensions between ethnic groups and classes in what was supposed to be a classless society won Lungin the best-director prize at the 1990 Cannes film festival. Only days after its premiere last week, the film became the sensation of Moscow's fall season. It depicts the taxi driver's confusion, endemic to contemporary Russians, when he realizes a way of life he has been taught was superior is in reality backward. Like the acclaimed Soviet documentary ``This is Not the Way to Live,'' about a crime-ridden society, ``Taxi Blues'' could not have been shown before glasnost, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policy of openness. A leading Moscow theater was sold out for the three-day premiere. An important drawing card is Pyotr Mamonov, a Soviet rock star who plays the musician. The master of ceremonies at the opening described him as ``the idol of Soviet youth.'' The predominantly young audience at the premiere seemed to regard the film as upbeat, focusing on the ultimate success of the Jewish jazzman rather than the frustrations of the Russian cab driver. ``It's about our times, and how people are very different but everyone lives together,'' said Lena, a 22-year-old in the October Theater audience. The movie is to be released in France in September and the United States in November. Veteran actor Pyotr Zaichenko plays the cab driver opposite Mamonov. They meet when Mamonov's character, Lyosha, rides in the cab driven by Zaichenko's character, Vanya Shlykov. After walking away without paying, Lyosha becomes Shlykov's live-in slave to work off the debt. As the story progresses, they grow to like and understand each other, but the relationship eventually breaks down, first because of Lyosha's success with Shlykov's girlfriend and later over his success in the West. Both characters are self-destructive, but the similarities end there. Lyosha is a free-wheeling individual with anti-establishment views whose musical career collapsed because of alcohol. He engages in such antics as drinking a bottle of cologne in the bathroom and romping around naked. Shlykov seeks escape from life's miseries in body building and a simple, stern philosophy revealed in his attempt to sober up Lyosha: ``Break your back like every Russian fellow!'' His crude behavior includes beating up teen-agers and drunks and forcing his girlfriend to have sex with him on a windowsill. Another dark side of Shlykov is his bigotry. ``What, are you a Jew?'' he says when he sees Lyosha drinking heavily, not believing Jews have drinking problems. Lyosha rebels against Shlykov's attempts to sober him up through hard labor and exercise, and retorts: ``You can't make an animal out of me!'' and ``You're a goat!'' The film explores prejudices and how difficult they make it for a Soviet who works with his mind, like the musician, and one who does physical labor, like the cab driver, from getting along with each other. Vignettes show a Soviet society plagued by alcoholism, anti-Semitism and moral decay. Most young people interviewed after seeing the movie sympathized with the irresponsible musician rather than the hard-working taxi driver. ``Shlykov is bitter,'' said Lalai, a 20-year-old student. ``He doesn't understand that a musician can make money and that music is a profession. He can only drive a cab.'' Lalai's friend, Dima, noted that Lyosha, who tours the United States, was like many Soviet cultural figures _ appreciated at home only after his talent is recognized abroad.

DOC.HEAD: Near The Border, A Staging Ground For Raids
LaserPhotos WX6,7
DOC.TEXT: Heavily armed Bedouins sit under a tent guarding a building identified by a new sign outside as housing offices of the Kuwaiti government-in-exile's Ministry of Oil. This is the forward command post for the Kuwaiti resistance movement. Its day-to-day operations include smuggling ammunition and communications equipment into Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, Kuwaiti exiles say. The Saudi-Kuwait border is just three miles to the north. ``All the operations to Kuwait come via Khafji,'' said a senior Kuwaiti guerrilla leader, who spoke on condition of anonymity out of fear of Iraqi reprisals. ``All communications, all orders, all border crossings ... You saw the trucks, the aerials,'' he said. He said the resistance movement has already recruited thousands of volunteers from among the estimated 70,000 Kuwaiti refugees in Saudi Arabia. A senior Saudi official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Sunday that the Kuwaiti resistance is ``growing in strength'' and stepping up its attacks on the Iraqi occupiers. An Associated Press reporter visited the Kuwaiti resistance headquarters last week. Over the weekend, the Saudi government barred journalists from traveling to Khafji without an official escort. The resistance and the Kuwaiti army, which has offices nearby, remain loyal to the government-in-exile headed by Kuwait's emir, Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah. The government is based in Taif, in southwest Saudi Arabia. The red-green-white-and-black Kuwaiti flag flies outside the building, which is also the new headquarters of the Kuwait branch of the Arabian Oil Co., a concern Kuwaiti exiles say is jointly owned by the Kuwaitis, Saudis and Japanese. That is somehow appropriate because Kuwait's oil wealth guarantees that the resistance movement will not lack for funds. Saudi officials estimate that the Kuwaiti government-in-exile has access to assets worth about $100 billion. The Kuwaiti guerrilla leader said money is not a problem. ``What we need is weapons,'' he said. Some arms have been obtained from Iraqi defectors, he said. Others came from the arsenal of Kuwait's National Guard, which Kuwaitis broke into a day after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion. The guerrilla leader refused to provide details about U.S. assistance to the Kuwaiti resistance, except to say that Americans were involved in recruiting Kuwaiti refugees for training in Saudi Arabia. Last week, several U.S. television networks reported that the CIA and Army Special Forces troops were helping the Kuwaiti resistance organize hit-and-run attacks on Iraqi occupiers. No Americans were involved in the fighting, but Kuwaiti fighters based near the Saudi-Kuwait border were reported to be getting intelligence, weapons, radios, advice on target selection and instruction from U.S. advisers, the networks said. President Bush would not confirm directly that his administration is supporting the Kuwaiti resistance. But, he said, ``In a broad way, I support the Kuwaiti underground. I support anybody who can have a hand in restoring legitimacy there to Kuwait and to getting the Iraqis out of Kuwait.'' The Kuwaiti guerrilla organizer said the resistance is still in its formative stages. It is headed by three Kuwaiti sheiks _ two based in Khafji and one in Hafr Al-Batin to the west near King Khalid Military City, a major Saudi military base, he said. In addition to coordinating attacks on Iraqi troops inside Kuwait, the resistance runs a radio and television station., Guerrillas have also managed to smuggle ammunition into Kuwait, the guerrilla organizer said. He said _ and Saudi officials confirmed _ that Kuwaiti women are playing an active role in the resistance. In one instance, he said, a Kuwaiti woman threw a grenade at a group of Iraqi soldiers, killing several before she was slain. The resistance is supported by a network of committees set up by Kuwaiti exiles in Saudi Arabia. Anwar Al-Duaij, the head of a group assisting Kuwaiti refugees in Khobar, 180 miles south of the border, said the military branch of his organization was registering volunteers wishing to return to Kuwait to fight the Iraqis. They are then sent north to infiltrate into Kuwait. He said most of the volunteers did not require training since most Kuwaiti men had served in the National Guard and were familiar with weapons. ``Every day we hear of 70 Iraqi soldiers being killed by the resistance. This is correct, this is not an exaggeration,'' Al-Duaij said. His figures could not be independently verified.

DOC.HEAD: Retransmitting a0787 to add overline
Exhibit celebrates names like Nameless,Texas
DOC.TEXT: Oh, to be chumming on Lake Chargoggagoggmanchauggagoggchaubunagungamaugg. By the time you've pronounced it, you've probably hooked a bass in this popular fishing spot in southern Massachusetts, which boasts the longest name in the United States. Also known as Lake Webster, its Indian name means, ``I fish on my side, you fish on your side and nobody fishes in the middle.'' The lake is among dozens of geographic oddities celebrated in a new Library of Congress exhibition titled ``A World of Names,'' which opens Thursday through Jan. 15. The show marks the 100th anniversary of the U.S. Board on Geographic Names, the federal authority that has officially recognized nearly 7 million foreign and domestic names for use in government maps and publications. If you're an optimist, you'll feel at home in Top of the World, N.M., or Carefree, Ariz. If you're a pessimist, you might be more comfortable in Lowpoint, Ill., or Droop, W.Va. The romantically inclined will enjoy an odyssey through Venus, Texas, and Romeo, Mich., followed by Ogle, Ky.; Valentine, Neb.; Kissimmee, Fla.; Romance, Ark.; Bridal Veil, Ore., and Blissville, Vt. When Christmas comes, you'll find a holiday mood in 836 places across America with ``Bethlehem'' in their names. There are a dozen places named ``holly'' in Maryland, a town called Santa Claus in Georgia and an Oregon stream called Donner and Blitzen. There's a Yankeetown and a Crackertown in Florida, towns called Laurel and Hardy in Iowa, Burns and Allen in Michigan, Carpenter and Hammer in South Dakota, and Narrows and Tight Squeeze in Virginia. Not to mention Ding Dong, Texas. If you have a taste for the unusual, by the way, Texas is your place. There you'll find towns called Loco, Faker, Bug Tussle, Cut and Shoot, Noodle, Tarzan, Dime Box, Turkey and Jot 'Em Down. Ronald Grim, an official of the geography and map division of the Library of Congress and curator of the exhibition, said the rich diversity of America's geographic names tells much about the country's history and cultural origins from Indians through French, Spanish and English settlers. Some names, like the border towns of Calexico, Calif., and Mexicali, Mexico, are artificial. Some, like Rome, Canton and Stockholm, N.Y., are borrowed from the great cities of Europe and Asia. Many towns were named by postmasters after their wives, daughters or girlfriends. Explorer John Wesley Powell named the mesas and buttes of the Grand Canyon for ancient gods and spiritual leaders: Buddha, Zoroaster, Wotan, Isis and Vulcan. The contours of the Rocky Mountains range in northwest Wyoming reminded French explorers of the female anatomy, so they were named the Grand Tetons after the French for ``big breasts.'' Local pride sometimes prompted name changes. Hog Heaven eventually became Moscow, Idaho, after the fabled Soviet capital, and Mole Hill became Mountain, W.Va. In the mountains of southeastern Oregon is ``Whorehouse Meadow,'' named for frontier prostitutes who solicited shepherds. A prudish federal bureaucrat changed its name to ``Naughty Girl Meadow,'' but local residents succeeded in reverting to the original name for historical reasons. For amnesiacs, there is Nameless, Texas. Grim said the local postmaster, exasperated by residents' bickering over what to name their new crossroads community, wrote authorities in Washington a letter declaring ``Let the place be nameless and be damned.'' The Post Office dutifully obliged.

DOC.HEAD: On Land and Sea Saudi Frontier Guards Battle Smugglers, Watch Iraqis
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Bursting from behind a clump of shrubs, a white Chevy pickup roars into the open and drives in frantic, dust-raising circles. Two truckloads of soldiers chase behind, their M-16s cracking in the desert air. Finally, the driver jumps from the pickup and tries to flee on foot. But the long skirt of his Arab dishdasha makes it easy for an officer to grab him. Saudi officials staged this episode Sunday for visiting television crews. The idea was to show how Saudi Arabia's frontier force catches smugglers and illegal aliens along the country's 1,600 miles of coastline and 1,200 miles of land frontier, most of it open desert. In normal times, the frontier force spends considerable effort tracking smugglers of alcohol, illegal in this orthodox Moslem kingdom. But these are not normal times. In addition to watching for smugglers of contraband, the frontier force is preparing for war. Its units are the farthest north of any Saudi forces, ahead of the Saudi army and ``right on the Iraqi border,'' an officer said. U.S. troops are further to the south. Although any move by Iraqi troops toward the border would probably be detected first by radar and other high-tech systems operated by the U.S. military, the frontier patrols have their own orders should they encounter any sign of trouble: send the alarm and get out of the way. ``We are the first line. We are the human early warning system,'' said a frontier force officer, who requested anonymity. He said that in the first days after the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion of Kuwait, Saudi border guards could see the Iraqis on the other side of the line. ``But they have pulled back and we can't see them now,'' he said. The frontier force is stretched thin. Of its 25,000 members, about 3,000 are assigned to the border in the crisis zone south of Iraq and Kuwait _ about two per mile, according to Gen. Mojab Al-Qahtani, who commands the force. At sea, the frontier force is using most of its 16 aging hovercraft to patrol the coastlines and watch for saboteurs or other unusual activity. In one notable incident earlier this year, sea patrols caught a Greek-flagged freighter anchored offshore which was operating as a floating liquor store for small boats running the contraband to shore. Alcohol confiscated by the frontier force is destroyed under the supervision of officials of the force, Saudi customs officers and the Muttawa, the officially designated Islamic religious police.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Day Weekend No Picnic for Active-Duty Guardsmen
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
Laserphoto XSAV1 of Sept. 2
DOC.NOTE: EDITORS NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for possible duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is following this small unit of 14 Guardsmen as they prepare for deployment overseas.

Labor Day weekend 1990. A time to spend with family and friends, maybe go to beach. Or maybe a time to march in the blazing sun wearing your M17A2 gas mask and charcoal-lined chemical warfare suit. Then, if there's time before dinner, you can practice what to do in case of nuclear attack. So goes the holiday weekend for the 265th Quartermaster Detachment, 14 South Carolina guardsmen training for deployment to the Persian Gulf. The water purification unit was placed on active duty a week ago. The men, all from the small community of Allendale, S.C., have been at Fort Stewart since Thursday, brushing up on survival skills. They did not take the holiday off. They jogged before dawn to prepare civilian bodies for possible military action overseas. They devoted part of the afternoon to throwing themselves on the ground in the prescribed method of surviving a nuclear explosion. Most of the day was spent outside the barracks in 90-degree heat, practicing how to survive chemical warfare. Over and over, a timekeeper would shout, ``Gas!'' and the men, in the posture of Old West gunfighters, clawed at the gas mask bags hanging on their hips, trying to get them over their heads before nine seconds passed and the timekeeper yelled ``Stop!'' The unit would freeze and Sgt. Bill Bostick, a Vietnam veteran, would inspect each man and declare him either dead or alive. As crows called from the high pines, the unit struggled into heavy, olive drab chemical warfare jackets and pants, then the thick black rubber gloves and overboots that keep out dangerous chemicals but keep in all body heat. The unit marched in single file past the rows of cinder block barracks where other reservists sat listening to rap music. After the walk, sweat dripped steadily from the bottom of their masks. It poured from the gloves when the men pulled them off. ``(If) we have to spend too much time in these suits over there where it's 120 degrees, there's going to be a lot of dead boys from Allendale,'' Spc. Edward Simmons, a lumber truck driver, said good-naturedly. ``Make him put back on that mask to keep him quiet!'' snapped Spc. Ulysses Calhoun. Later in the day, there is time for basketball. Simmons and Calhoun lead a team of younger men facing an older squad that includes unit leader Sgt. Ronnie Jackson, a stocky 39-year-old probation officer who referees high school basketball games. The younger team wins. ``Hey, reporter,'' Simmons called to the lone observer of the victory. ``You tell them we beat the sergeant.''

DOC.HEAD: IMF Study May Provide Key To Slowing Moscow's Economic Slide
Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: While the Middle East crisis will occupy center stage when President Bush meets with Mikhail Gorbachev next Sunday, the Soviet leader certainly could be forgiven if he also tries to steer the conversation around to his own economy's desperate situation. Gorbachev has been struggling with a myriad of economic problems in recent weeks ranging from a continued shortage of consumer goods on store shelves to wrangling among competing economic commissions over just how fast the Soviet economy should move to a free-market system. Gorbachev is appealing for massive financial aid to turn the situation around, but the United States and many of its allies are demanding a look at the Soviet balance sheets before they commit to any major assistance programs. Many analysts believe those studies, especially one being conducted by the International Monetary Fund, could prove critical in determining the fate of Gorbachev's faltering economic reforms. In announcing the hastily scheduled summit in Helsinki, Finland, the White House on Saturday said it would focus primarily on the Middle East. But Bush said the discussions would not be limited to that area. Whatever the agenda, the summit will allow Gorbachev to turn briefly to statesmanship and away from his economic problems. At the last meeting between the two leaders, May 30-June 3 in Washington, Gorbachev stressed the need for Western aid to insure the success of his efforts to rescue the faltering Soviet economy. Bush, however, has remained opposed to direct Soviet aid, and even the U.S.-Soviet trade agreement which the two leaders did sign remains stalled, awaiting passage in the Soviet parliament of legislation to ensure free emigration. The impasse is occurring as the Soviet economy continues in a steep nose dive. The total output of goods and services actually shrank during the first six months of the year, while the country's trade deficit has more than doubled and both unemployment and inflation are up sharply. ``The Soviet economy is disintegrating,'' said Marshall Goldman, the associate director of Harvard's Russian Research Center. ``Everybody is standing around watching Moscow burn, but nobody knows what to do about it.'' Gorbachev's appeals for Western aid will be considered this month when the IMF and its sister organization, the World Bank, hold their annual meetings in Washington on Sept. 20-27. No decisions on those appeals are expected from the meetings. But finance ministers from the 152 nations that make up the two organizations will discuss the IMF-led study, which was ordered by President Bush and other Western leaders this summer at the economic summit of leading industrial nations in Houston. The study was a compromise between demands by the French and West Germans for an immediate $15-billion aid package and resistance to direct economic aid by Bush and other summit leaders. It is scheduled to be completed in December. The International Monetary Fund generally is viewed as the top cop of international finance. Its clout stems not just from the loans it hands out, but also from the fact that other lenders take their cue from the fund. If, for example, the IMF does not approve of a nation's plans to get its economic house in order, that nation has a hard time getting credit. But IMF austerity programs have in the past triggered bloody riots in Third World nations unhappy with the prescription to curb runaway inflation. Whether the Soviet Union, with its long history of distrust of Western capitalism, will readily accept IMF dictates remains to be seen. The study team faces other formidable obstacles. There is the question of how to measure the Soviet economy, which operates with a currency that is not convertible into other foreign currencies. While the Central Intelligence Agency estimates that the Soviet economy was roughly 51 percent the size of America's $4.2 trillion economy in 1989, other experts have attacked those figures as grossly inflated and suggested that the total output of Soviet goods and services is really only one-third that of America's gross national product. The IMF study may resolve this debate, since one of its main jobs will be to conduct an exhaustive look at a host of economic statistics. These include Soviet gross national product, trade statistics and the amount of hard currency on hand to pay for shortfalls between what the country sells overseas and what it imports. For decades, the Soviet Union was considered a good international credit risk because the government always promptly paid its import bills. But because of a widening trade gap, the Soviets have fallen behind on their payments and are seeking trade credits from other nations. West Germany already has agreed to $3 billion of such credits and other European nations are expected to follow suit. The Bush administration, however, has so far rejected proposals for direct financial aid, and instead offered technical assistance, including advice on improving the collapsing food distribution system or how to establish private banking. But many experts believe that the Soviet problems are so severe they can be resolved only by a major overhaul of the economy and massive economic support from the West. ``The Soviets face fundamental economic problems that are not amenable to quick fixes,'' said Jeffrey Schott, an expert at the Institute for International Economics, a Washington-based research organization. ``The question of restructuring their entire economy and their distribution system will take quite a number of years to accomplish.''

DOC.HEAD: Countdown Begins Again for Columbia
DOC.TEXT: The countdown began today for NASA's third attempt to launch Columbia with the Astro observatory after engineers solved the latest problem to befall the mission. Liftoff is scheduled for 1:20 a.m. EDT Thursday. It will be the first shuttle launch in more than four months _ the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger disaster. ``It's been a long, hot summer, and we're just glad to be getting back into the flight business,'' said NASA spokesman Dick Young. The shuttle fleet had been temporarily grounded after hydrogen leaks were discovered on two of the three orbiters, including Columbia. NASA decided on a Thursday launch after re-establishing full contact with the X-ray telescope inside Columbia's cargo bay. The telescope is one of four that constitute the $150 million Astro observatory. Contact between the instrument and launch control computers was lost Wednesday night after the cargo bay doors were closed, and NASA scrubbed Saturday's launch attempt. Workers installed a new electronic component for the telescope inside the cargo bay and finished testing it Sunday. Engineers also had trouble verifying the telescope's ability to send signals over a radio link that would be used during the flight. The problem was caused by faulty software and was corrected Sunday, Young said. Columbia's liftoff would have been delayed until at least Friday if the problem had not been solved by midnight Sunday, Young said. That's when workers planned to begin freezing the argon used to keep the X-ray telescope's instruments cold. Columbia was supposed to have gone up May 30, but hydrogen leaked during fueling and NASA called off the launch. Atlantis was the next shuttle scheduled to fly, but its classified Pentagon mission was delayed from July to November when it, too, was found to have hydrogen leaks. Columbia returned to the launch pad in August with new hydrogen lines. NASA has not sent up a shuttle since April, when Discovery carried the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Columbia has a crew of seven astronauts, the largest since Challenger. Four of the crew members are astronomers who will work in non-stop shifts to operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes during the nine- to 10-day mission. Astro will return to Earth with the shuttle and might be used again on a later flight. Astro is designed to observe some of the hottest objects in the universe, including a comet and a supernova. It will be the first shuttle mission in five years dedicated entirely to scientific research.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq's Air Fleet Poses Sanctions-Busting Threat
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein has a fleet of more than 150 transport aircraft, including airliners plundered from Kuwait, that could be used to beat the United Nations-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq. But aviation experts stress that any attempt at airborne blockade-busting is fraught with difficulties and dangers, for both sides. They note, too, that an airlift would likely be little more than a gesture of defiance because it could never carry enough supplies to feed Iraq's 17 million people or enough military materiel to make a serious difference in Saddam's confrontation with the West. ``The sheer amount of cargo that would be needed to resupply a whole country by air is mind-boggling,'' said Don Kerr of London's International Institute for Strategic Studies. ``You only need to look at the U.S. airlift into Saudi Arabia to get some idea of the logistics and equipment involved _ and the Iraqis have nothing to compare with that,'' Kerr said in a telephone interview.
