During the Berlin Airlift in 1948-49, the United States and its allies flew more than 277,000 missions to haul nearly 2 million tons of food, coal and other life-saving provisions into West Berlin after the Soviets cut it off. At the peak of the 15-month operation, the allied air forces were flying 1,200 missions a day that carried 13,000 tons of supplies. The State Department reported last week that Iraq ``may increasingly rely on air transport'' as a means of avoiding the tightening naval embargo spearheaded by the U.S. Navy. The Washington Post reported Saturday that North Korea and Cuba have been flying military-related materiel into Iraq. But Britain's Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, said Sunday that these flights are ``not a major problem at the moment ... One of the calculations is that Saddam will run out of money to pay for such air shipments because the oil trade will be blocked.'' Kerr and other experts say Iraq may be able to maintain an aerial lifeline, providing U.S. and other members of the multinational force enforcing the U.N.-ordered embargo do not decide to begin shooting down transport planes. U.S. and other warships have U.N. permission to use ``minimal force'' to prevent ships supplying Iraq. That could be done without causing casualties by shooting off the rudders of blockade-running ships. But it's a different matter in the air. ``What do you do if you challenge an aircraft and it doesn't turn away?'' said Kerr. ``The only alternative is to shoot it down and that could cause an outcry with all kinds of moral and political ramifications.'' It is not clear whether U.N. rules of engagement for enforcing the embargo permit firing on aircraft flying into Iraq. But Hurd said the British and others are ``considering how one would set about'' blocking the flying embargo-busters. Iraq's state-run airline, Iraqi Airways, and Arab Air Cargo, a freight line operated with neighboring Jordan, have more than 70 aircraft between them. These include Boeing 747 jumbo jets that can carry more than 100 tons and Soviet-built Antonov An-24 transports with payloads of more than 80 tons. The Iraqi air force has 82 transport aircraft, including An-24s and Ilyushin IL-76s. Each is capable of carrying 45 tons of freight but many would probably be needed for military movements and might not be available. Kuwaiti sources in the Persian Gulf say the Iraqis seized at least 15 of Kuwait Airways' 21 airliners in the Aug. 2 invasion, flying them to Iraq. In theory, Iraq has the capacity to fly in hundreds of tons of cargo a day, provided it has friendly countries willing to provide airfields and to covertly ship in supplies for Baghdad. Jordan is a close ally of Iraq and has said it will abide by the U.N. sanctions. But the Jordanians, who depend heavily on trade with Iraq, are quibbling about compensation before they lower the boom. Yemen, another country with strong links to Baghdad, has said it also will adhere to the sanctions. But Western officials suspect it might be a conduit. Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi declared Saturday that Tripoli will also comply with U.N. efforts to block oil exports from Iraq and occupied Kuwait. But he stressed that ``it is impossible for us in the end to take part in starving ... people'' in Iraq. But Iraq is ringed by Syria, Saudi Arabia, Turkey and Iran, which if not downright hostile are not disposed to allow Iraq-bound planes to fly through their airspace. Only Jordan to the west could provide an avenue for a Baghdad airlift _ but would in doing so risk international reprisals.

DOC.HEAD: Authors Divided on Killer in Quirky Mystery Series `Twin Peaks'
DOC.TEXT: Four best-selling authors questioned by TV Guide couldn't agree on who killed Laura Palmer in ABC's ``Twin Peaks,'' but say the series better solve the crime in a hurry. Jackie Collins, Andrew M. Greeley, Tony Hillerman and Iris Ranier Dart, were asked to pick the most likely villain of the quirky show, directed by David Lynch and set in a sleepy logging town in the Pacific Northwest. Their answers appear in the Sept. 8 issue of the magazine. The show that received 14 Emmy nominations began with the murder of homecoming queen Laura Palmer and subsequent shows revolve around the investigation of her death, with a dizzying number of plot twists and turns. It offers an eclectic mix of characters ranging from FBI Agent Cooper, a straight-laced law enforcement type who loves cherry pie, to the Log Lady, a woman who walks around town carrying a log. Greeley, the author of the 1990 best seller ``The Cardinal Virtues,'' believes the killer is Dr. Lawrence Jacoby, a psychiatrist. ``Laura was driving Jacoby crazy,'' Greeley said. ``He was attracted by her innocence and by her evil.'' Ms. Collins, author of 12 best sellers that have sold 100 million copies, concluded the killer was Sheriff Truman's deputy, Andy, ``because he appears to be the least likely.'' Cooper was shot in the last episode of the past season, but Ms. Collins said he has to survive. ``He's the whole show,'' she said. ``It's obvious he wears a bulletproof vest because he needs one to hold in his stomach.'' Hillerman, author of ``Coyote Waits,'' a current best seller, believes the killer will turn out to be Leland Palmer, the victim's father. ``It's possible that he could have bumped her off in a rage after he found out she was working at One-Eyed Jacks (a brothel-casino),'' he said. But Hillerman complained that he wasn't sure the show's writers have even decided who the killer is. ``By normal standards the series is sloppy and inconsistent,'' he said. ```Twin Peaks' sets things up and then does nothing with them.'' Ms. Dart, whose best seller ``Beaches'' was made into a feature film starring Bette Midler, came up with the idea that Laura was the killer and not the victim. The victim, she believes, is really Madeleine, Laura's cousin. ``Laura wanted to come back as Madeleine so she could start afresh and escape her tainted past,'' Ms. Dart theorized. Greeley, Ms. Collins and Hillerman all said the mystery has to be wrapped up in the first episode of the fall season, a two-hour show scheduled for Sept. 30. ``It's not going to be popular with a mass audience unless they start coming up with answers,'' Ms. Collins said. ``But they should find another murder victim when the killer is identified _ just to raise some doubt.''

DOC.HEAD: ``Loser!'' `Old Hag!'' _ An Anglo-Iraqi War of Words
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Diplomatic exchanges between Iraq and Britain are getting a touch personal. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has called President Saddam Hussein of Iraq ``a person who has taken hostages, cruelly, brutally, and a person who has hidden behind the skirts of women and children.'' ``This man is a loser,'' she added in an interview broadcast Sunday on Britain's TV-AM network. The Iraqi News Agency fired back: ``The old hag Thatcher seems to have been upset by the permission given women and children to leave Iraq, as she had wanted to make an issue of them in her electoral campaign.'' ``Thatcher would do well to bear in mind that the empire on whose possessions the sun did not go down has long been defunct, and neither she nor any of her allies will be able to set the clock back,'' it said. It referred to ``Thatcher's canine, harsh voice'' and ``empty bluster.'' The state newspaper al-Iraq called her a ``circus buffoon who is dancing on American ropes ... vomiting poison like a spotted serpent,'' waging an ``imperialist- Zionist-colonialist-reactionary aggression against Iraq.'' ``Thatcher, the frenzied and corrupt lady, does not frighten the glorious Iraqi knights,'' al-Iraq editorialized. In London, interviewer David Frost asked Mrs. Thatcher whether she thought Saddam was mad. ``Calculating, not mad,'' she replied. ``Fanatical in that his personal ambitions must come before everything and everyone else. And he has no regard for human life or liberty or justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Abe Death Toll at 51
DOC.TEXT: Typhoon Abe killed at least 51 people and injured about 250 when it hit Shanghai, China's largest city, and surrounding coastal areas, an official newspaper reported today. The storm, which struck Friday, killed three people in Shanghai, which just two weeks ago was suffering from a heat wave, the China Daily reported. Previous reports have said 48 people were killed in coastal Zhejiang province by Abe, the sixth major storm to batter China's southeastern coast this summer and the worst typhoon to hit Zhejiang in 34 years. Heavy rainfall flooded most of urban Shanghai during the weekend. One district registered 8.2 inches of rainfall in one day, China Daily said. An accompanying photograph from the neighboring city of Nanjing showed trees planted in sidewalks uprooted and leaning into the streets. In Zhejiang, 41,000 people were left homeless and 45 were reported missing, the paper said.

DOC.HEAD: Jailed IRA Member Could Be Freed After 7 Years of Legal Limbo
DOC.TEXT: Joseph Doherty, a folk hero in the Irish-American community who has a Manhattan street named for him, could soon be free on bail after seven years behind bars _ and in legal limbo. Doherty's allegiance to the Irish Republican Army and its control over his decision-making is the focus of a bail hearing Tuesday. It was called by U.S. District Judge Miriam G. Cedarbaum, who is considering a bail request for Doherty while he pursues political asylum in the United States. ``She wants to know what his relationship is, if any, and if he's still a member (of the IRA) and would he follow their orders in violation of a bond if it were to be set,'' said Doherty's attorney, Stephen A. Sommerstein. Doherty, 35, has been imprisoned in a Manhattan jail since his 1983 arrest in New York. He faces a life sentence in the United Kingdom for the 1980 slaying of a British officer, and prison escape. He won a series of court battles in the United States to avoid extradition, some of which were later reversed by the Justice Department. Doherty has acknowledged that the British officer was killed in a gunfight between troops and Doherty's four-man IRA unit, but claims the fighting was political. His lawyers argue he should be freed on bail, claiming his right to due process has been violated by his lengthy imprisonment. ``The Constitution just doesn't permit indefinite imprisonment under these circumstances,'' Sommerstein said. The U.S. government opposes Doherty's release. Assistant U.S. Attorney Claude A. Millman argues the government can detain an alien who entered the country illegally, as a convict. ``Given the government's substantial interest in assuring Doherty's availability for deportation ... it simply cannot be said that Doherty's detention has any constitutional dimension,'' Millman said in court papers. ``Unquestionably, Doherty's deportation case is of extraordinary importance to our foreign relations,'' he said. Sommerstein has proposed a bail package that would allow Doherty's release on a $100,000 bond posted by former City Council President Paul O'Dwyer. The attorney also has arranged a $35,000-a-year job for Doherty at a Long Island factory. Sommerstein said other supporters have offered to post money and their homes to insure that Doherty won't flee. In an effort to establish ties to the community, Sommerstein described in court papers the wide support Doherty has received from politicians, religious leaders and Irish-American organizations. He said Doherty had received visits in jail from numerous senators and congressmen, Roman Catholic Cardinal John O'Connor, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and the Rev. Lawrence Jenco, a former hostage in Lebanon. Doherty also has been designated honorary grand marshal at St. Patrick's Day parades across the country. New York City gave his name to a street near the jail where he is housed. ``I've never seen a group of people so incensed at what has happened,'' O'Dwyer, an attorney, said of the Irish-American community. ``The Constitution is violated in letter and in spirit.'' Doherty fled to New York in 1982 after more than a year on the run in Ireland. He was arrested by the FBI in 1983, and the British government requested his extradition. Earlier this summer, Doherty won his latest legal victory when a federal appeals court ruled that he is entitled to seek political asylum in the United States. The U.S. government is appealing the decision, which said U.S. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh was improperly influenced by political concerns when he denied Doherty the chance to show he would be persecuted if returned to the United Kingdom. Doherty last was questioned about his loyalty to the IRA at a hearing in 1984. He indicated he still took orders from the IRA. The judge then barred his extradition, ruling that the British officer's killing was an act related to IRA's political goal of a unified Ireland. When asked to characterize Doherty's mood going into the upcoming hearing, Sommerstein said, ``Joe's got no fears stating his position.''

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Klan Protestors Succeed in Forcing Cancellation of Klan March
LaserPhoto WX10
By IAN WAGREICH
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: About 3,000 counter-demonstrators succeeded in forcing the Ku Klux Klan to call off its planned march through the capital, but Klansmen are vowing to return next Labor Day. But robed and hooded members of the Mount Holly, N.C.-based Christian Knights of the Ku Klux Klan still held a brief rally on the U.S. Capitol steps Sunday as a mob, held several blocks away by police, shouted protests. Police escorted about 46 members of the white supremacist group to the Capitol while a crowd estimated by police at 3,000 attempted to move into the area. Officials said the klansmen called off their planned march after learning that counter demonstrators were blocking the route. ``Officials conferred with the Klan and they were advised ... anti-Klan protesters were blocking the roadway and it would be difficult, if not impossible, for the Klan to march through there,'' District of Columbia police spokeswoman Shannon Crockett said. A Klan leader promised his group would return. ``We are coming back,'' Christian Knights Grand Dragon Horace King said. An unidentified klansman said, ``We'll be back next year with more. We'll be coming every Labor Day.'' Police officers wearing helmets and carrying nightsticks, riot shields and gas masks held the anti-Klan protesters about three blocks from the Capitol grounds. Tin cans and rocks were thrown from the surging throng. Police said three people were charged with disorderly conduct and a juvenile was charged with inciting to riot after an incident that sent one anti-Klan protester to the hospital with head injuries even before the march was to kick off. Crockett said four police officers and four other persons were treated for injuries, five of them at local hospitals. She said an undercover D.C. police officer was injured when a rushing crowd trampled her, an officer was hurt when he was hit by a rock, knocking him to the ground, and two other officers were treated at the scene after sustaining minor injuries. Law enforcement officials said about 3,000 anti-Klan demonstrators were in the area, but the All People's Congress, one of the counter demonstration organizers, said it counted nearly 10,000 people. About 5,500 anti-Klan protesters took to the streets for a Nov. 27, 1982 Washington march by a different branch of the Klan. Looting and violence followed that Klan appearance and police fired tear gas in an attempt to break up crowds of counter demonstrators. In the ensuing confrontation, 11 D.C. police officers were injured and 38 persons were arrested on a variety of charges. Officials abruptly sealed off all access to the Capitol grounds when it appeared the crowd would surge toward the building, said U.S. Capitol Police spokesman Dan Nichols. Police declined to reveal the number of officers on duty. Meanwhile, the permit for the anti-Klan demonstration on the Capitol grounds was revoked after the protesters arrived en masse, in violation of the terms of the agreement, Nichols said. Among those attending the counter demonstration at the Washington Monument were Effi Barry, wife of Mayor Marion Barry, and their son Christopher. Mrs. Barry said Christopher was concerned about the Klan rally and wanted to express his First Amendment rights. About 200 Klan members rallied in northeast Georgia on Saturday, and a SWAT team broke up a small Klan rally in Louisiana. D.C. Police Chief Isaac Fulwood said city residents didn't want the Klan to march and won. At one point, as authorities were attempting to break up the demonstrators, Fulwood spoke to a group to explain what had happened. A demonstrator, Matthew Pringle, told Fulwood ``They will never march here _ not in my time.'' Fulwood pointed to Pringle and said, ``Listen to the man, this is why the Klan did not march.''

DOC.HEAD: State Restores Springfield Home to Frank Lloyd Wright's Vision
DOC.TEXT: As a young Chicago architect in 1902, Frank Lloyd Wright got a dream job: build a house with no limit on cost or creativity. Wright spent two years and $60,000, planning every detail from walls to chairs. Now, nearly nine decades later, the state has spent three years and $5 million restoring the vision of the man who became America's most famous architect. The result goes on display Friday when the house Wright designed for a wealthy widow opens to the public for the first time since 1987. ``This building is probably the most perfectly preserved of his early buildings,'' said site manager Donald Hallmark. ``Literally, almost everything he designed for it is still here.'' The Dana-Thomas House _ named for its owners _ was one of Wright's first large homes, said Wright expert Elaine Harrington, curator at the Wright Home and Studio Foundation in Oak Park. By 1902, the architect was growing in prominence, but most of his work was still small homes in Chicago suburbs. The building is an example of the ``prairie'' style of architecture, which emphasizes horizontal lines and an open, flowing floor plan. The two-story home looks vaguely like pagodas joined by a low walkway. Copper-green rain gutters form a prominent border to the sloping roof. A green plaster frieze runs near the top of the walls, linking the roof to the pale brick below. Inside, low, dim rooms will suddenly give way to high ceilings and shafts of sunlight. Rooms seem connected at random, with open spaces here and sudden turns there. Hallmark said architects usually have limited control over a home's furniture and decorations, but Wright designed everything, like a composer writing music. ``It is a long symphony,'' Hallmark said. ``It is probably the greatest symphonic collection of decorative art objects that you're ever going to find from the early 20th century.'' That collection of Wright lamps, stained-glass windows and furniture makes the Dana-Thomas House stand out, experts say. ``Not all buildings are allowed to survive with all that intact,'' Harrington said. ``If you're going to explain the work, you need as much of that stuff as you can possibly afford.'' Gov. James R. Thompson was a a chief supporter of the restoration. The project spent $704,000 in privately raised money to buy a lamp Wright designed for the house. The furniture is so valuable that its location was kept secret while it was being restored. Wright built the house for widow Sarah Lawrence Dana to hold lavish parties. Poet Carl Sandburg sometimes read his work there, and Dana once held a reception for conductor John Philip Sousa. She threw frequent parties _ one with 1,000 guests. Eventually, Dana was hit with financial and health problems. The Thomas Publishing Co. bought the house in 1944, using it as office space but also taking care to preserve the building as Wright had designed it. The house was sold to the state in 1981 for $1 million, a fraction of its value, Hallmark said.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix coding
Slim Prospects for Big Power Shift in 1990 Elections
DOC.TEXT: Republicans and Democratic challengers claim they are on their way to upsetting senior senators, but the prospects are slim that the 1990 elections will alter Washington's balance of power. Barring an extraordinary political upheaval on Nov. 6, President Bush will spend at least two more years dealing with a Congress controlled by the opposition Democrats. Familiar faces may disappear, however. Democrats say this is the year they can defeat Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C. Republicans have high hopes of unseating Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I. Major changes are certain to occur in state capitals where 13 governors are retiring, including those in California, Texas, Illinois and Ohio. When the dust settles in November, the most significant result of the 1990 elections is likely to be which party won the political control in key states to redraw congressional and state legislative district lines to conform to the 1990 census. According to preliminary Census figures, population trends will require shifting 19 House seats before the 1992 elections. Most of the seats will move South and West with California picking up seven, Florida four, and Texas three. New York will likely give up three seats, and Illinois, Pennsylvania, Michigan and Ohio will probably give up two apiece. The political importance of controlling the redistricting process has made the race to succeed Republican George Deukmejian as governor of California the most important race of the year. Democrat Dianne Feinstein and Republican Pete Wilson are spending millions of dollars to blanket California with television appeals for support. The Democrats already control the California legislature. If Feinstein is elected governor, the Republicans will have little voice when lines are drawn for the state's seven new U.S. House seats. A victory by Wilson would force the two parties to come up with a compromise plan. Florida faces a similar situation, in which former Sen. Lawton Chiles and Rep. Bill Nelson are competing for the Democratic nomination to challenge Gov. Bob Martinez, rated by Democrats as one of the most vulnerable Republican incumbents. One of the most closely watched Senate races is in North Carolina, where former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt is running neck-and-neck with Helms, the Republican conservative icon whose latest crusade has been an attack against federal grants for art work he deems obscene. So far, Gantt, who is black, has surprised observers by the amount of support he has attracted in opinion polls. All told, the 1990 numbers look like this: _ 35 Senate seats are up for grabs, 18 now held by Republicans and 17 by Democrats. The Democrats now control the Senate by a 55-45 margin. The Republicans are given a good chance to narrow that margin, but are considered very unlikely to regain the majority they lost in 1986. _ The entire House faces re-election and the current Democratic majority of 257 to 176 isn't expected to change much. Two seats are now vacant. _ 36 states will elect governors. Twenty of those now have Democratic governors, 16 Republicans. Nationwide, 29 states have Democratic governors and 21 have Republicans. Eight Democrats and five Republicans are not seeking re-election. _ Voters also will fill 6,262 state legislative seats and elect hundreds of mayors, including a successor to Marion Barry, the embattled mayor of the nation's capital. Awaiting sentencing on a misdemeanor cocaine possession charge, Barry is running as an independent for a seat on the District of Columbia City Council. All these campaigns are getting into high gear while the public's attention is riveted on the Persian Gulf and the buildup of American forces following the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait on Aug. 2. Pollsters and politicians agree there is no way of assessing what impact the Middle East crisis will have on the November elections. At the same time, they also agree that the threat of a desert war is making it tougher than usual for candidates to get the voters' attention. ``Iraq knocked everything off the radar screen,'' said Ed Rollins, co-chairman of the House Republican campaign committee. ``I don't know where it goes from here,'' he conceded. Before the Iraqi invasion, Rollins said he hoped Republicans would benefit from ``an anti-incumbent mood that was starting to build,'' and was being fed by public unhappiness over the political ties between members of Congress and operators of savings and loan institutions. ``It's awful hard to talk about savings and loans when you're on the verge of war,'' he said. Whether voters are listening or not, candidates are raising other issues. Abortion, a major issue in the handful of races last year, is a big concern throughout he country with politicians in both parties scrambling to get on what they consider the safest ground. Typical of one approach is the television ad run in Ohio by Democratic gubernatorial candidate Tony Celebrezze. ``I believe you can be personally opposed to abortion,'' Celebrezze says in the ad, ``while recognizing as I do that politicians shouldn't dictate to a woman what choice to make.'' His Republican opponent, former Cleveland Mayor George Voinovich, countered that Celebrezze was ``completely reversing'' his former strong anti-abortion position. In many high-profile races, the two candidates are on the same side of the abortion question. Feinstein and Wilson, in California, are both pro-abortion rights, as are Democratic Sen. Paul Simon of Illinois and his rival, Republican Rep. Lynn Martin, and Pell of Rhode Island and his challenger, Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider. Republicans say they think the popular 43-year-old Schneider has a good chance to upset Pell, 71, the patrician chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Promoters: Brains Featured Alongside Beauty in 70th Miss America Pageant
DOC.TEXT: Brains _ and beauty _ highlight this week's Miss America Pageant, heralding a new era in the 70-year-old contest better known for skin-tight swimsuits than generous college scholarships, promoters say. Competitors for Miss America 1991 still spray glue on their swimsuits to prevent skin spillover and swab their teeth with petroleum jelly to ensure a shiny smile, but pageant executive director Leonard Horn said change is coming. Horn eliminated pre-competition photo opportunities featuring contestants in swimsuits this year and for a second straight year the swimsuit competition will account for 15 percent of pageant scoring, an all-time low. ``The swimsuit competition is our Achilles' heel,'' Horn said. ``I find it difficult to rationalize putting a young college woman in a swimsuit and high-heel shoes. ... But it would be folly for us to eliminate it unless we can find an acceptable alternative.'' The search for such an alternative goes on, he said, adding the emphasis should not be on swimsuits, but rather on the $5 million in scholarships awarded at state and national levels. Many contestants are working toward master's degrees or doctorates, he said. They range in age from 19 to the pageant maximum of 26. The winner receives a $35,000 scholarship. ``This program is involved in volunteerism and wholesome American values that in a world teeming with negativism is one little positive light,'' Horn said. ``In today's world, role models are more important than ever.'' The pageant is celebrating its seventh decade. It was created in 1921 by local merchants trying to squeeze in an extra tourist weekend after Labor Day. Returning this year is 75-year-old Bert Parks, who was fired in 1980 for being too old to croon ``There She Is'' to the new Miss America. Co-host Gary Collins will still fill that role, but Parks will serenade 26 former Miss Americas with his trademark song during one segment of the two-hour production. Miss America 1971 Phyllis George joins Collins as co-host. Weeklong preliminary competitions culminate in nationally televised finals Saturday. Judges allot 30 percent to an interview with the contestants, 40 percent for talent, and 15 percent each to evening gown and swimsuit. Celebrity judges this year include actresses Shirley Jones, Delta Burke, Nell Carter and Cynthia Sikes; actor John Forsythe, author Sidney Sheldon and talk show host Larry King. The winner will succeed Miss America 1990 Debbye Turner. Miss Turner plans to return to the University of Missouri-Columbia Veterinary School where she is six months short of her doctorate in veterinary medicine.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Serial Killer Left Clues
DOC.TEXT: With one day to go before classes resume at the University of Florida, police are studying what they vaguely described as ``messages'' left by the killer of five college students. Investigators on Sunday also said they reduced their list of prime suspects from eight to four, and clues left by the killer are helping. The slayings have terrorized the campus, where students are on a Labor Day break until Tuesday. ``The messages were given to us from the crime scenes,'' said police Lt. Sadie Darnell. ``The messages are indirect that we're interpreting to be messages of some importance.'' The killer left no notes or other writings, she said, declining to provide further details. Sheriff's Lt. Spencer Mann added that no ``calling cards'' were found on the bodies. ``It's not a signature-type homicide,'' he said. Autopsies on Tracy Inez Paules and Manuel Taboada, both 23, showed they died of stab wounds similar to those that killed the other victims, Mann said. Unlike the first three, the bodies of Miss Paules and Taboada were not mutilated. Mann would not say whether the same weapon was used in all five slayings. Police said an Ohio fugitive, 58-year-old Warren Virgil Tinch, was dropped from their ``prime suspects'' list. Tinch is sought in Ohio in the stabbing death of a 52-year-old woman and is suspected of stealing cars in Ocala and Gainesville a week before the killings. Mann would not say whether 18-year-old Edward Lewis Humphrey is among the top four suspects and would not otherwise disclose who is on the list. Humphrey, a part-time freshman at the university whom authorities describe as emotionally troubled, is in jail on $1 million bail for allegedly assaulting his 79-year-old grandmother and has been questioned as a suspect. Miss Paules and Taboada were found Tuesday at the apartment they shared at a complex where Humphrey lived for a few weeks this summer. A neighbor said Humphrey was romantically interested in Miss Paules and often waited for her by the pool. Police took prints of Humphrey's feet in jail, and two officers in hip waders Sunday used a metal detector to search a creek next to his apartment complex, Darnell said. Police said all they found was an old street sign. The victims were students at either the university or Santa Fe Community College. Their deaths terrified classmates, including about 100 who dropped out or transferred. University President John Lombardi said campus security was tight. ``We believe this community to be as safe as any other university community in America,'' he said. ``Would I send my child back to the University of Florida? Yes, I would.'' Student body President Michael Browne said that his classmates are still afraid but that dropping out would be a mistake. ``Above all, we must not be held hostage to our fears,'' he said. ``Giving up will not solve anything.'' Also slain were Christina Powell, 17, of Jacksonville; Sonya Larson, 18, of Deerfield Beach, and Christa Hoyt, 18, of Newberry. All lived in off-campus apartments and were discovered beginning Aug. 26. A memorial service for the victims is scheduled for Wednesday at the school's basketball arena.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Iraq Would Rather Eat Mud Than Capitulate
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The government has acknowledged that it is instituting food rationing but says Iraqis would rather eat mud than bow to foreign powers, who have isolated Baghdad as punishment for its seizure of Kuwait. Government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi on Sunday denied reports that the U.N.-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq had caused shortages. He said, however, that as a precaution his government was instituting steps to reduce food consumption. ``We have a war-tested society. We have a war-tested economy. So even if we eat mud, we will resist pressure and not kneal down to any foreign power,'' he said, referring to the eight-year war with Iran that ended in 1988. Foreigners who left the country reported lines for bread and other food. Last week, Iraqi sources said rationing was to begin Sept. 1, but on Sunday a shopkeeper said he thought the rationing would begin on Wednesday. It was not immediately clear whether the measures affected all of Iraq at once. The embargo, backed by a U.S.-led armada of warships from several countries, has halted nearly all of Iraq's vital oil exports and food imports, aiming to force an Iraqi pullout from Kuwait. Al-Hadithi and Information and Culture Minister Latif Nasaif Jasim took a defiant stance in a meeting with reporters on Sunday, saying Iraq wanted peace, but was prepared for war. Jasim said Iraq was not afraid of war with the United States, which has deployed tens of thousands of troops in the Saudi desert since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said his country has 1.5 million men under arms and 5.5 million volunteers ready to fight. ``During the war with Iran, hundreds of American-made planes darkened our skies, and even our children used to throw rocks at these planes,'' Jasim said. ``So if Bush wants to stay in power, he will pull out his soldiers and not make war.'' Under a plan organized by the ruling Ba'ath Party, stores will limit the quantity of certain products that can be sold at one time, al-Hadithi said. ``We need only bread and water. We need no more than that. We can live for a long time,'' Jasim said. ``Dignity is more important than food.'' Earlier, sources said coupons had been issued to Iraqis entitling them to a monthly allocation of 13 pounds of flour, 3.3 pounds of rice, 2.2 pounds of sugar, 3.5 ounces of tea, 1.1 pounds of oil, 17 ounces of detergent and one bar of soap. Two food store owners in Baghdad said they were told the rationing plan would limit purchases of such items as rice, sugar, tea, cooking oil, baby food, detergent and soap. ``We really don't think about this. I'm not hoarding. Everything is here. We are not worried about it,'' one shopper said on condition of anonymity. Al-Hadithi said the plan was a precaution prompted by the U.N. sanctions but not a response to any spot shortages. ``We are determined to live on our own cultivation,'' he said. ``Iraq reached self-sufficiency in vegetables and fruit during the war with Iran.'' He said production of rice and wheat were up significantly, and that the government had taken steps to encourage farmers to put more land into cultivation and to entice businessmen to take more interest in the countryside.

DOC.HEAD: Las Vegas Motorcyclist Dies in Lightning Strike; Californians Injured
DOC.TEXT: Lightning killed a man riding on the back of a motorcycle and injured the driver when the bolt struck as they rode down a six-lane highway, police said. The passenger was struck on U.S. Highway 95 outside of town Sunday afternoon, said Nevada Highway Patrol dispatcher Patrick McDonald. The woman motorcycle driver was injured and taken to a hospital where she was treated and released, McDonald said. He said the victims, whose names were not disclosed, were Las Vegas residents. In California, 10 campers huddled under an awning were injured when lightning struck a nearby tree, authorities said. About 20 people staying at a San Bernardino National Forest campground near Big Bear took shelter from a fast-moving storm Sunday afternoon, said fire Capt. Ron Lee of the California Department of Forestry. The awning was connected to a vehicle parked under a pine tree. ``What happened was the lightning hit a tree next to the trailer, started to spiral down but then jumped onto the group,'' said CDF Capt. Bob Buhrle. One dog was killed and another injured. Lee said at least three people suffered burns but he was unsure how severe injuries were. He said seven others had ``varying other complaints.'' All were transported to area hospitals, where their conditions were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Day Celebrations Mix Fun, Prayer, Mock Funeral to Mark Demise of Summer
DOC.TEXT: Americans enjoying the last gasps of summer sizzled hot dogs and hamburgers on barbecues, frolicked on the beach, spread out picnics and just plain had fun in Labor Day celebrations nationwide. Sobering current events take center stage tonight in Corpus Christi, Texas, where a prayer service for U.S. military personnel shipped to the Middle East was organized. A mock funeral in New York today will mark the unofficial demise of summer with the burial of a coffin containing hot-weather items like sunglasses and swim trunks. Virgina Beach saw no repeat of looting and violence that marred last year's holiday, a $40 million aquarium complex on the Mississippi River opened to record attendance in New Orleans and annual clamshell-toss championships were held on the New Jersey shore. Hordes flocked to the beach in California, where a body-building competition was scheduled for today at famed Muscle Beach in Los Angeles. In Texas, the annual Marfa Lights Festival ends its four-day run today after celebrating the natural phenomenon that can always be viewed about five miles east of Marfa, a city about 200 miles southeast of El Paso. Scientists haved tried to explain the mysterious lights, first documented more than 100 years ago by pioneer ranchers. Legend has it the lights are the ghost of the Mescalero Apache Indian Chief Alsate looking for his tribe. Gospel music Sunday at the Spirit Festival in Kansas City, Mo., gave way to rock 'n' roll from the group Santana Sunday night. Controversy flared briefly at the festival when not everyone was amused by live mice on a roulette wheel or the mule that jumped through a blazing hoop. Animal-rights activists complained and the attractions were shut down. Barbecue was alive and well in Ireland, where a team of four Kansas City-area grill chefs were named grand champions at the 6th Annual World Cup Barbecue Competition in Lisdoonvarna. The competition was waged over hot coals by 31 teams, including representatives from the Soviet Union, Italy and Holland. A team from Kansas City won last year, too. Sunday's crowd of 16,009 at the Aquarium of the Americas in New Orleans was a single-day record, said spokesman Steve Schulkens. The figure topped the previous high of 15,101 set in 1989 by the National Aquarium in Baltimore. In Cape May, N.J., Betty Ann Saraceni of Philadelphia won the women's singles in the 44th annual Clamshell Pitching Contest. She also won a share of the women's doubles title. Contestants take turns tossing clam shells into holes in the sand 25{ feet apart. Michigan Gov. James Blanchard was expected to join more than 70,000 people early today for the 4.5-mile Mackinac Bridge walk in Mackinac City. The event traditionally kicks off statewide Labor Day festivities. Elsewhere, state fairs, demolition derbies, union gatherings and musical concerts were scheduled. Residents in western New York organized the mock funeral procession along Lake Erie today. ``Mourners'' were encouraged to bring summertime items for interment in a coffin. ``Everybody feels so awful at the end of summer, so why not say good-bye with a funeral,'' said organizer Jan Reuther, of Tonawanda.

DOC.HEAD: Experts: Newspaper as Crime-Fighting Tool May Tread Dangerous Ground
DOC.TEXT: ``Murders-Rape-Abuse-DUI's-Drugs-Shoplifting-More.'' A retrospective of summer films? No, it's the subheading for the prototype of The Informer, a new Florida newspaper promising crime stories and no glory. Fed up with big-city newspapers missing all but the most sensational crimes, a Florida man is publishing a tabloid listing every local arrest, including those for alleged shoplifting and drunken-driving, as well as murder. The Informer plans to fight crime by filling pages with a blotter-style listing of every suspect _ even though they're innocent until proven guilty. ``This is going to be a deterrent,'' said publisher Ray Aden. ``What is happening is the great majority of people violating our laws are not known _ to their neighbors, their bosses, sometimes even their family.'' ``But nobody wants to get their name in the paper.'' Some daily newspapers already print crime blotter information. There's nothing unlawful about printing arrests from the public record. But civil libertarians and attorneys say the tabloid is treading dangerous legal ground and could trample the rights of the accused. From a small office in this St. Petersburg suburb, Aden and a handful of employees are busy preparing for the Oct. 3 premiere of the twice-monthly, 89-cent publication. Aden, a 70-year-old marketing analyst, has spent nine months and more than $150,000 getting ready to print the paper slated to be about half advertising and half listings of arrests, along with articles such as ``How To Deal With Obscene Phone Calls.'' The area's big dailies report only a few arrests a day, focusing on major murders and drug busts. But each issue of The Informer is designed to bulge up to 48 pages and list hundreds of arrests in St. Petersburg, Clearwater and surrounding Pinellas County communities. All of them list only the standard booking information: name, address, age and arresting charge. ``We're not crime reporting or editorializing _ that's not the concept,'' Aden said. ``We give the community information. ... It probably will evolve into more area crime watches, which will benefit the community.'' And on every page, beneath boldface headers reading ``Domestic Violence'' and ``Shoplifting'' disclaimers in the newspaper's tiniest type read, ``Note: being arrested does not mean the person is guilty.'' ``They have an absolute right to print arrests,'' said Robyn Blumner, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida. ``But I would only hope the public is smart enough to know that arrests by themselves are legally irrelevant.'' Patricia Anderson, a libel attorney whose clients include the St. Petersburg Times, said publishing arrests is fine, but they had better be accurate. ``One wrong first name or one wrong middle initial and you could have a big lawsuit on your hands,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Drop, Dollar Also Slides
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell sharply today, and the dollar declined against the Japanese yen. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, the Tokyo exchange's most closely watched indicator, plunged 557.94 points, or 2.15 percent, closing at 25,420.43 points. A light 360 million shares changed hands. Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said the stock index had risen robustly in the morning along with bond prices, but collapsed in the afternoon on a rumor of a price increase for imported liquefied natural gas. ``If there is the slightest bit of news, traders are poised to begin selling,'' Nomura said. A security dealer with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities added that shares were sold on a rumor that authorities were investigating possible manipulation of paper company shares. The dealer, speaking on condition of anonymity, also said buying enthusiasm declined after a Japanese news report quoted a British newspaper as saying the United States had decided to use military force against Iraq. The price movement of the benchmark No. 119 10-year government bond closely paralleled that of the Nikkei average. After a morning rise, the price fell back at the finish to the same level as Friday's close of 83.07. The yield also matched Friday's close of 8.105 percent. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 143.55 yen, down 0.95 yen from Friday's close of 144.50. It opened at 143.40 yen and stayed in a narrow range between 143.32 yen and 143.70 yen. Exchange dealers attributed the lower opening to cross trading between the yen and principal European currencies, especially the British pound. ``There are no incentives to buy the dollar or to sell it,'' said Toru Kanai, exchange analyst for New Japan Securities. DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Move Tens of Thousands of Civilians Inside Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Cambodian guerrillas have moved at least 60,000 refugees from camps in Thailand back into Cambodia and some have died from disease as a result, Western aid officials said today. Most of the refugees were from camps run by the Communist Khmer Rouge, said a senior aid official, speaking on condition of anonymity. The others were from a camp controlled by the allied guerrilla forces of Prince Norodom Sihanouk. He said the movements began after the September 1989 pullout of Vietnamese troops from Cambodia but most of the refugees had been relocated in the past six months. They were moved apparently to consolidate areas the guerrillas recently ``liberated,'' he said. The relocations continue amid stepped up efforts to end the 11-year Cambodian war. The Vietnamese-installed Phnom Penh government has accepted an invitation to join the guerrillas in talks in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday on an interim government and a new United Nations peace plan. Its premier, Hun Sen, said in a statement broadcast on state radio Sunday he hoped the meeting would ``open the way toward a common solution for the Cambodian problem.'' Hun Sen said he will attend if Sihanouk, the main guerrilla leader, also attends. Otherwise, the government will be represented by Hor Nam Hong, a minister in the prime minister's office in charge of foreign affairs. The Khmer Rouge and the non-communist Sihanouk forces are allied with the Khmer People's National Liberation Front against Hun Sen. The Khmer Rouge relocated millions during its brutal attempt in the 1970s to turn the country into a radical agrarian commune. Hundreds of thousands of people were executed or died of hunger and disease before Vietnam's late 1978 invasion ousted the fanatical regime. The aid official said some refugees fell sick after the latest relocations and tried to return to U.N.-aided camps in Thailand for treatment. But some were prevented or delayed from doing so and had died, mostly from malaria and anemia, he said. He said he could not give a figure. ``You have people who are going voluntarily, people who don't mind, and people who are forced to go back,'' he said. ``Our officers in the field believe the total number to be close to 100,000,'' he said. ``We believe we are facing a tremendous problem.'' International relief officials have seen trucks taking the refugees to border crossing points, said another aid official. ``You can say that they died from a political decision ... that brought them back inside Cambodia without providing them with the minimum of medical care,'' he said. ``As well as medical supplies, we know there are shortages of food, too, although no one is starving yet,'' he said. In the past month, some 1,000 people had returned to the Khmer Rouge camp of Site 8 with malaria, tuberculosis and other diseases rife in the border region, he said. Aid officials stressed they had an incomplete picture of the movements. They said many refugees habitually cross the border and later return to the U.N. camps in Thailand. They also raised the possibility the Thai military had a hand in the movements. There are more than 300,000 refugees in camps along the Thai border run by the guerrillas and given humanitarian aid by the U.N. Border Relief Operation. However, most of those moved by the Khmer Rouge were from their hidden ``satellite camps'' _ closed military and civilian communities near the U.N. camps. The Khmer Rouge and the Thai military do not allow Western aid agencies to work inside these camps but have let many refugees there seek medical assistance outside. The senior relief official said the satellite camps near Site 8, the main U.N.-aided Khmer Rouge camp in Prachinburi province, and those farther south, near the U.N.-aided Site K camp in Trat province, were empty. Other movements were reported from areas along the northern part of the border, near the U.N. camp of O'Trao in Sisaket province. The refugees from the satellite camps near Site 8 had to travel only a few miles to the border, but those in the south had to walk for several days to reach their new homes, where the medical situation was very bad, the official said. He said Sihanouk's authorities moved between 10,000 and 20,000 people from Site B, a U.N.-aided camp along the northern border in Surin province. They were being moved mainly to two new settlements just across the border.

DOC.HEAD: AIM Gathering Brings Indian Cultures Together
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Indians, including some from Mexico and Guatemala, gathered for a long weekend of dance, song and traditional rites at the American Indian Movement's 22nd Annual Gathering of Nations. ``When I was growing up, Indian people were almost taught to be ashamed of their heritage,'' said Clyde Bellecourt, who founded AIM in 1968. ``We try to get our young people away from that John Wayne, wild West, the-only-good-Indian-is-a-dead-Indian mentality.'' The four-day event that ends today stresses fellowship to build understanding between diverse tribes. Attendance should easily surpass last year's mark of about 9,000, Bellecourt said. About 50 tribes were represented at Fort Snelling State Park. ``It's like we make one big city here that can speak to my culture, to his culture, to your culture and everyone's culture,'' said Alfonso Perez, 41, who journeyed from Mexico City. ``We come with peace and dignity to share our culture with everybody.'' ``I'm here because I'm culturally awake and I want to stay that way,'' said Mitch Walking Elk, 39, of Tahlequah, Okla. ``It's fun and it's serious. It's rejuvenating.'' Julio Revolorio, 32, of Guatemala City said he was following his ancestors' footsteps by traversing a continent that once had no national boundaries. All modern Indian people should take pride in the accomplishments of ancient civilizations throughout the Americas, he said ``The biggest thing is to thank the creator,'' said Revolorio, who participated in a traditional peace pipe ceremony. Bellecourt said the political side of the event includes discussions of such issues as environmental protection, desecration of Indian burial grounds and fishing rights. On Sunday, there was an open discussion of the conflict in Oka, Quebec, between Mohawks and the government. AIM gained notoriety in 1972 when it seized the Bureau of Indian Affairs building in Washington, D.C. In 1973, AIM activists rioted in front of the courthouse in Custer, S.D. Also in 1973, the 71-day occupation at Wounded Knee on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota left two Indians dead and a federal marshall paralyzed.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to CORRECT cycle designator.
Execution Becomes Polical Issue For Arkansas Governor
DOC.TEXT: The scheduled execution of a man convicted in the rape and murder of a nurse has taken on political overtones for Gov. Bill Clinton, who is seeking a fifth term this fall. Civil rights groups want Clinton to delay the execution of Barry Lee Fairchild, a black man who contends he was coerced into confessing. They warn the Democratic governor could lose his traditionally strong support in the black community if Fairchild dies as scheduled Wednesday. ``There is too much uncertainty in this case for an execution to take place,'' the Rev. Ellihue Gaylord, president of the state National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, said at a recent news conference. Clinton, 44, has nurtured a zealous anti-crime reputation the past few years, supporting prison boot camps and the state's first drug czar in a 1989 legislative package. ``He's in a tough spot no matter which way he turns,'' said Mahlon Martin, one of several black appointees to Clinton's Cabinet. Martin left the administration last year. The execution of Fairchild, 36, would be the third in Arkansas this year. Cop-killer John Edward Swindler and mass murderer R. Gene Simmons were white. Swindler was the first Arkansas inmate executed since 1964. Fairchild was convicted in the 1983 rape and murder Marjorie Mason, 22, a Little Rock Air Force Base nurse. A key for prosecutors was two videotapes in which Fairchild unemotionally detailed the abduction and rape of Ms. Mason. His head is bandaged in the videotapes. The head wound was received during the arrest and he also was bitten by a police dog, police said. On appeal, Fairchild said he was beaten by police and confessed to a crime he didn't commit. U.S. District Judge G. Thomas Eisele dismissed the claims Wednesday. He said nobody testified that they saw Fairchild being beaten. The FBI is investigating alleged inmate abuse while U.S. Rep. Tommy Robinson, R-Ark., was Pulaski County sheriff from 1980 to 1984. Little Rock is in Pulaski County. But the judge said he is convinced the matter doesn't pertain to Fairchild. Eisele also rejected arguments that Fairchild's limited mental capacity could cause a second jury to believe Fairchild was coerced. He said the inmate ``wasn't so retarded that he confessed to a murder he did not commit.'' Opponents of the execution want Clinton to issue a reprieve until the FBI inquiry is complete. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis will hear an appeal Tuesday. That court and the Supreme Court have turned Fairchild away twice. ``I'm going to try to depoliticize this as much as possible, read the facts of the case against the law and, hopefully, make the right decision,'' Clinton said Thursday. The case gained an added political dimension when the NAACP, Amnesty International and the American Civil Liberties Union held a news conference Thursday to pressure Clinton. Keith Jennings, deputy director of Amnesty International's southern region at Atlanta, said national black leaders will contact Clinton to ``let you know that should you have national aspirations, the African community won't forget.'' Clinton toyed with the idea of running for president in 1988. The governor may be worried about more than the black vote. ``There's another political issue here that makes it different,'' said Martin, now president of the Winthrop Rockefeller Foundation. ``We've had two executions this year and those were white people. ``Unless the white community agrees there are unique matters in this case and differences _ which I think there are _ I think they may see a granting of a stay as strictly a racial issue.'' Martin said that perception could hurt Clinton in the November election. Arkansas' black population is about 16 percent, and Clinton is already in trouble with some rural white voters who blame him for the closing of their small school districts. Clinton appears willing to leave the matter in the courts' hands. ``My leanings are to give great weight to the decisions of the federal district court,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Cricizes Greed, Powerseekers For Failure of Development
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II decried today the failure of development in Africa, blaming a thirst for power and profit for plunging the continent into poverty and injustice. ``How many young people in Africa are deeply affected by the lack of hope that overshadows their future,'' the pope said on the third day of a 10-day African tour. John Paul flew from the country's commercial capital, the port city of Dar es Salaam, 380 miles to southwestern Songea to celebrate Mass. The pope was greeted by traditional dancers and music, people singing hymns and ululating. About 25,000 people attended the service, which was held in an open field in the African savannah. ``Certainly it is not easy for people, especially young people, to be self-giving and generous when they see around them so much poverty and suffering, so many instances of neglect and injustice,'' he said in his homily. John Paul said the hopes of many Third World countries have been dashed by hunger, malnutrition, crime and corruption. He compared the situation to the chaos discribed in the Book of Genesis _ the world was a ``formless void and there was darkness over the deep.'' But he urged Africans to maintain hope. ``Many problems of development, no matter how overpowering, can be solved if there is a new attitude diametrically opposed to a selfish desire for profit and the thirst for power.'' The pope was to fly to northwestern Mwanza, on the shores of Lake Victoria, later in the day to bless 100 patients at an Episcopal-run hospital, make a speech and dine with the archbishop, Monsignor Anthony Mayala. On Sunday, the pontiff called for cooperation and brotherhood between Christianity and Islam in Africa, where the world's two largest religions have occasionally clashed in competition for converts. The pope hailed good relations between the two faiths in this largely Moslem country where Catholics are only 21 percent of the population of about 24 million. The Moslem community contributed financially to the pope's visit, according to Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro. The nation's Moslem president, Ali Hassan Mwinyi, attended an open-air Mass Sunday morning. He also provided a small plane for the pope to travel in from Dar es Salaam to Mwanza. John Paul winds up the Tanzania leg of his seventh trip to Africa on Wednesday. He will go on to Burundi, Rwanda and Ivory Coast, where he ends the trip Sept. 10 with the consecration of a massive basilica.
