DOC.HEAD: Emigration Jumps Almost 50 Percent As Fears Of China Loom
DOC.TEXT: Emigration from Hong Kong will leap almost 50 percent this year because of fears of Communist China's takeover in 1997, the British colonial government announced today. The government said 62,000 people are expected to leave the territory in 1990, compared to 42,000 last year, an increase of 47.6 percent. Mike Rowse, head of a government task force on emigration, predicted about 60,000 people a year _ or 1,150 people a week _ would leave the colony in 1991 and 1992. ``But after that you're getting into crystal ball gazing,'' he said. Some analysts say emigration from Hong Kong will skyrocket after 1992, five years before China resumes control of the colony and the year China's controversial Daya Bay nuclear power plant is scheduled to come on stream 30 miles north of Hong Kong. Reports of numerous construction problems have dogged the plant, causing worries about its safety. Rowse said most of the people leaving are members of Hong Kong's vibrant, well-educated middle class, who have turned this 410-square-mile patch of islands and peninsula on the southern Chinese coast into an economic powerhouse. Their departure has sparked fears of economic and social problems in Hong Kong once China resumes control of the territory in 1997. Interest in emigration has increased since China cracked down on a movement for freedom in Beijing in June 1989. The crackdown convinced many in the territory that China could easily break its promise to maintain the colony's freewheeling economic and social system for 50 years. London's refusal to give most of its Hong Kong colonial subjects the right to live in Britain also played a role in encouraging emigration. The British government has recently approved a package that will give about 225,000 of Hong Kong's 5.7 million people the right of abode in Britain. Only certain individuals, such as senior civil servants, top businessmen, educators and highly-skilled workers, qualify. Rowse said applications for the package would begin to be acted on in November and that the first passports under the plan would be issued by spring. But, he said, the government has no way to predict whether people who receive the passports will stay, as the plan intends, or leave immediately for Britain. Horatio Cheung, an emigration specialist who has criticized Hong Kong in the past for softpedaling the emigration problem, said he thought the government's predictions were accurate this year. ``But it's significant that they didn't look past 1992,'' he said. ``That's when I believe you'll see a mass exodus.'' So far, the most popular destination has been Canada. Australia will probably surpass the United States this year for the second slot. But that lineup soon could change. A bill being debated by the U.S. Congress would raise Hong Kong's immigration quota to America from 5,000 to 20,000 people.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: in 4th graf, `Mrs. Marcos ... ', changes `courses' to `choruses.' ^Former Philippine First Lady Returns to Hawaii
DOC.TEXT: A triumphant Imelda Marcos hugged friends and supporters and kissed children as she returned to her home-in-exile to mark her late husband's birthday. The former Philippine first lady, clad in her customary black dress and draped with flower leis, also took time Sunday to praise U.S. courts after her arrival at Honolulu International Airport. ``The system works. God bless America,'' said Mrs. Marcos, cleared in June of federal racketeering charges. More than 100 supporters waved U.S. and Philippine flags and serenaded Mrs. Marcos with choruses of ``God Bless America,'' ``The Mabuhay (long life) Song,'' and ``We Are Filipinos.'' Mrs. Marcos left Hawaii in March to face trial in a New York City federal court on fraud and racketeering charges alleging she helped steal millions of dollars from her homeland to buy art and real estate in the United States. A jury acquitted Mrs. Marcos and her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi. Mrs. Marcos and her husband, Ferdinand, fled the Philippines in February 1986 during a civilian-military revolt that propelled Corazon Aquino to the presidency. Ferdinand Marcos died Sept. 28, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Hunters Find Dead Animals and Indications of Ritual Sacrifice
DOC.TEXT: Bags containing decapitated animals and indications of ritual animal sacrifice were discovered by hunters in Angeles National Forest, authorities said. The hunters found the bags Saturday near a U.S. Forest Service station on Angeles Crest Highway, said Los Angeles County sheriff's Sgt. Dan Cox. ``The animals were possibly used in a spiritual ritual. There's no further information or suspects,'' he said. Authorities said one bag held a black rooster wrapped in a black sheet bearing a pentagram, coconut shells, a handmade doll and candles. A sheep and two roosters, all decapitated, were in a second bag. A third contained a rooster and a goat, both decapitated. The roosters' heads were in the bags but the goat and sheep heads were missing. Deputies filed a cruelty-to-animals report and gave the case to the county's animal control board.

DOC.HEAD: Water Guns Mark Weekend Festivities
DOC.TEXT: Young people roamed the streets with water guns this Labor Day weekend and police looked the other way when large crowds gathered around boom boxes _ a far cry from last year's rioting. Police spokesman Lew Thurston said 86 people had been charged with misdemeanor offenses along the oceanfront as of 5 p.m. Sunday. Last year, 158 people were arrested and taken into custody and 614 people were issued summonses for misdemeanors following two nights of rioting and looting. City officials, who estimated the 1989 crowd at more than 100,000, put this year's crowd at 29,000. Troy Hazell and nine friends were among the water gun brandishers, gathering at an oceanfront intersection Sunday night. ``People who don't have water guns seem to get mad but people with water guns don't mind. They shoot us back,'' he said. Hazell, 21, of Queens, N.Y., chose his targets carefully. ``We're having fun,'' he said. ``I met about 27 girls. I got 27 numbers.'' But some people said the party atmosphere was lacking for what is usually the biggest holiday of the summer. Visitors complained about streets closed to cars and the strong police presence. Cynthia Cramer, 25, of Washington, D.C., said people were being harrassed when she arrived with friends Saturday night. ``We saw police make a young guy walk three straight lines, then another one holding his foot,'' Ms. Cramer said. ``I feel like I'm back in the '60s.''

DOC.HEAD: Saudis to Boost Oil Output to 7.6 Million Barrels, Survey Says
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Saudi Arabia will boost its daily oil production by 2.27 million barrels this month to make up for the loss of Iraqi and Kuwaiti output, the Middle East Economic survey reported today. In addition, the United Arab Emirates will boost output from fields in Abu Dhabi by about 450,000 barrels a day, the respected Nicosia-based oil industry newsletter said. Before Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, Iraq's President Saddam Hussein warned that he would retaliate for the violation of OPEC quotas by Kuwait and the U.A.E. The extra oil on markets was driving down crude prices. A United Nations economic embargo imposed on Iraq four days after the invasion stopped Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil exports, slashing available OPEC production by 4 million barrels a day and driving up prices. The new increase in daily output follows an agreement by Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Vienna on Aug. 29 to suspend quota restrictions and allow production to rise toward 22.5 million barrels a day. That was the production level set in Geneva by the oil cartel on July 27, six days before Iraq invaded Kuwait. The move to boost oil production by Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates will boost Saudi output to 7.65 million barrels daily, and the Emirates' to about 2 million barrels a day. The newsletter estimates that OPEC production will reach 22.1 million barrels a day this month and rise to 23.1 million barrels daily by year's end. The Vienna agreement was aimed at restoring market stability and salvaging OPEC's credibility in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis. The accord was seen as a major political victory for Saudi Arabia, which had lobbied for a rapid production boost against opposition from other OPEC members, notably Iran. The kingdom had threatened to boost production unilaterally if necessary. The economic survey said Saudi Arabia will give priority to supplying ``developing countries whose oil supplies have been affected by the Iraq-Kuwait cut-off.'' These include Turkey, Brazil, the Philippines, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Taiwan and South Korea. Next on the list are the Japanese, the newsletter said. In last priority are increases for U.S. and European buyers, it said. ``At the same time, Saudi Arabia is also to supply crude on a commercial basis to two OPEC countries hit by the crisis,'' the survey reported. The Kuwait Petroleum Co. ``will be receiving 150,000 barrels a day of Saudi crude in September, rising to 220,000 barrels a day in October,'' it said. ``Indonesia will be receiving Saudi crude to make up for a 30,000 barrel-a-day supply contract it had with Iraq,'' the newsletter reported. The survey said 7.5 million barrels a day of the increased Saudi production will come from Aramco fields. That is roughly the oil giant's sustainable capacity, although it has a short-term surge capacity of up to 8.5 million barrels a day. The rest of Saudi Arabia's output will come from its half of the so-called ``neutral zone,'' which it shares with Kuwait. The land fields in the zone, whose production installations are on the Kuwaiti side of the border, have been closed since Aug. 2. But the offshore fields, which lie on the Saudi Arabian side, remain in operation. All the United Arab Emirates' increase will come from Abu Dhabi, the federation's main producer. Dubai, its other producer, will maintain its current output of 400,000 barrels a day, the newsletter said. ``Whether Abu Dhabi production goes even higher in the fourth quarter ... will no doubt depend mainly on technical oilfield factors,'' the newsletter noted. Venezuelan production is also expected to rise this month by 350,000 barrels a day, increasing another 150,000 barrels daily in November to a total of 500,000 barrels a day. Newsletter editor Ian Seymour said the Vienna accord ``stands a good chance of defusing the oil supply crisis in its present form _ that is to say, unless anything worse happens in the Middle East arena.''

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Gustav No Longer Tropical, Heading Towards Open Atlantic
DOC.TEXT: Tropical Storm Gustav sped out into open waters this morning, churning away from Canada's Maritime provinces with top sustained winds near 65 mph, forecasters said. Gustav could make its way across the Atlantic and pose a storm threat later in the week to western Europe, said hurricane specialist Bob Case of the National Hurricane Center in suburban Coral Gables. At 6 a.m. EDT, Gustav was centered near 51.0 north latitude and 40.5 west longitude, or about 650 miles northeast of Cape Race, Newfoundland, according to the hurricane center. Gustav was moving northeast at near 35 mph with storm force winds extending up to 230 miles from its center. The storm was expected to continue on the same heading with little change in strength for the next 24 hours, Case said. Gustav dropped below hurricane-force winds of 74 mph on Sunday, a day after the system boasted 100 mph winds, forecasters said. The Atlantic hurricane season lasts from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: Annual Muscular Dystrophy Telethon Starts On New Stage
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto LA6 of Sept. 2
DOC.TEXT: The Jerry Lewis Labor Day Telethon turned 25 this year, shifting from Las Vegas to a revolving Hollywood stage and retaining a very familiar host. Lewis kicked off the 21{-hour fund-raiser Sunday night for the Muscular Dystrophy Association with a dedication to the late Sammy Davis Jr., his voice breaking with emotion as he recalled the entertainer's recent death. Lewis' role is somewhat smaller for this year's show, which he didn't produce. That job went to veteran television producer George Schlatter. The comedian will share time as host with ``Entertainment Tonight's'' Leeza Gibbons and ``Tonight Show'' emcee Ed McMahon. There also were to be frequent appearances by talk show host Sally Jessy Raphael, comedian Norm Crosby and entertainer Ben Vereen. The telethon began in 1966 in New York City and was moved in 1973 to Las Vegas, where Lewis raised more than $500 million. Last year's show tallied a record $42.2 million to fight 40 neuromuscular diseases that kill and cripple thousand of people annually, most of them young people. The Star Search Theater on Sunset Boulevard, where McMahon presents a glitzy talent show, was the home base for this year's syndicated telethon, which was to be seen on 200 stations nationwide.

DOC.HEAD: Americans Home from Gulf Say Comrades Hungry, Thirsty and Tired
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 3-5 bgng ``The situation... to UPDATE with hostage comments; 5th graf pvs bgng ``I wasn't... edited for transition; ^By W. DALE NELSON
DOC.TEXT: Americans freed from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, after weeks as virtual prisoners of Iraqi soldiers outside the walls, say the comrades they left behind face mounting hunger, thirst and weariness. As the 47 Americans arrived Sunday, the few who met with reporters painted a grim picture of life inside the eight-block compound just across a six-lane highway from a Persian Gulf beach. ``The situation is deteriorating daily,'' former hostage Lloyd Culbertson, 76, said today. He estimated that 20 to 25 Americans remain at the embassy. ``The food is spoiling. There is no electricity,'' Culbertson said on CBS ``This Morning.'' ``We have no means of communicating with other people. Our ambassador is not allowed to talk with other ambassador or to American citizens. He can't leave the compound.'' ``These situations also prevail at the Canadian Embassy and the Japanese Embassy and possibly others,'' he said. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed al-Mashat, who met the former hostages at Washington-Dulles International Airport on Sunday, told them, ``I come to welcome our guests here.'' His remarks got a cold shoulder. ``I wasn't a guest,'' said the white-bearded Culbertson, of El Paso, Texas. ``I damned near starved to death.'' Bonnie Anderton of Denver said, ``It is the only hotel I have ever been a guest in that I don't intend to leave a tip. We were sleeping on the floor, there was no water and no power and we were being eaten alive by bugs.'' Mrs. Anderton was accompanied by her daughter, Jennifer, 10, who nervously twirled a red baseball cap as her mother spoke. Jennifer's father, Richard Anderton, an engineer, remained behind in the embassy, where the family took refuge the day after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Iraqi officials cut off power and water to the embassy after Washington refused a demand to close it. Jesse Jackson, the American civil rights leader who arranged for more than 100 foreigners to leave Baghdad and Kuwait City on Saturday, urged the Iraqis to restore water and power, saying that otherwise he did not believe the embassy could hold out more than a few days. ``He doesn't know us,'' said Mrs. Anderton. ``We'll make it. I think they'll stay as long as they have to.'' D. Michael Cheers, a freelance photojournalist who accompanied Jackson, said the Americans in the embassy were boiling water from the swimming pool for drinking and breaking up furniture to burn in wood stoves. Many of the hostages were greeted in their hometowns by joyful relatives. ``Long live America!'' 16-year-old Sayyeda Mirza's father, Masood, said after he, his daughter and his wife arrived at New York City's La Guardia Airport on the last leg of their journey to their Manhasset Hills, N.Y., home. Mirza said that when he learned he was being released, ``I was happy. I was crying. ``And the next moment I thought, `What about the others?' '' Prabhavathi Murikpudi, 40, wept with joy when she and her 10-year-old daughter, Sylaja, were met at Chicago's O'Hare International Airport by her husband, whose monthlong effort to gain their release included a videotaped plea sent to Saddam. Sylaja celebrated her 10th birthday while in Iraq. ``Some ladies mentioned (her birthday) to the cook and they arranged a big celebration,'' including champagne, music, gifts and a candlelight dinner, she said. ``We were really treated very well, physically,'' Mrs. Mirza told television station WCBS-TV in an interview at the family's Manhasset Hills home. Others disagreed. A U.S. official said 24 women, 11 men and 12 children arrived Sunday but declined to identify them, citing privacy laws. About a third of the women were reported to be pregnant. The State Department said about 1,000 Americans remain in Kuwait, and about 500 are in Iraq. Among the men was Edward Johnson, 62, a vice president in the St. Louis office of Fasco Industries, which makes electric motors. ``We don't want to leave the embassy,'' he said. ``It's American ground.'' Cheers said the men who were allowed to return after Iraqi President Saddam Hussein announced he would free women and children were chosen because of medical problems. Johnson, a diabetic, said he took refuge at the embassy Aug. 17 on the advice of an embassy official. Culbertson, who taught electronics to the Kuwaiti military, had been in the embassy since Aug. 10. Of the Americans aboard the green Iraqi jumbo jet who had been held in Baghdad, only one spoke to reporters. She gave a markedly different picture of her captivity than those from Kuwait City. ``I have had an enjoyable time,'' said Beth Krekeler of St. Louis, a former English teacher in Baghdad. ``I have had a cross-cultural experience.'' Mrs. Krekeler, who spoke to reporters while cuddling her two-year-old cat, Minutiae, also said she did not object to the Iraqi policy of ferrying hostages to potential bombing targets to serve as human shields. ``I think it is a very noble thing to be there, to stop the bombing of cities and the bombing of people,'' she said. Culbertson criticized President Bush for vacationing during the crisis and said, ``If it were not for the grace of God and Jesse Jackson, we would not be here. The State Department has not lifted a hand for us.'' Asked if the people left behind feared for their lives, Culbertson said, ``Yes, they certainly do.'' Mrs. Anderton said Iraqi troops often fired shots near the U.S. Embassy compound during the day. Jackson said at the airport, ``Now that the military has played its role, diplomacy must work. If preconditions make talks impossible, war is inevitable.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Jewel Robberies in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Three robbers, firing automatic weapons, blasted their way through Hong Kong's main tourist center today and escaped with about $1 million worth of jewelry, police said. The robbery was one of two major jewelry heists today in the swank Central District, home of the famed Star Ferry terminal. Police, pointing to a trail of blood leading into a subway entrance, said they believed one of the robbers was shot in the firefight with officers. Authorities said three men, two armed with automatic weapons and another with ``a grenade-like object'' burst into a watch shop on Queen's Road late this morning. While one man stood guard, his colleagues snatched about 85 expensive watches along with jewelry and rings. A police sergeant arrived at the scene. The robbers shot at him seven times while the officer fired three times, police said. Clutching their bag of goods, the thieves fled down alleyways that wind through the business district, filled with high-rises and expensive retail shops, police said. Police and the robbers exchanged fire once more before the threesome ducked into a subway entrance and disappeared. Also today, a band of robbers smashed into a jewelry store on another main commercial thoroughfare, Nathan Road, snatching about $500,000 worth of gold, police said. They also escaped.

DOC.HEAD: Former KGB General Wins Seat in Soviet Parliament
DOC.TEXT: A former KGB general who was dismissed after criticizing his employers has been elected to the Soviet Parliament, Tass reported today. Oleg Kalugin received a majority of votes cast Sunday in a run-off election for a seat in the Congress of People's Deputies, the official news agency said. The Election Commission chairman in the southern Russian province of Krasnodar, where the vote took place, would not confirm or deny the report. Vladislav Busheyev said he would not comment until after the commission met later today to approve the vote count. Tass did not say how many ballots were cast, or how many people voted for Kalugin compared to his opponent, Nikolai Gorovoi, an agricultural official. Kalugin's election campaign focused on his allegations that the KGB continues to tap telephones, infiltrate trade unions and the Russian Orthodox Church and play dirty tricks abroad, despite a campaign to shed its image as an instrument of purges and repression. Kalugin was dismissed and stripped of his rank after going public with his accusations in June. The Soviet prosecutor has been investigating him since July 17 under a law against divulging state secrets, but no formal charges have been brought brought against him. As an elected lawmaker, Kalugin cannot now be prosecuted on criminal charges without the agreement of the Soviet legislature. The 55-year-old former major general was a KGB agent in the United States from 1958 to 1970, first while working as a Radio Moscow correspondent and later as a first secretary in the Soviet Embassy in Washington. The KGB and its supporters tried to discredit Kalugin before an initial vote was held last month in Krasnodar, an agricultural region along the Black Sea 750 miles south of Moscow. Kalugin outpolled 20 other candidates but did not win the required majority. On Saturday, the KGB accused him of slander for saying that two defectors had once worked as assistants to KGB Chairman Vladimir Kryuchkov and his deputy chairman, Viktor Grushko. Kalugin made the allegations Friday night on the popular television program ``Viewpoint.'' The KGB called it ``another slanderous allegation by Oleg Kalugin.'' In a statement released by Tass, the KGB also said ``it is impossible to bypass the fact that many statements by Kalugin betray striking affinity to numerous statements'' by one of the defectors. The KGB said neither Kryuchkov nor Grushko have ever had assistants who betrayed their country. Krasnodar's seat in the national Congress, which meets twice a year, was vacated by Ivan Polozkov, who left to become the Communist Party chief of the Russian federation, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics.

DOC.HEAD: Shot Fired in Mohawk Indian Standoff
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with shot fired, both sides deny firing. Pick up 2nd graf pvs, `On Sunday...' Minor editing to trim.
DOC.TEXT: A shot was fired this morning as soldiers moved closer to the last area under control of armed Mohawk warriors. There was no immediate indication which side fired the shot, but it did not appear anyone was hit. Both Mohawk and army spokesmen denied firing. The incident took place as a 2-month-old standoff wore on today, with troops surrounding about 30 Mohawk Indian militants who refused to surrender and retreated to a drug and alcohol detoxification center on Indian land. On Sunday, about 350 soliders demolished the last barricades blocking access to the Kanesatake Indian reservation, and seized control of most of it. Mohawks were confined to a small wooded area around the center. Late Sunday, the militants issued a statement saying the army had given them an ultimatum to surrender by 8 a.m. EDT today or face attack. But an army spokesman, Maj. Jean-Paul Macdonald, said that was ``absolutely wrong.'' ``The Canadian Forces are not in the business of giving ultimatums in such sensitive situations,'' Macdonald said. Native representatives, including three chiefs from the Six Nations Iroquois Confederacy, met late into the night at the center to discuss ways to end the standoff without violence. The Indians had errected the barricades at Kanesatake and another Mohawk community, Kahnawake, in a dispute over plans by Oka town officials to expand a golf course onto what they claim is tribal land. The barriers had blocked traffic on an Oka highway and, about 20 miles away, on a bridge connecting Montreal to southern suburbs. On Sunday, the Warriors, a militant Mohawk organization, periodically came out from the trees and stood face-to-face with soldiers at Oka. On one occasion, a Warrior approached a soldier, stood chest-to-chest with him and stared into his eyes as a group of reporters watched. Finally, he let out a war whoop, turned and walked away. ``I want to see their face before I kill them,'' the Warrior said. The Mohawks fortified their positions by using a front-end loader to pile earth on a road near the two-story detoxification center in the woods. Some crouched behind trees in wait for the army. When asked whether the Warriors were prepared to shoot it out with the army, one militant said ``definitely.'' ``This is it. We can't be pushed any further,'' he said. However, no fighting broke out between the soldiers and Indians Sunday. Military helicopters flew overhead and about 80 armored vehicles were in the area, the army said. Mohawk spokesman Ellen Gabriel said the Indians are ``pretty squeezed in right now. There's no way out really.'' Last week, Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa ordered the army to dismantle the barricades. The army moved into the Kanesatake Mohawk settlement in Oka, 18 miles west of Montreal, Saturday afternoon after factional fighting broke out between moderate and militant Mohawks. Two Indians were hurt before the army moved in. When the soldiers pushed forward, only one shot was fired by a Mohawk on Saturday, said army commander Lt. Col. Pierre Daigle. There were no casualties. The dispute over the golf course expansion was solved when the federal government purchased the land and said it would give it to the Indians. But the Mohawks seized the situation to publicize a much wider range of grievances, including demands for sovereignty, and their campaign caused numerous brief sympathy blockades across Canada. One week ago, provincial authorities gave the military the go-ahead to end the armed standoff that began July 11 when the Quebec provincial police attempted to storm the Mohawk barricade at Oka. One officer was killed in that assault, but it is still not clear by whose gunfire.

DOC.HEAD: Jackson Urges Diplomatic Solution To Gulf Crisis
With Gulf-Americans Home Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Any diplomatic solution to the Persian Gulf crisis must regain Kuwaiti sovereignty, assure Saudi Arabian security and ``assure the integrity of Iraq,'' the Rev. Jesse Jackson said today. Jackson returned from Iraq on Sunday with 47 freed American hostages after he met for six hours with Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. The civil rights leader and former Democratic presidential aspirant urged President Bush to pursue a diplomatic solution to reverse Iraq's takeover of Kuwait and cautioned against relying solely on military pressure. ``Just as our generals are in Saudi Arabia with a military presence, our politicians should be as evident in seeking diplomatic solutions,'' he said on NBC-TV's ``Today.'' Jackson, who met with Jordan's Crown Prince Hassan as well as the Iraqi president, said a diplomatic solution must ``regain the sovereignty of Kuwait, assure the security of Saudi Arabia and assure the integrity of Iraq.'' He called for an end to the ``drum-beating hostile rhetoric.'' Jackson, in an interview on ABC-TV's ``Good Morning America,'' said he challenged Saddam on his takeover of Kuwait, saying the annexation and his threats against Saudi Arabia were errors. If war breaks out over the crisis, Jackson said, innocent people will be killed and oil wells destroyed. Asked to respond to criticism that he was exploiting the hostages' plight for his own political gains, he said, ``Suffice it to say, blessed are the peacemakers, even when they are beguiled.'' Jackson said he rejects the idea that Saddam's annexation of Kuwait is the only problem in the crisis and that only a military solution will work to resolve it. Jackson went to the Middle East with a journalistic team and said he plans a series of broadcast reports on the crisis.

DOC.HEAD: U.N. Chief Disappointed by Talks; Iraq Would Rather `Eat Mud' Than Give In
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Perez de Cuellar comment on Kuwait embassies, EC meeting planned, Hurd in Yemen, 50 said hurt in Bangladesh demonstration, more on freed Americans. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5,8,9
DOC.TEXT: U.N. chief Javier Perez de Cuellar says he's deeply disappointed by Iraq's intransigence in two days of talks, and Baghdad is starting to ration food and promising that Iraqis will ``eat mud'' before yielding to foreign pressure. Perez de Cuellar said Sunday that diplomatic efforts to resolve the month-old standoff between Iraq and U.S.-led multinational forces in the Persian Gulf should now be turned to the weekend superpower summit in Finland. The first beneficiaries of tentative moves toward diplomacy in the crisis returned to freedom Sunday in the first major airlift of Western captives from Iraq. Some had been held at strategic Iraqi sites to deter any U.S. attack. Despite attempts to find a peaceful solution to the crisis Iraq's Saddam Hussein precipitated by having his troops seize oil-rich Kuwait on Aug. 2, the Baghdad government seemed to be settling in. It appeared intent on waiting out the roughly 100,000 American troops now positioned in Saudi Arabia and on U.S. ships in the region. But the round-the-clock deployment was continuing. Five U.S. amphibious-warfare ships transited the Suez Canal today en route to the gulf region to join the multinational armada. In order to withstand a U.N.-imposed economic embargo, Iraq announced Sunday that it would begin rationing food. There have been reports of food shortages in Iraq, although Iraqi government spokesman Naji al-Hadithi has denied those claims. It was not immediately clear when the rationing would begin. Some sources said it was to have begun over the weekend, but a Baghdad shopkeeper said he was told the plan would take effect on Wednesday. ``We have a war-tested society. We have a war-tested economy. So even if we eat mud, we will resist pressure and not kneel down to any foreign power,'' al-Hadithi told a news conference. Iraq's 8-year-war with Iran ended in 1988. Iraq appeared in no hurry to compromise on its Aug. 6 annexation of Kuwait, or on its policy of holding thousands of Westerners as hostages. After seven hours of meetings with Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz in Jordan, Perez de Cuellar said he was ``deeply disappointed'' because he had expected ``a certain flexibility'' on the part of Iraq. ``What Iraq wants is to stay in Kuwait, which is unacceptable to the international community, to the U.N. Security Council and to its secretary-general,'' Perez de Cuellar told reporters Sunday in Paris after arriving from Amman, Jordan. Perez de Cuellar's negotiations were the only direct talks held with the Iraqi leadership since the early days of the crisis. The U.N. chief said he still held out hope that Iraq would become more accommodating. ``I am available,'' he said. ``If, at any given time, they wish to modify their position, I will be delighted to listen to them.'' The only major public talks on the Persian Gulf crisis now scheduled are the Helsinki summit on Sunday between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. The European Commission announced today that the foreign ministers of the 12 European Community nations will meet in Rome on Friday to discuss the crisis in the gulf. It will be their second such meeting since the invasion. The superpower summit in Helsinki does not raise many hopes for a speedy resolution. ``We have to settle down for a long haul, which will require a good deal of steady determination on the part of all concerned,'' said British Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd. Hurd was in Yemen today, the fourth stop in a tour of the gulf region. Yemen remains a weak link in the embargo, and Yemenis have been demonstrating in the streets to display support for Saddam. In Bangladesh, at least 50 people, including six policemen, were reported hurt today in a demonstration protesting the dispatch of Bangladesh troops to the gulf, United News of Bangladesh reported. In Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, on Sunday, House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt said a lengthy U.S. military presence in Saudi Arabia might strain the American public's patience but that time will be a worse enemy for Saddam. ``There's a patience problem on the Iraqi side as well,'' said Gephardt, D-Mo., who led a congressional delegation in a visit to U.S. troops. ``It's the world against him _ it's not the world against us.'' But the standoff was taking its toll on the skeleton staffs of embassies in Kuwait that are resisting Iraqi orders to close. At the U.S. mission, diplomats were breaking up furniture for firewood and boiling water from the swimming pool to drink, said a photographer accompanying the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The U.S. Embassy, like many other missions in Kuwait, has had its power and water cut by the Iraqis for defying the closure order. The photographer, freelancer D. Michael Cheers, traveled to Kuwait and Baghdad with Jackson, who helped secure the release of some American captives. Perez de Cuellar indicated that the Iraqi foreign minister gave some indication of possible movement on the issue of foreign embassies in Kuwait. ``Tariq Aziz promised me to do something, to display some flexibility ... to avoid diplomats' expulsion,'' he said on French television. But he added: ``I regarded it as unlikely.'' Former hostage Lloyd Culbertson, 76, who had been among those trapped in the U.S. Embassy compound in Kuwait, said today the situation at the mission is ``deteriorating daily.'' ``The food is spoiling. There is no electricity,'' Culbertson said on CBS ``This Morning.'' ``We have no means of communicating with other people. Our ambassador is not allowed to talk with other ambassador or to American citizens. He can't leave the compound.'' A diplomatic source in Brussels said on Sunday that the East German ambassador to Kuwait was picked up by Iraqi authorities and taken to Baghdad. He had ventured out of his embassy to visit the West German mission. Jackson accompanied 300 Westerners _ mostly women and children _ on an Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 plane that carried them out of Iraq and stopped in Paris, London and Washington. The plane left Baghdad on Saturday along with two other planeloads of foreigners. For most of those freed, joy upon reaching safety was muted by fears for husbands and fathers left behind. Bonnie Anderton of Denver got out with her daughter Jennifer, 10, but Jennifer's father, Richard, remained behind. They were among 47 weary Americans arriving at Dulles International Airport outside Washington earlier Sunday. At Tokyo's international airport, 68 Japanese women and children arriving on a Japan Air Lines flight were greeted by tearful relatives and friends. A Lufthansa plane with 250 women and 61 children on board _ including 60 Americans and 71 Germans _ landed early Sunday in Frankfurt, West Germany. The airlifts came after Saddam, in what he called a humanitarian gesture, announced last week that women and children among the foreign captives would be allowed to leave Iraq. However, the departure of others was apparently delayed Sunday as Iraq withheld landing clearance for two special flights from Britain and France. Western governments have demanded the release of all the hostages, and denounced Iraq's footdragging in freeing the women and children as promised.

DOC.HEAD: Son Stabbed to Death in NYC Subway After Robbers Slug His Mother
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to recast lead; add what was stolen, other detail; UPDATE with three sted two young men being questioned.
DOC.TEXT: A young tourist from Utah was fatally stabbed on a subway station platform after he intervened when muggers robbed his father and punched his mother, police said. Brian Watkins, 22, of Provo, Utah, was in New York with his family for the U.S. Open tennis tournament on Sunday when he was attacked on a midtown subway platform, Transit Police spokesman Sgt. Bob Valentino said. Watkins, along with his father, mother, 26-year-old brother and his wife, ventured into the subway station at 53rd Street and Seventh Avenue for a two-stop ride to a station near the Tavern on the Green restaurant in Central Park. As the family waited on the northbound platform about 10:20 p.m., five young men, described as being between the ages of 16 and 20, approached. One brandished a knife, sliced open the father's pants and took a money clip containing about $200 and some credit cards, Valentino said. ``During the robbery, one of the assailants punched the mother in the face and the two sons interceded,'' Valentino said. The victim was stabbed during the fight. The robbers fled, Valentino said. Three men were questioned early today, but no immediate arrests were made, police said. Watkins was the 18th homicide victim in the New York subway system this year, Valentino said. The system moves more than 3 million riders a day.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Gears Up for Gorbachev Meeting As Maine Vacation Ends
DOC.NOTE: EDS: INSERTS new grafs 4-5 bgng, Meanwhile, administration... to UPDATE with Bush trip details; Bush leaves Maine 4:25 p.m. EST
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is returning to Washington for a hectic few days of preparation before his third summit meeting with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. As aides scrambled to work out logistics and prepare an agenda for the hastily called summit, Bush today was concluding a three-week vacation in Maine that he took under the cloud of the Persian Gulf crisis. He returns to Washington two days after announcing that he would meet with the Soviet leader in Helsinki next Sunday. Meanwhile, administration officials said today that details are still being worked out on the upcoming summit _ including the possiblity of extending it by one day so that Bush can meet with Finish President Mauno Koivisto. Deputy press secretary Roman Popadiuk said that such a courtesy session would likely come on Saturday, and that it could mean that the president would leave for Helsinki on Friday instead of on Saturday. Bush spent Sunday hosting his longtime friend, evangelist Billy Graham, at his seaside vacation home. The pair went to two churches for morning services. ``These are rather trying times and right now I would suggest we get our strength from being one nation under God,'' Bush told the congregation at the First Congregational Church. Officials said Bush's one-day summit with Gorbachev will likely entail about five hours of talks, focusing on the Persian Gulf crisis. They said the two men would also discuss conventional arms reduction talks between the two nations and regional issues, including Cambodia and Afghanistan. The president said he was pleased with Soviet cooperation on a number of global issues. ``I think it is important at this juncture that we discuss issues not just as they relate to Europe and try to update where we can on these arms negotiations, but also to discuss the Middle East,'' the president said. On the Persian Gulf, one official said of the two superpowers: ``We're comparing notes. We would be explaining where we think the situation is, where we would go.'' Side meetings between aides are not planned for this summit, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Such sessions usually are standard during summit meetings. Another official described the one-day session as more an ``informal meeting'' between the two leaders. On the subject of conventional arms talks, one official said the two leaders discussion ``would just be a review'' of the continuing negotiations to reduce Soviet and U.S. troop strength in Europe. Bush has said he does not expect the Soviet Union to mediate between Iraq and the United States. But the administration would welcome any pressure Gorbachev can bring against Iraq, a longtime recipient of Soviet arms. Bush said he has not spoken to Gorbachev since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2. He said he has not telephoned Gorbachev _ something he has done to many other world leaders _ ``Because I had anticipated seeing him.'' Bush proposed the meeting to Gorbachev a week ago. He held his proposal so closely that several top White House staff members did not know about it when they were in the Soviet Union last week. They were there with White House Chief of Staff John Sununu at Gorbachev's request to explain the technical workings of the U.S. executive branch. Sununu was informed of the arrangements for the summit meeting but was not a key player in setting it up, aides said. White House staff members met Sunday to begin working on logistical details and plans for contacting their Soviet counterparts. ``Everybody's scrambling to put their pieces together,'' one official said. Sig Rogich, who oversees White House advance logistics and imagemaking, ended his vacation early on Sunday to coordinate the planning. Sununu was driving his family back to Washington from his home state of New Hampshire on Sunday, a day after his arrival from the Soviet Union. Bush's wife, Barbara, and Gorbachev's wife, Raisa, also will travel to Helsinki.

Americans freed from the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait, after weeks as virtual prisoners of Iraqi soldiers outside the walls, say the comrades they left behind face mounting hunger, thirst and weariness. As the 47 Americans arrived Sunday, the few who met with reporters painted a grim picture of life inside the eight-block compound just across a six-lane highway from a Persian Gulf beach. Iraq's ambassador to the United States, Mohamed al-Mashat, who met the former hostages at Washington-Dulles International Airport on Sunday, told them, ``I come to welcome our guests here.'' His remarks got a cold shoulder.

Saddam Hussein has a fleet of more than 150 transport aircraft, including airliners plundered from Kuwait, that could be used to beat the United Nations-ordered embargo on trade with Iraq. But aviation experts stress that any attempt at airborne blockade-busting is fraught with difficulties and dangers, for both sides. They note, too, that an airlift would likely be little more than a gesture of defiance because it could never carry enough supplies to feed Iraq's 17 million people or enough military materiel to make a serious difference in Saddam's confrontation with the West. ``The sheer amount of cargo that would be needed to resupply a whole country by air is mind-boggling,'' said Don Kerr of London's International Institute for Strategic Studies.

Heavily armed Bedouins sit under a tent guarding a building identified by a new sign outside as housing offices of the Kuwaiti government-in-exile's Ministry of Oil. This is the forward command post for the Kuwaiti resistance movement. Its day-to-day operations include smuggling ammunition and communications equipment into Iraqi-occupied Kuwait, Kuwaiti exiles say. The Saudi-Kuwait border is just three miles to the north. ``All the operations to Kuwait come via Khafji,'' said a senior Kuwaiti guerrilla leader, who spoke on condition of anonymity out of fear of Iraqi reprisals.

With one day to go before classes resume at the University of Florida, police are studying what they vaguely described as ``messages'' left by the killer of five college students. Investigators on Sunday also said they reduced their list of prime suspects from eight to four, and clues left by the killer are helping. The slayings have terrorized the campus, where students are on a Labor Day break until Tuesday. ``The messages were given to us from the crime scenes,'' said police Lt. Sadie Darnell. ``The messages are indirect that we're interpreting to be messages of some importance.''

The countdown began today for NASA's third attempt to launch Columbia with the Astro observatory after engineers solved the latest problem to befall the mission. Liftoff is scheduled for 1:20 a.m. EDT Thursday. It will be the first shuttle launch in more than four months _ the longest gap between missions since flights resumed following the 1986 Challenger disaster. ``It's been a long, hot summer, and we're just glad to be getting back into the flight business,'' said NASA spokesman Dick Young. The shuttle fleet had been temporarily grounded after hydrogen leaks were discovered on two of the three orbiters, including Columbia. NASA decided on a Thursday launch after re-establishing full contact with the X-ray telescope inside Columbia's cargo bay. The telescope is one of four that constitute the $150 million Astro observatory.

People convicted of savings and loan fraud are getting harsher prison sentences than the typical white-collar criminal, according to Justice Department figures. Thirty-seven of those convicted for S&L crimes since Oct. 1, 1988, have not been jailed. But the 128 who received prison sentences got an average of 3.2 years, according to department statistics. That compares to an average 2.5 years for all federal fraud cases, including embezzlement and forgery, according to a study compiled last year by the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics. That study used figures from 1987, the most recent year available. The average sentence for embezzlement during 1987 was 1.8 years while the average sentence for mail and wire fraud was 2.6 years.

Oh, to be chumming on Lake Chargoggagoggmanchauggagoggchaubunagungamaugg. By the time you've pronounced it, you've probably hooked a bass in this popular fishing spot in southern Massachusetts, which boasts the longest name in the United States. Also known as Lake Webster, its Indian name means, ``I fish on my side, you fish on your side and nobody fishes in the middle.'' The lake is among dozens of geographic oddities celebrated in a new Library of Congress exhibition titled ``A World of Names,'' which opens Thursday through Jan. 15. The show marks the 100th anniversary of the U.S. Board on Geographic Names, the federal authority that has officially recognized nearly 7 million foreign and domestic names for use in government maps and publications.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most major foreign currencies Monday and gold prices were higher in thin trading. In Frankfurt, dealers said they did not want to get caught without dollars in their portfolios if fighting broke out in the Gulf. One noted that United Nations Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar failed to make any diplomatic progress this weekend in talks to mediate the dispute. But a London trader said there was no fundamental reason for the dollar's rise. ``There have been no large positions taken and nothing has changed. It's just a lack of fresh ideas,'' he said. Without any fundamental news to guide the market, dealers said most of the week would be spent predicting the outcome of Friday's U.S. employment figures. But, the August jobs data will likely confirm other numbers suggesting a slowdown in the U.S. economy, traders said. In Tokyo, the dollar fell to a closing 143.55 Japanese yen from 144.50 yen at Friday's close. Later, in London, it fell to 143.54 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.8730 from $1.8900 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: 1.5837 German marks, up from 1.5758; 1.3158 Swiss francs, up from 1.3075; 5.3080 French francs, up from 5.2825; 1.7840 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7685; 1,179.00 Italian lire, up from 1,169.00, and 1.1535 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1552 Bullion dealers said the Labor Day holiday in the United States, where financial markets were closed Monday, and a lack of new developments in the Gulf standoff left dealers with little to trade on and markets were quiet. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $387.00 a troy ounce, up from $384.45 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $387.50, up from $384.00 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.11 to close at a bid $386.61. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.83 a troy ounce, up from $4.81 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Share Prices Rise
DOC.TEXT: Share prices rose Monday on the London Stock Exchange but the Labor Day holiday on Wall Street held down trading volume. At the close, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 3.8 points, or 0.18 percent, at 2,166.6. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index closed down 6.2 points at 1,687.4, slightly down on Friday's figure of 1,693.6. Volume Monday was 220.2 million shares. The Financial Times 500-share index was up 2.45 at 1,160.96.

DOC.HEAD: EC Foreign Ministers To Meet Friday on Gulf
DOC.TEXT: The foreign ministers of the European Community nations plan to meet in Rome Friday to discuss the Gulf crisis and U.S. President George Bush's appeal for more financial aid in confronting Iraq, authorities said Monday. The 12-member Community will use the meeting to signal its positions to Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev before the superpower summit, an official said. ``The voice of the Community will express itself Friday, before the (U.S.-Soviet) meeting on Sunday,'' Italian Foreign Ministry spokesman Giovanni Castellaneta told a briefing. The one-day meeting Friday will be held under the chairmanship of Gianni De Michelis, the Italian foreign minister whose country currently holds the EC's rotating chairmanship. Castellaneta said the ministers will discuss aiding countries damaged by their participation in the U.N. trade embargo imposed on Iraq after its Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. He mentioned Jordan, Turkey and Egypt in particular. He also said the ministers would be ``taking into account the request of Bush'' for more financial support. Bush appealed last Thursday to allied countries to help pay for part of the U.S. military deployment in the Gulf and to assist nations hurt by the trade embargo against Iraq.

DOC.HEAD: Trading Volume Light on World Financial Markets During U.S. Holiday
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Day holiday in the United States and the unsuccessful end of talks between the United Nations secretary general and Iraq's foreign minister kept trading light in major financial markets Monday. Stock prices were down sharply on thin trading in Tokyo, London prices rose slightly and in Frankfurt stocks were down a bit also on light trading. ``If there is the slightest bit of news, traders are poised to begin selling,'' Kazuhiro Nomura, a stock trader with New Japan Securities Co. in Tokyo. The dollar started its day with a decline in Tokyo, closing at 143.55 yen, down 0.95 yen from Friday's close. Later Monday in London, the dollar was up against most major currencies. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average, the Tokyo exchange's most closely watched indicator, fell 557.94 points, or 2.15 percent, closing at 25,420.43 points. A light 360 million shares changed hands. In London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 3.8 points, or 0.18 percent, at 2,166.6. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index closed down 6.2 points at 1,687.4, slightly down on Friday's figure of 1,693.6. Volume Monday was 220.2 million shares. The Financial Times 500-share index was up 2.45 at 1,160.96. The German Stock Index lost 0.29 points to finish at 1,629.22 points. ``There is no mood to buy,'' said one operator. ``There is no new bullish incentives.'' In London, the British pound fell to $1.8730 from $1.8900 late Friday. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Friday: 1.5837 German marks, up from 1.5758; 1.3158 Swiss francs, up from 1.3075; 5.3080 French francs, up from 5.2825; 1.7840 Dutch guilders, up from 1.7685; 1,179.00 Italian lire, up from 1,169.00, and 1.1535 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1552 Bullion dealers said the U.S. holiday and a lack of new developments in the Gulf standoff left dealers with little to trade on and markets were quiet. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $387.00 a troy ounce, up from $384.45 bid late Friday. In Zurich, the metal rose to a closing bid of $387.50, up from $384.00 bid late Friday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold rose $3.11 to close at a bid $386.61. Silver bullion rose in London to a late bid price of $4.83 a troy ounce, up from $4.81 bid late Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Northwest Confirms Airbus Order
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines will take delivery from Airbus Industrie of 75 commercial jets, and has taken out options on 30 more planes, the company said Monday. The deal, announced at the Farnborough Air Show, is worth $4.6 billion, said Northwest and Airbus, a consortium of European aircraft manufacturers and engine makers. The order for delivery of 75 of the A320 jets confirms a tentative order placed by Northwest in 1989. At that time, the airline made 25 firm orders and took 75 other orders subject to confirmation on a series of dates through 1994. The options cover the A321, a stretch version of the A320, scheduled to enter service in the first quarter of 1994. Northwest is Airbus' biggest customer. Airbus Industrie also announced Monday that the Australian airlines, Ansett, had signed a contract for 10 A321s in a $350 million deal.

DOC.HEAD: Asiana Orders and Options Boeing Jets Worth Up to $6 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Asiana Airlines has ordered 27 Boeing jetliners and taken options on 24 more in a deal that could be worth up to $6 billion, the South Korean carrier and Boeing Co. announced Monday. The contract was signed by Asiana chairman Hwang In-sun and Boeing Commercial Airplane Group president Dean Thornton at the Farnborough International Airshow in Farnborough, England, Asiana said. In becoming Boeing's latest multibillion-dollar customer, Asiana placed firm orders for six 747-400 Passenger-Combies, three 747-400 freighters, 10 767-300s and eight 737-400s. That order is worth $3 billion. Asiana, which began operating only two years ago exclusively with Boeing planes, also took options on nine more 747-400s, eight 767-300s and seven 737-400s. If all the options are filled, the total order of the 51 planes would be worth $6 billion. The first delivery is scheduled in late 1991 and the last in 1999, Asiana said. The Seoul-based carrier said it ordered the planes with the intention of expanding its international flights, which are now limited to Japan. Asiana plans to add Taipei and Hong Kong later this year and add Singapore, Bangkok and some U.S. points next year. Asiana, South Korea's second-largest airline after Korean Air, currently operates a fleet of 10 737-400s and two 737-500s, all under lease.

DOC.HEAD: Corry Discussed Sale Of Steel Units, Paper Reports
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. Chairman Charles A. Corry has explored the possibility of selling the company's steel operations to foreign investors in the last few months, according to a report published Monday. Corry told The New York Times he would be willing to sell the steel unit at the right price, but said he did not expect such a sale to occur soon because of a weakness in the industry. ``The company has been growing in the energy business and reducing its exposure to the steel business,'' Corry said. ``And that will continue to be the trend.'' The discussions, with British Steel PLC and others, came on the heels of a USX effort to defeat a similar proposal made by New York financier Carl C. Icahn, who holds a 13 percent stake in USX. Shareholders rejected Icahn's plan in May. USX executives whom the Times did not identify said Icahn's move made it clear to the company that there was increased sympathy for splitting the steel business from energy interests. Icahn had advocated issuing shares in separate companies upon a split and said the value would grow afterward. An economic forecaster said Corry opposed Icahn's proposal because ``he thought the timing was wrong'' last spring. ``The market was still headed downward during the Icahn situation,'' said Christopher Plummer of the WEFA Group of Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. ``And USX would not be in the best position to sell assets.'' USX, which owns Marathon Oil and Texas Oil and Gas, was known as U.S. Steel until 1986. Analysts told the Times another possible purchaser of the USX steel units is Pohang Iron and Steel Co. The South Korean company operates a joint venture with USX in Pittsburg, Calif. Neither Pohang nor British Steel would comment on the matter.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Stymied in Effort to Boost Oil Production
Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union, hungry for hard currency, is reaping a windfall from higher oil prices and would like to increase exports to take advantage of shortages caused by the Mideast crisis. But it can't. The problem is an antiquated and long mismanaged Soviet petroleum industry unable to boost production. It may, in fact, yield 500,000 fewer barrels a day this year than last, Western analysts say. The Soviet Union produced about 12.1 million barrels of oil a day last year, a sixth of the world's total and more than Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Kuwait combined. It exported 3.7 million barrels a day _ more than Iraq _ with about half going to the West. ``They are producing at maximum capacity and their production is declining. There's no way they can get increased production,'' said John Lichtblau, chairman of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. Not only is the Soviet industry unable to boost production, its problems with nuclear reactors have added to the domestic demand. The Soviet Union's appetite for oil is second only to the United States. ``There's no way that they can take advantage of what's happening in the market,'' said Robert Ebel, vice president for international affairs for the Enserch Corp., an engineering and construction company. Ebel and other U.S. experts acknowledge that the Soviets are expected to gain hundreds of millions of dollars in additional hard currency in the coming months if the higher oil prices stand. It's estimated that every $1 a barrel increase could mean $1 billion a year in additional hard currency for the Soviet economy. Last year, oil exports brought $20 billion in hard currency into the Soviet Union, accounting for about 40 percent of the country's hard currency earnings. As oil prices began to climb after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Soviet oil bound for exports also became more valuable. A Moscow business publication, Kommersant, estimated recently that the worldwide jump in oil prices could increase Soviet hard currency revenue by $750 million by the end of the year. Some Western analysts suggested the increase could be twice that. If the Soviets export 1.3 million barrels a day to the West and prices continue to hover at $25 a barrel, compared with $16 a barrel before the Iraqi crisis, they stand to gain $1.5 billion in additional hard currency this year. The Soviets also have said they want Eastern block countries, where the other half of Soviet oil exports are sent, to begin paying in hard currency next year, according to U.S. oil experts. But the Soviet windfall will be muted by declining production that also will force down exports. Production at its Mammoth field on the edge of Siberia reportedly has declined by one-fourth since 1988. Based on performance over the first seven months of the year, the Soviets may average only 11.6 million barrels a day in 1990, compared with 12.14 million barrels a day in 1989. ``That's a rather dramatic drop,'' said Ebel, the Enserch executive and former U.S. intelligence expert. ``For what they have to sell to the West, they're going to get more money. But the amount of oil is going to be less.'' Soviet oil reserves are estimated to be more than 60 billion barrels, twice that of the United States. And the Soviets are wooing Western petroleum companies in the hope of expanding exploration and improving production facilities plagued by years of mismanagement, outdated equipment, deteriorating pipelines and a shortage of money for capital improvements. In the past, the Soviets shied away from seeking out foreigners in developing its vast oil reserves. Even when oil prices were declining, the Soviet government poured large amounts of funds into oil development and boosted production. Revenue from oil exports pumped up other areas of the economy. But the cost of exploration for Soviet oil has nearly tripled in the last five years and the Kremlin last year began to reduce funds for oil development. It also stepped up its search for outside technical assistance and began negotiating possible joint exploratory ventures with Western oil companies. Both Chevron Corp. and Texaco Corp. have reached preliminary agreements with the Soviets on joint oil exploratory ventures. A number of U.S. service companies also are involved in oil exploration with the Soviets, as is Elf Aquitaine, France's largest oil company. ``They want to get Western technology and capital,'' says Lichtblau of the New York-based Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. But, he adds, those new ventures are unlikely to have an impact on production for years to come. ``They desperately need American technology and American finances'' to boost oil exploration and production, said Henry Shuler, a Soviet expert at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington. ``About all they can hope to do in the short to medium terms is slow the rate (of oil production) decline.''

DOC.HEAD: Drug Companies Offering Medicaid Discounts to Ward off Legislation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Tuesday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Upjohn Co. and other pharmaceutical firms are offering Medicaid discounts as they try to pre-empt proposed legislation that would cap the cost of drugs sold to the poor. Last week, Kalamazoo-based Upjohn followed other industry leaders' discount offers by proposing a $1.35 rebate for each Medicaid prescription filled with its drugs. ``I think it's a smart move to try to eliminate the need for legislation,'' said Ronald Nordmann, an industry analyst with Paine-Webber. ``It probably won't mean much in terms of losses, either, since Medicaid sales represent only about 10 percent of the market.'' But there's a catch: Any state that accepts a company's discount must offer all of the company's drugs to Medicaid patients, even the expensive ones that some states now refuse. That's expected to create virtual monopolies in some states by knocking competing drugs off reimbursement eligibility lists. Most of the largest drug companies have refused in the past to offer the same discounts to Medicaid programs that they have given to the departments of Defense and Veterans Affairs as well as hospitals and large health maintenance organizations. But earlier this year, the U.S. Health and Human Services Department said it wanted to cut 1991 Medicaid expenditures by $300 million, prompting a legislative proposal that would restrict the drugs covered by Medicaid, thereby forcing competitive bidding by drug companies. Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., who introduced the bill, said it would save between $100 million and $200 million each year. Congressional hearings on the plan will be held in mid-September. The cost of drugs sold to Medicaid totals $3.5 billion a year. At least 19 state Medicaid programs have already limited the drugs they offer poor patients, often excluding more expensive, patented drugs, as a way to get the drug companies to negotiate. Medicaid officials say drug prices are the fastest rising segment of their programs. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association is adamantly opposed to legislation that would restrict access to any drug. It says a federally mandated program for competitive bidding would lead to inferior health care for the poor. ``Under the bill, manufacturers of chemically different drugs that treat the same disease would be required to bid against each other and the cheapest medicines _ which are almost always the oldest ones _ would win the bid,'' association spokesman Jeff Trewhitt said Friday. ``Medicaid patients would be deprived of some medicines and in many cases would be getting second-class care.'' Trewhitt said many medical groups and advocacy groups for the poor are also opposed to the legislation. The association has remained silent on the individual companies' discount plans. Pryor, chairman of the Senate Special Committee on Aging, said last week that the current discount plans _ offered by Merck & Co., Pfizer Inc., Glaxo Inc. and Upjohn _ aren't good enough. ``While I commend these four companies for offering national proposals, the savings for Medicaid and the safeguards to assure these savings are just not there,'' Pryor said. Merck, which has agreed to offer states the same discounts it gives other health care providers, has already signed up about 20 states. Upjohn, which announced its plans more than three months later, has signed up just Maryland so far. While the discounts could cost the participating companies a significant amount in the short run, analysts say those losses could be more than made up over time if the companies win enough Medicaid contracts.

DOC.HEAD: In Shaky Economic Times, Rumors Can Take on a Life of Their Own
Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: When Franklin D. Roosevelt told a nation mired in the Depression that ``the only thing we have to fear is fear itself,'' he was talking about the kind of economic fright that turns rumors into reality. Bank of New England got a taste of just what kind of damage false rumors can do in a nervous economic climate last week, when talk hit Wall Street that federal regulators were preparing for a takeover. Area economists said Massachusetts' souring economy _ and the recent spate of federal bank takeovers nationwide _ have given rumors a potency they might not hold in better times. ``I do think that the bad news sometimes can be cumulative and indeed feeds on itself,'' said Wayne Ayers, chief economist at the Bank of Boston. James Howell, a former Bank of Boston economist who now runs his own consulting firm, agreed that rumors thrive during a faltering economy. ``When things begin to turn sour there is sort of a notion that `I hope the bad things that are happening to other people won't happen to me.' Therefore, I respond to rumor as if some of it or all of it may be fact,'' he said. In the Bank of New England flap, a congressional candidate gave the rumor a substantial push. Democratic hopeful Ted Dimauro faxed a statement to news organizations lamenting the supposed federal takeover. The bank has been struggling to recover from a downturn in the state's economy _ especially from a decline in the real estate market _ and has operated under federal scrutiny since early this year. Federal officials issued strong statements that reports of the bank's demise were wrong. But there was some damage. Bank of New England's stock plunged 38.5 percent to $1 a share Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. ``The problem is that irresponsibility like this press release can kill a bank,'' Ellen Stockdale, a spokeswoman for the Comptroller of the Currency in Washington, which regulates federally chartered banks, said after Dimauro's statement appeared. Dimauro later apologized, blaming an aide for releasing a statement without his final approval. And the bank's stock more than doubled the next day, rising $1.12{ to $2.12{. The incident highlights just how jittery investors and others watching the market have become. In particular, it demonstrates an uncertainty about banks sparked by the savings and loan crisis and the recent spate of bank failures nationwide. Banks traditionally are considered conservative, reliable financial institutions. ``For the first time since 1933 ... people are wondering whether or not they have their savings or deposits in the right bank, the one that will not fail,'' Howell said. ``That is the most significant change in thinking in the post-World War II period.'' Howell and Ayers agreed that the recent problems in the banking industry have been sparked, in part, because there are too many banks, and the industry is adjusting. There are between 13,000 and 14,000 commercial banks in the country, and about 4,500 savings banks, they said. ``We don't need any of the 4,500. Period. You can just mark them off,'' Howell said. Rumors may threaten to become self-fulfilling prophecies until the economy levels off, Ayers said. ``I think a lot will depend on the health of the economy,'' he said. ``I think if we can sidestep recession nationally, these rumors, this falloff in confidence, will gradually arrest itself.''

Wholesale gasoline and crude oil prices moved higher in the futures market but failed to recover all the ground lost earlier in the week. Traders said buying picked up Friday as the stalemate in the Middle East dragged on. Early waves of selling this week had been inspired by hopes for a quick negotiated settlement to the crisis, which has threatened the world's oil supplies. Light sweet crude oil rose 55 cents on the New York Mercantile Exchange to end the week at $27.32 per barrel on contracts for October delivery.

Members of the International Energy Agency agreed to work together to avert oil shortages from the Persian Gulf crisis, but they said the threat to supplies had eased. Senior officials of the IEA, comprised of 21 industrialized nations, said Friday they expected production hikes authorized by OPEC nations on Wednesday would counter the effects of the U.N. boycott of Iraq and Kuwait.

Driving to the family barbecue this Labor Day weekend cost more than it had in years, but higher gasoline prices apparently aren't keeping fuel-thirsty Americans off the road. ``If it would be $5 a gallon, I'd still go away for the weekend,'' Bud Case said as he shelled out $26.13 to fill up his camper Friday in Charleston, W.Va. The American Automobile Association said gasoline prices were averaging $1.307 a gallon for self-serve regular unleaded. That's up from $1.084 over the July 4 holiday and $1.062 on last Labor Day. The AAA predicted a 2 percent decrease in Labor Day travel, but said higher gasoline is not the culprit.

The Resolution Trust Corp. plans to hire a special group of employees to watch for possible corruption as it sells hundreds of failed savings and loans. The RTC hopes to set up a team of 20 to 30 ``contractor cops'' this fall to oversee the sale of billions of dollars of S&L assets, spokeswoman Kate Spears said Friday.

Hundreds of Chrysler Corp.'s union workers punched out for the last time, accepting buyouts from the automaker designed to reduce the need for layoffs. The reduction Friday in the company's work force, expected to involve about 600 employees, comes as Chrysler negotiates a new national labor contract with the United Auto Workers union and as the financially struggling company seeks ways to cut costs.

The Persian Gulf crisis has not been kind to the shipping industry, whose stocks have tumbled on fears tankers will be idled as insurance companies impose war-zone premiums and sailors demand hazardous duty pay. Analysts in world shipping capitals say the market, complex and highly sensitive at best, now also is confused. In some cases, it's nearing panic. Stock market shipping indexes have slumped about 25 percent worldwide since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, said a spokesman for Lloyd's List International in London.

When many travel agents around the country tried to lock in tickets for airline customers earlier this week, their computers balked. A deadline for cheap autumn fares combined with a new charge for higher jet fuel costs threw the nation's airline reservation system into what agents and airlines described as unprecedented gridlock Wednesday. As tens of thousands of Americans jammed phone lines seeking to book tickets, computers were so slow that getting reservation information often took 30 minutes or more. Some systems crashed.

Michigan's largest conservation and sportsmen's group has taken aim at J.C. Penney Co. Inc. for marketing boys' clothing with an anti-hunting message. ``The message that kids will pick up from this _ that the traditional hunting sports are wrong and that anyone who enjoys hunting is somehow dangerous and evil _ is simply outrageous,'' said Thomas Washington, executive director of the Michigan United Conservation Clubs. Penney spokesman Duncan Muir said Friday the company would make a decision on the merchandise next week.

While White House officials scrambled for information during the initial hours of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, AT&T's own crisis management center was plotting an escape for dozens of employees. An undisclosed number of American Telephone & Telegraph Co. employees were among a group of U.S. nationals working in Kuwait whose companies had security measures in place for such a crisis. ``Our security director was awakened about 3 o'clock in the morning by our people in a location in Kuwait City,'' AT&T spokesman Herb Linnen said Friday.

Stock prices rose, but trading set its slowest pace of the year Friday as the market coasted into the long Labor Day weekend. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials gained 21.04 to 2,614.36, finishing the week with a net gain of 81.44 points. Bond prices were narrowly mixed in a quiet, abbreviated session. The dollar advanced against most major currencies except the Japanese yen. Gold prices slipped. Grain and soybean futures prices were lower; energy futures rose; precious metals fell; cocoa futures gained; orange juice retreated; and livestock and pork futures were mixed.
